145364948.review:
[h1]Uh Oh - It's the Determined Noodle![/h1]

Don't let the childish graphics and upbeat soundtrack fool you. Beneath its colorful exterior lies a dark underbelly of terror, a machiavellian maze designed by the twisted genius of The Architect. This game is the digital equivalent to dancing with the devil. 

They always said Noodle was different from the other snakes. While the other noodles sunned themselves lazily by the watering hole, this Noodle lived for the thrill of the hunt. There is a dark intelligence shining behind that languid tongue, an all-consuming drive to dominate whatever lands dare cross his path.

Noodle's single-minded pursuit of gathering ridiculously placed gemstones shows a disturbing fixation on goal-oriented behavior. The fixated gaze, the flickering tongue - all signs of a calculated killer. That's no garden snake - it's an embodiment of the PCL-R checklist.

The level design, the obstacles, the puzzles, all serve to showcase Noodle's dark and twisted mind. Each level is a twisted labyrinth of danger and despair, where one wrong move could spell your doom. And as you navigate these treacherous terrains, the Determined Noodle's smirk will be etched into your soul, a constant reminder of the malevolence that lurks within.

As you guide this unstoppable force through his elaborate death mazes, it becomes horribly clear - you are merely a pawn in Noodle's sinister game. He slithers and slinks with focused determination, never hesitating to put others in harm's way to get what he wants. The smug self-satisfaction in noodle's face shows us a creature devoid of any guilt or remorse, a hunter on the prowl. Just look into those eyes - the icy emptiness of a true apex predator.

By world 2 you begin trembling at every shadow, haunted by Noodle's lurking presence just out of sight. Is that a phantom hiss on the wind, or his cold flesh sliding over sticks and stone, ever-closing in your position? Sanity itself hangs by a thread as you navigate deeper into his carefully crafted domains, built for no other purpose than to break the minds of those foolish enough to challenge his throne.

By world 3 I was a paranoid, jittery wreck. Every rustle of grass or chirp of bird was Noodle, closing in for the kill. What twisted machinations went on in that serpentine brain of his? What dark desires fueled his relentless pursuit of more, more, MORE gems? I've seen the work of many serial killers, but none so cunning and calculated as Noodle. He was like Hannibal Lecter with scales - always three moves ahead, and smiling that horrifying smile.

With every collected gem, his smirk grows wider. He's savoring the hunt. The façade crumbles. Noodle is no clumsy garden snake. He's a predator. A monster. Your hands shake on the controls as his face leers from the screen. Those dead eyes look right through you.

You begin to question it all. Who is The Architect? What does Noodle want? Is any of this real? Madness creeps in. Harmless distractions make you flinch. Every shadow holds lurking danger.

You've stared too long into Noodle's void. Something has stirred, deep in the reptilian part of your brain. Primal fear. You startle awake at night, grasping phantom gemstones, pursued by that ceaseless smirk...

That's when you hear it.. 'Uh Oh' - as the devil's mark is carved on your already shattered psyche, sending you deep down into the bottomless pit of the mind. 

It's over. Now you have become.. 

[b]BOTTOMFEEDER[/b]

It's a fun, unique little platformer.
Controls work fine, the camera is your worst enemy like in all 3d platformers, but it's not as bad as it could be. If there is a story, I haven't paid attention to it. I would prefer there was no dialogue at all. There is an annoying friend character like in all 3d platformers, but what ever it's saying is easily skipped.

The game looks nice and the level design in solid. Some missed opportunities, like the wind gameplay is just odd. It would seem like using it to float around was an obvious thing to do, but instead you get a one button quick time event where the annoying little bird just plays the game for you a little bit.

Like I said, the controls are fine. I got the hang of it quite fast and actually it works surprisingly well. Maybe after you learn the basics some little annoyances start to appear. Like the end part of the body is just a dead weight you drag around, it doesn't help you in any way and if your head hits an obstacle, it doesn't slow anything else down that the head. Which sometimes leads to annoying deaths as your head doesn't go where you want it to, but the rest of the body just zooms on and off the cliff.
I never found any use for the "grip" button, which the game keeps telling me is super duper vital - again and again. It seems it's just a suppression button for "slither". But I can just not press slither.

Anyways. I have had fun with the game. Paid a few euros during summer sale for this, and it's easily been worth the money!

137407330.review:
Snake Pass is a platformer game where you play as a snake with a bird sidekick, trying to restore pathways in the realms you're residing in. The main appeal of this game is the mechanic of moving around by only slithering and wrapping around things to reach different areas. 

The gameplay within this game can be seen in multiple ways. On one hand, the layout of levels are intuitive and attractive, with each level presenting a new and exciting challenge. I believe the gameplay is well constructed for the most part, and they even give you save spots right before or after difficult sections, so you don't need to feel nervous about dying once you finish a difficult section and need to go to the next one. But on the other hand, the difficulty and annoying nature of the movement of your character becomes frustrating very quickly. The levels take a while to complete if you are collecting every item, and if you are doing this, you are likely to need to make many difficult maneuvers to collect them, which may lead to many death or inconveniences, such as forgetting a coin near the start of the level once you are already near the end of the level. Factors like these make it hard to play more than 1-3 levels in one sitting. 

The soundtrack is also very nice. It is a small selection of songs, but they were very well made. My favorite track is from the lava realm, but the other realms have some solid tracks too.

Unfortunately, one of this game's weak points is the story and characterization. The story is irrelevant, and the characters simply don't have character. They are simply a means to an end. They are only here because you need someone to play as, and you need a sidekick to evoke the same feeling as games like Banjo-Kazooie or Spyro. Along with the lack of character in the characters, there isn't really much of a story to this game, which is fine. I generally understand why I'm collecting gems for gates in this game, but it doesn't feel like I'm really doing anything significant. It is more like I am just collecting things just because that is what the game tells me to do.

Overall, Snake Pass is a difficult game with an interesting gimmick. The story, characterization, and certain portions of the gameplay could be better; however, the game is an overall good experience. I wouldn't recommend this game to achievement hunters, as it is sort of a painful achievement hunt, but I would recommend this game to anyone who doesn't care about that.

137367980.review:
This is more of an interesting tech demo than a game. The controls and camera need a little bit of work, as it ends up feeling incredibly inconsistent to play. Everything is physics based, and I can't help but think that sometimes it is better to not make everything strictly based on physics in order to achieve a better feel and give the player a bit more control. It is a pretty finicky experience that had me janking my way around the levels sometimes, but getting janked by the level at other times.

As a game, there's really nothing of substance here. There are 15 levels but they may as well all be pretty much the same thing. The motif only slightly changes from level to level. The collectibles are literally just that, and don't actually do anything beyond giving you some sense of accomplishment I guess? It seems that if you get 100% you unlock a new skin, but there's very little reason to play the game after that unless you are intent on speedrunning.

If you can get the game on sale for a couple bucks or something, then it might be worth it just to mess around for a bit. Though it's really nothing to write home about, and they could have been much more imaginative with adding things like new abilities or a higher degree of variation in the levels. It would have been cool to see something like boss fights at the end of worlds, too. Either that, or some moments with set pieces that are interesting.

The checkpoint system is also a little wonky, with physical buttons you have to land on in order to save your progress in the level. If you just went through a big set of snaking around over a perilous void, grab the main collectible you need to beat the level, and then die after, you're going to have to do it all over again instead of just starting from when you collected the main piece. It can get a little annoying.

There are also cutscenes you can't skip that sort of overstay their welcome, and your spot in the level select isn't saved so you have to navigate back to the level you left off on one by one. The options menu is also pretty lacking. Minor problems, but they start to get old pretty fast.

Can't comment on the music because I turned it off and played my own.

137053700.review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=https://www.dragon-quill.net/christmas-steam-games-2022/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

A “platformer” where you play as a creature who can’t jump: a snake. While most games anthropomorphize snake characters to give them familiar control schemes, this game drills down into imagining what it would be like to control a real snake. The control scheme is deliberately weird and clunky — to the point that, according to Steam statistics, half of all players never even finished the first level! — but that’s what makes it so unique. Controls are similar to how vehicles are usually handled in video games: Instead of being able to freely move in any direction, you can only accelerate forwards and steer on the go. However, the physics of the snake’s body add more depth to this and are amazingly well-done. Climbing across objects requires you to coil around them for support, just like real snakes do, and you have to keep track of how your weight is distributed across such a long body to ensure you don’t lose balance. Also, moving in straight lines is very slow, but you can slither side-to-side to build up speed, which I thought was really neat. The controls initially feel very confusing and even basic tasks require deep concentration, but over time they become second nature. The whole thing is a really clever, inventive, and well-done idea. The game’s tagline is “Think like a snake,” and by the end I definitely was — like all good puzzle games, it encouraged me to expand my way of thinking.

Additionally, I really enjoyed the aesthetics. Environments are very colorful and well-lit, so important objects never feel hidden by the level design. Noodle himself is absolutely adorable, and I especially love the distressed noises he makes when he slips or grips tightly — it’s not only cute characterization, but a genuinely helpful audio cue to help you keep track of his huge body. Unlike in most platformers, I rarely felt frustrated by failures, because Noodle was so silly and charming I couldn’t stay mad at him.

My one criticism is that the game really needed a “skip cutscene” option. Cutscenes are replayed every time you revisit a previous level, which is a real pain in a collect-a-thon platformer where you’re encouraged to return to levels to get stuff you missed. Similarly, while I respect that you have to return to a checkpoint to record collectibles as obtained so you can’t just bypass the puzzle by making a suicide jump off a cliff, checkpoints could have been more frequent; there were many times where I had to re-collect items while redoing a difficult sequence I died on a lot. Something like Celeste‘s mechanic where they get recorded as soon as you touch safe ground would have been a lot smoother.

What a colorful, cute, polished mix of joy this game is.

The controls (keyboard+mouse for me) are done well and feel really intuitive. There's a learning curve to it (going straight for 100% collectibles from the beginning can be frustrating) but a few hours into the game you'll start really getting the hang of it. Sooner than later you'll find yourself sliding-stretching-curving-swinging like a really slick snake and it feels great.

The snake's ever-changing facial expressions and gasped groaning gives it so much character. 15 large, gorgeous locations to explore and find collectibles cleverly hidden and/or difficult to snatch (as you need to get back to any checkpoint for the pickups to count).

I did not find most of the game particularly difficult. Some select coins were challenging to grab but just playing the story mode is fine. That is until the last two levels where the difficulty spikes noticeably. Not to a point where it competes with hardcore platformers or anything but your younger brother probably won't get through it. I also saw someone complain about the snake being too slow, well perhaps you should pay a speck of attention at the tutorial and slither/zig-zag to go faster.

Anyway, the minor downsides are a few unskippable cutscenes and lack of rewards. There's a whole "unlocks" menu and you do unlock something for collecting all hidden coins in the game. But when it comes to beating all levels without dying, completing time trials, or playing the arcade mode you get nothing out of it. I wish they'd put something in but either way the content is incredible, start to finish.

135440038.review: I mean, before even playing the game, you know that Snake Pass will be very good, you get to control a cute, friendly snake! The fact that actually playing the game is also wonderful is just a bonus. The control scheme of Noodle is a really interesting one that is particularly effective at making you entirely rethink how to approach even the most basic of platforming challenges, replacing thoughts of jumping to new areas with understanding how to slither up the bits of environment surrounding you. It ends up having a dynamic more akin to a puzzle platformer than a more traditional one, where almost every obstacle's challenge stems from working out how to approach something as opposed to the execution of that approach itself.It's not as if the game doesn't require good execution at all either though, since the control scheme is initially pretty tough to wrap your head around all the intricacies of, particularly the careful balance you often need to strike between being very meticulous and being fast. The level design plays into this very nicely as well, with a lot of sections being built in such a way that you're able to bypass a lot of seemingly difficult challenges if you fully come to terms with the nuances of your movement, leading to an experience that feels rife with discovery that largely feels self-motivated. It goes a long way in making you feel like you're beginning to understand the unconventional methods you need to take to accomplish basic traversal without feeling directly enforced either, leading to a unique experience in a way that isn't as immediately apparent as the fact that you're playing as a snake.The presentation elevates things that bit further as well, with the beautiful, lush environments and fantastic soundtrack making it pretty pleasant to exist in these levels even if you're stuck at a particular section for an extended period of time while you're further refining your movement. One thing I think would've been nice is something to have added a bit more variety to the individual stages though, as while what the 15 levels here have still make for a fun time, it does begin to wear out its welcome a tiny bit by the final couple, and I think it's just because of the lack of real variety beyond a couple of clever obstacles that still didn't feel like quite enough to differentiate one level from the next. It's definitely not a dealbreaker since there's some appeal in coiling around the various poles and platforms to reach greater heights even after you've done it countless times, but some more unique stage elements would definitely elevate this further. Even with that said though, this is great, would highly recommend for people to play this if they're interested in seeing a rather fresh take on collectathons.8/10

135420721.review: [list]A imperfect but fun platformmer in the vein of a less stressful Getting Over It.[/list][list]Unfortunately the saving/checkpoint system is outdated and just bad. You either spend 10% of your time backtracking to checkpoints or dying and redoing simple platforming segments. Where Getting Over It is built on stress and sequential platforming segments, Snake Pass is designed as individual challenges, but with 30 seconds of boring backtracking to save your progress in between. The game would be shorter but way more entertaining if touching ground with your entire body saved the game and you just had to worry about platforming and not meta gaming the system.[/list][list]Furthermore, you cannot even save a level half way through and play later; And when the game restarts, instead of hovering over your next level, you start with the first level selected, forcing you to browse each level one at a time to whatever your current position is. It has a champaisn, with a story, where levers unlock one at a time, and your position is not evne saved![/list][list]Overall, a unique and fun game but the devs just don't respect the player's time at all. It feels like they simply never played the game in the way a player would.[/list]

131600928.review:
HOT GARBAGE is the best way to describe this game.

-Here's the elevator pitch:
Hey, you know QWOP? Surgeon Simulator? Mount Your Friends? I am Bread?Getting Over it? 
You know those wonky control games you play for five minutes until the novelty wears off?
Yeah, how would you like a full game of that? 
Well, do I have good news for you. Here's a game that would've been better off had it remained a game jack project.

Boasting luscious Nintendo bright aestethics, wonderfully rendered in Unreal Engine and the whimsical UI design of a Rayman game, I present to you a game which is best enjoyed by watching others play it for 10 minutes then forgetting it ever existed.

You think to yourself: this looks relaxing, this looks fun, this could be my chill-out game when I'm feeling tired. But alas, NO.

Despite having perfectly competent art direction and an immaculately executed core mechanic, the design is atrocious.
This is a sin onto the gaming space, bringing in early tweens restrictive hand-holding and tutorializing like a Wii era 3rd party Nintendo game.

The companion character is worse than unncesary. This worthless, piece of dung hummingbird for some reason keeps popping up tutorializing the most basic things, interupting the gameplay every 30 seconds with unskippable cutscenes which triggered at the start of each level. 

THis utter trash character can interupt you after you just cleared a quarter of the stage, just to announce" HURR DURR! OH NO! THE GEMS ARENT IN THE PORTAL. WE HAVE TO GET THE GEMS> REMEMBER? THE THING YOU DO EVERY LEVEL? HURR DURR?
And then you die because his cutscene interupted you while you were scaling an obstacle and it moved the camera and killed your controls so now you fell, and YOU LOSE ALL PROGRESS.

Yes, for God-knows-what-reason this game has no freaking persistance. If you fall down a cliff you lose all progress. WHY?! Why in a game with NO TIMER and NO LIVES I have to finish every level perfectly without one slip-up or I lose all my progress.

You know what the fun in these collect-athon games is? IT'S EXPLORATION.
How am I supposed to want to explore and get everything if everytime I try something fun I get punished and have to go through the whole stage again. 

I end up just wanting to get the gems to unlock the exit and go to the next stage instead of wasting my time trying the same stupid obstacles over and over again and losing all my progress.

Whoeve designed these systems literally ruined all the work their more competent colleagues did.

Freaking unplayable. This is just a frustration factory. 
A real shame. 
If you just corrected these minor aspects, which would actually be removing components, rather than any creative work, you'd have an amazing chill game.

If someone makes a mod to remove the stupid humming bird and stop the progress reset on falls, this game is worth a spin.
Until then, stay the hell away.

130144542.review:
WHAT IS THIS GAME?
This game is all about mastering the wonky controls of a snake protoganist in order to collect items throughout obstacle courses.

WHAT THIS GAME *IS NOT*
This game doesn't involve solving any puzzles; the levels are designed like obstacle courses, not puzzles. Also, it's *not* particularly relaxing; you'll often find yourself tightening your grip on the mouse/controller and cringing as you try not to slip off ledges.

WHAT GENRE IS THIS GAME?
It's not quite an adventure in the spirit of Banjo-Kazooie. I would actually liken it more to Mirror's Edge. Like Mirror's Edge, the game is based entirely around your skills with a particular set of moves/controls.

HOW DIFFICULT IS THIS GAME?
There's a steep learning curve at the beginning, but about an hour or two into the game, you'll realize that the game is pretty easy to complete. However, the game is significantly more difficult if you try to collect all the collectibles and *especially* if you try to collect all the Steam achievements. This game is good for both casual gamers and "serious" gamers alike.

IS THIS GAME WORTHWHILE?
Yes, this game is definitely worthwhile. The most common complaint among the negative reviews seems to be that people don't like the controls. Well, mastering the controls is the whole point! Be prepared for a steep learning curve over the first hour of gameplay, but if you're OK with that, then I think most people would enjoy this game.

Snake Pass is a short physics based 3d platformer/collectathon that has a different approach to the genre. Controls are the main mechanic in this game. You slither and wrap yourself around poles to overcome obstacles and collect required stones. Controls will seem hard at the beginning but honestly it feels ingenious and satisfying.

129999270.review:
This game [i]slithers[/i] right into that sweet spot between frustrating and challenging, but there are a few aspects that often tip it over to frustrating:

-Pacing: Platforming with Noodle is a slow and precarious process. Messing up means you've committed that much more time to redoing a section, and the added bonus of losing the collectables you've gathered since the last checkpoint makes it all the more tedious if you're a completionist. 

-Camera: When you get to the rotating bits, it becomes hell trying to maneuver Noodle while also maneuver the camera around the moving object.

-Accessibility settings: There are none, barring the "easy" preset for the controls. For a game that seems to market toward all ages, you'd think it would incorporate some options to make it more comfortable and enjoyable for everyone. (And no option to disable controller vibration in-game? [i]Smh my head...[/i])

-Cutscenes: You can't skip em. They aren't all that interesting and they start to get pretty annoying when you want to replay levels. 

Overall, Snake Pass is cute and fun the majority of the time. The pursuit of mastering the controls is the game's focal point and what I keep coming back for. But keeping in mind its issues, I'd recommend you pick it up [b]only[/b] when it's on sale.

For something that is relaxing and fun most of the time, this sweet little game has the ability to evoke a surprising amount of rage. ;)

I got this as a gift and after trying for a couple of hours got a bit frustrated and at that time would not have recommended it.
I don't know if it was just a bad time for me or what, but having given it another chance I had quite a bit of fun and would definitely recommend it now.

Animations are nice, graphics and music are pleasant and relaxing. Story is simple and cute.
The gameplay is fun and smooth and mechanics work mostly as probably intended. This can be frustrating if you're not used to how it all works especially if going for some harder collectibles right from the beginning. To maximise enjoyment of this game, I would highly recommend taking the time in the first few levels to really get used to the controls and behaviour of the snake body and how best to utilise that when moving along climbable objects horizontally and vertically. There are also ways to creatively use some of the mechanics for collectibles to make things a bit easier.

Completing the levels isn't hard, some of the achievements and collectibles are the difficult part, but if you're interested in trying, it is definitely important to master the mechanics to avoid tearing your hair out from the frustration of dying for 100th time like I did the first time I tried playing it ;) For me at least it made a huge difference once my brain clicked on how to best approach certain types of situations/climbable material.

Kind of annoying:
- Sometimes the mechanics don't work how you might expect, but once I got used to how it works in game it wasn't too much of a problem, just occasional bits where it could have been better.
- Cutscenes unskippable even on second playthrough which is a bit of a pain when replaying for achievements

126945821.review:
Strange game.

THE GOOD
It is competent in exactly one aspect: it's core-gameplay. In my book, the game nails the movement of the snake. This is so unique and ultimately satisfying, that I'd go so far to call this game an 'experience' (in the good sense).

THE MEH
All the rest is either okay or flawed. The soundtrack, although apparently composed by the Donkey Kong-guy doesn't go beyond serviceable in my opinion. Graphics and story also don't get in the way of the fun, but are not amazing either.
The learning curve is more of a tiny wall. Steam achievements show that like 50% of players drop off before the first real achievement (crazy!) and only about 5% finish the game. I also raged after 20min, but after like an hour it clicked and I felt totally comfortable.

THE BAD
- The camera comes close to making this unplayable at times. 
- There is a sense of 'jankyness' that runs through the game, in how the main menu or stage select looks like.
- The game actually straight up got confused at some point and soft-locked.
- In a puzzle-/precision-platformer, each challenge should be tackled in succession and then saved, like it's mostly done in Celeste. Instead, there are (admittedly rather frequent) checkpoints. But there is no joy in redoing stuff you already mastered. A game like this should not induce risk-reward trade-offs, but should encourage players to attempt difficult maneuvers at all times.
- The open-worldyness does not help the game. Partly due to the abysmal camera, I did not enjoy exploration at all and just wanted my gauntlet of platforming challenges.
- Too frequent, unwanted hand-holding in the beginning (gets better).
- Too short with only 6 hours of playtime. To be fair - the lack of diversity in gameplay also meant that I would not have wished for more game after that point.

THE VERDICT
- Regular price is €20. If money isn't too tight, you are willing to invest in a game and/or you want to play something you never played before, then I'd recommend the game even at that price. Otherwise it'd be a no.
- Sale price is €3: go for it!
For all its flaws, I must recommend the devs for trying something radically different, executing formidably where it counts the most and creating a memorable experience.

Review for keyboard+mouse. (gameplay only, but it's not like this game has any story in it) TL;DR : don't bother.

123043876.review:
[b]TL;DR: Very original, cute and enjoyable experience, assuming you have the patience to learn unique/unusual mechanics. [/b]

I had a great time with this game. Remarkably, the whole thing (controlling a snake in 3D in a platforming environment) feels original, and technically, I think the goal has been well achieved. It does however require time to get used to the controls, and even more to master them. It gave me some kind of Octodad vibes, except without the arguably social commentary, and much slower paced. As such, especially getting some of the trickiest collectables can be stressful, in a good way though if you do have the patience to learn the ropes.

I must admit I didn't personally find the game as hard as what its reputation seems to indicate, and so it took me about 7 hours to finish the game and get all the collectibles. That being said, the game could indeed use a bit more checkpoints at times and the camera does tend to fight against the player in more enclosed areas. I'd say don't forget you can zoom in and out a little, which sometimes makes a big difference. And while we're at it, you might want to know (at least I wish I knew) that after finishing the game once, you receive a special power, snake vision, that lets you see through walls and thus, no need to worry much about the more excessively hidden collectibles you might miss (assuming you care about them).

The visuals and the music are amazing! Although both could arguably gain from more diversity after a while. Honestly, only four songs for all the levels gets a bit repetitive, especially if you take the time to reach the optional collectibles. But in the end, it remains accessory to the experience, which is profoundly mechanical. In any case, I was quite pleasantly surprised! There's just no other game like it (that I know of).
8/10

122835994.review:
Snake Pass is an alright game, but I don't think I can recommend it at full price.

The main conceit of Snake Pass is that well, you're a snake named Noodle. This means that your method of movement is fairly unique, as you have to slither around and coil yourself around poles in order to get around. It's quite awkward to try to coil yourself around stuff but later on it'll become second nature to you. It is quite slow compared to other games and "platforming" rewards careful patient movement, as rushing or panicking will likely cause Noodle to slip off whatever pole or bit of landscape he's on and send him plummeting to his doom.

However, this same slowness can be a detriment to the experience. The game is hard and you will die a lot especially when trying to gather all the various collectibles. While there are checkpoints scattered across the levels failure means you'll keep having to repeat the same careful movements over and over just to get back to where you failed at prior. This gets time-consuming and tedious.

Speaking of time-consuming, the game likes to wrest control of Noodle and the camera for unskippable pseudo-tutorial sections. You'll have to deal with them every time you respawn or replay a level. In fact, these forced pauses can straight up kill Noodle if you activated them in a bad spot! The length of death animations and how long it takes to resume control when respawning at a checkpoint is also a bit too long.

The camera itself is quite wonky, it's not uncommon to have your vision of Noodle and obstacles that you need to navigate obscured by random objects being in the way or because the camera is too zoomed in. It can be quite disorienting and infuriating when Noodle dies cuz you can't tell what's going on. The camera can also result in your control over Noodle being rendered more awkward and erratic as he goes where you don't want him to go, which is quite bad in a game as previously stated rewards methodical movement.

As for the levels themselves, they're broadly good. There's a variety of mandatory and optional obstacle courses mainly designed out of poles in different positions that manage to be quite distinct and fun to navigate in practice. Levels also need you to collect three different gems to use the exit. These gems are almost always found on different paths that you can tackle in any order, and they loop back on the main hub of each level which makes accessing the paths to other gems convenient and relatively speedy.

There are four worlds each with a different theme and four (three in the case of the final one) levels each. They each introduce new kinds of obstacles to contend with which keeps things fresh and focus on them just enough where you get a good interesting experience with em where they don't wear out... except for the third world but I'll get to that later.

I do feel like the four worlds do feel a bit samey though. While they do have different skyboxes, soundtracks, minor decorative differences, and lighting the building blocks of the levels and what Noodle will be slithering over will still be overgrown ancient Mesoamerican themed stone ruins covered in bamboo poles no matter what. It's not a deal breaker in any way but it would have been nice if there was more distinction in the visuals of the different worlds.

My biggest problem however, are with one particular kind of obstacle. Moving blocks and poles. They make the camera and movement controls [i] really [/i] act up. Furthermore, in a game whose basic controls and issues encourage slow patient movement moving platforms and poles suddenly demand that you make quick decisive actions and constantly move in a game that isn't built for that sort of thing. 

Failure no longer feels like the result of your own mistakes but instead the result of bullshit fucking you over in ways outside of your own control. Success no longer feels vindicating and rewarding by having you demonstrate to yourself you own improved proficiency at the game letting you successfully navigate its challenges but instead makes you sigh in relief as you lucked out and managed to get past something unfair.

The worst instance of the issues the game has is the third world, which is a fire themed one. Not only does the main obstacle here, hot coals, obscure your vision when you touch them but the color grading in said world makes stuff even harder to see due to how red and darkened everything looks. And then it has the highest amount of the aforementioned moving platforms and poles in the game, which combined with the vision issues makes things even more frustrating. Finally it makes you work with physics operated switches a lot of the time, which are clunky and slow to use. I had a hard time even figuring out if they were activated or not!

The game itself also just ends anti-climatically, which I believe is on purpose. It is kinda cute how it seemingly builds up to  something but then turns out to be a trick, but it still feels like a lack of needed resolution.

In summary, this game is at its best when it rewards careful thought-out movement that its mechanics naturally encourage, and at its worst when it forces you to waste your time and demands that you start doing the sort of thing that causes you to fail over and over, which is start rushing.

121822794.review:
I really like this game. It's fun, but it's also broken and diabolical.

In Snake Pass you play as a chain attached to a lead weight. You steer the lead weight left, right, back and forth and can lift it up a certain distance, however once you let go of the 'lift head' button it drops like an anchor and if you're careless while climbing the momentum will drag you to an unfortunate death while as you scream in terror. The front half of your snake can grip onto horizontal and (to a point) vertical surfaces such as walls and monkey bars, but appears to have a disproportionate amount of trouble with any degree of inclined surface, which cause him to slow down or slip off in a direction you might not expect. There is a 'grip' button that is supposed to help you not slip off things. It doesn't really help with that most of the time to the point that I'm not sure what it actually does mechanically, but there are a couple of situations where holding or tapping it helped with... something or other. The back half of your snake has no particular ability to move or grip on its own, however it will stabilise you on certain surfaces (in a way that is hard to describe) and is essentially a helpful platform that follows the front half when it isn't actively trying to kill you.

Speaking of platforms, the game is a platformer, which traditionally means that you play as a biped who advances the game by jumping between said platforms. However, in this game you play as a snake, who cannot jump by traditional means due to the unforunate circumstance of not having any legs. On top of this Noodle is a disgusting vegetarian who is incapable of striking like a regular snake meaning he is also incapable of jumping by nontraditional means. Instead he has to cross between platforms by stretching his body and slithering over and around monkey bars or by swimming in that deadly substance known as DiHydrogen Monoxide, which tragically claims the lives of millions of platforming bipeds every year. Fortunately, Noodle is immune to the stuff.
Sometimes between the platforms there is ground, so if you fall down have to try over. At other times there is fire, spikes or nothing between the platforms, in which case if you fall down you have to try over. Sometimes the platforms move and/or rotate with their attached collection of monkey bars, in which case you have to carefully time crossing between so that you don't fall down and have to try over. Also later on there are gusts of wind which either mildly inconvenience you or bug out Noodle's physics.
By the way most of the time on the fire puzzles Noodle's tail just barely hangs into the fire so he screams in agony the entire time. Fun fact.

The way you solve most puzzles doesn't really change much in concept (you wrap around shit and try not to go too slow/fast), but that isn't so bad because zooming around as a snake doesn't seem to get old. If you swish Noodle's head from side to side while moving like a real snake (i.e. slithering) you will pick up speed and momentum. The problem is that you will get stuck on objects on the ground, real or imaginary, and inclined slopes will kill your momentum entirely, so a lot of the time you are not zoomin at all. If you brush past grass or a pipe or rock then Noodle will often drop down to a snail's pace until his whole body is past the obstacle. Some objects can make him stop entirely until you backtrack past them. However, those times when you actually are zoomin do kind of make it worth it.

I'm going to clumsy segue into difficulty now, which results almost entirely from the game's physics model being capricious and brutally unforgiving. On some puzzles you just slip off for no reason. Noodle is cued to scream in terror any time he falls off an object, and on certain puzzles for no visible reason he screams the entire time you're doing it. I think it's what happens whenever the monkey bars are at a 15 degree or more incline, which tend to yeet you into the abyss if you slow down for a couple seconds or fail to keep wrapping Noodle around the bars consecutively. I don't mean to imply that if you slow down you'll slide down the bar's incline. Instead, for some reason Noodle's coils unravel from the tail and then the weight and momentum of his falling back half rips his front half off the bars. For contrast, if you're climbing up the side of a flat wall and can hook Noodle's neck just barely over the top edge, you can wiggle him back and forth and he slowly pulls himself up. This works on totally horizontal monkey bars to a lesser degree - Noodle can do as many pullups as he wants as long as the bar isn't just barely on an incline, or if it isn't Tuesday.
On that line of thinking, your snake's passive ability to grip onto objects often doesn't work properly when any physics other than straight downward gravity are being applied. If a puzzle is moving you side to side or rotating, sometimes Noodle will unravel and get left behind or otherwise get shot off in a random direction and fall into the abyss. I recall one platform that moved quickly up and then to the side. It had a vertical monkey bar for you to grip onto, however Noodle would always unravel and then fall off before reaching the top, and the only way to avoid this was to do the snake equivalent of jogging on the spot. No other puzzle in the game did this to me as obviously, but it did vindicate the suspicion I had that certain puzzles just break the game somehow.
Just as an aside, you would think that the 'grip' button would be designed to help in this kind of situation, but it didn't work in this case or on any inclined bars and it also stops Noodle from moving forward while you press it in which case it becomes a handy and convenient 'slip off and die' button instead. Oh the irony.

I don't think the developers understood the difficulty of their own game. I went for 100%, and some of the most frustrating coins to collect were right at start of the game in puzzles that consisted of a few slightly inclined bars hanging just below the edge of a cliff, which as previously mentioned have a habit of flinging you to your death. This sort of design resulted in the game's difficulty curve looking more like a difficulty electrocardiogram. That said, maybe it would've been different if I hadn't gone for collectables, but I don't think there would've been much game left over if I had cut them out.
On the counterside to that, if you master slithering you can abuse that momentum to easily blast through, over or around a large number of the game's puzzles. In all honesty I found circumventing puzzles far more fun than challenging them as intended by the developers, and it began to feel a little bit like revenge after a while, too.

While I'm here I may as well comment on the game's checkpoint spam. That's not to say that there are a huge number of checkpoints IN the game, but rather if you don't enjoy frustration then you'll be visiting one after every couple of collectibles because dying takes them back off you. I appreciate that they had to put this mechanic into the game so that you can't grab coins by yolo flinging yourself into the abyss, but it did nevertheless waste a huge amount of time, and it doesn't help that Noodle isn't always allowed to go at max speed. The result was that my go-to strategy since level 1 has been to find a save point after doing any puzzle that took more than several moments to beat. For me this was like the platformer equivalent of being stuck on the road behind a grandma driving at half the speed limit.

On controller you may find yourself dying a lot when you take your thumb off the 'lift head' button to adjust the camera. They could have made his head stay put and made the 'dive' button lower your head instead but no. The camera sucks too. No seriously I do actually like playing this game though.

TL;DR satisfying movement mechanics except when they're not, and powerful frustration due to capricious physics.

A fun and short platforming game. The gameplay is pretty simple. Coil and twist your snake across the map and find all the collectibles. Like most platformers though, the swearing in anger at deaths and the elation of getting everything on the maps is what makes the game fun.

My only gripe is that I felt there was not enough difference in the worlds to truly make them feel all that different. Like if 80% of all the maps all have the same cookie cutter portions, then the repetitiveness starts to sink in. In fact, I could normally only play a map or two before I had to take a break to avoid burnout. There was enough game here though that made me want to finish it. 

Overall, I got 7 hours of decent platforming out of the game. If you enjoy these kinds of games, then I think this would be a good Steam sale purchase.

7.5/10.0

119714811.review:
I got this game on PS4 when it launched, I was so pumped for it. A 3D Platformer fun colorful graphics and great music is just what I like. Then I played a few levels and didn't like it, and didn't touch it again. I fought with the controls. I got it in a bundle on steam and figured I'd give it a try again. I'm glad I did, but this game is not without faults. It is not a 3D platformer in the same vein as Banjo, Crash, Spyro, or Croc, despite being a ( loose) platformer, and in 3D. I say loose platformer, not as a pun, but because you're not going to be running, or jumping. You will be slithering, coiling and falling. It's more a physics based platformer, and you can fight the controls a lot before getting them, if you get them. Once you get them, it's very satisfying to do some fun tricks and cheese through parts of the levels, you can do some pretty crazy level skip portions when you get good at them.


Pros: 
-Great Graphics, colorful vibrant levels
-Great mascot, Noodle is cute and reminds me of 90s platformers like Croc, Crash, Banjo and Spyro design wise
-Fun collectathon
-What music there is, is catchy
-level design is fantastic
-Once you get the controls, they are fun! I recommend easy controls, it's just less buttons to hold. (I used controller, but I played a level with KB/M despite not preferring it, and it controlled great as well.


Cons:
-No enemies. Like I said, the only thing you will fight is the controls.
-No Bosses either
-story is really non existent, and bad, even by kids game/platformer standards.
-Cutscenes , dialogue and animations are not skippable, which while they aren't plentiful or long, when you're replaying for achievements it gets old, and the end level cutscene gets annoying quick
-Needs more music variety. I think they're are maybe like 8 tracks in the game if that. At least from what I heard.
-More Levels, or collectables. Each world has 4 levels except the last which has 3. Only 4 worlds. The last level isn't like a big boss level either, a normal level. It's like they just straight up forgot the last level. You can likely get every achievement and 100% this game in ten hours or less if you try or are better at this sort of game.
-Camera, the camera in this game is bad. A pan out or top down view to check surrounding would be great, you'll die a few times too many due to not being able to see your character.



Overall, the pros outweigh the cons for me and I very much recommend this game. It's a fun game to cozy up to and just spend some time getting everything in,

118804142.review:
Ως φαν των δυσκολων platformers ειπα να ξανα πιασω ενα παιχνιδι με το οποιο ειχα ασχοληθει κανα μισαωρακι το 2018 με controller τοτε και κατι μου ειχε φανει υπερβολικα δυσκολο ακομα απο το πρωτο level. Πριν 4 μερες κατι με τραβηξε παλι για δυσκολο platformer και ημουν σε mood για platformer με αρκετο χρωμα και περιεργους μηχανισμους. Αυτη τη φορα δοκιμασα με πληκτρολογιο/ποντικι μιας και η αμεσοτητα δεν συγκρινεται με αυτη ενος χειριστηριου και μιας και παλιοτερα πλατινιασα το Crash Bandicoot 1 παλι με mouse/keyboard το οποιο το δινουν βαθμο δυσκολιας 8/10 για 100% achievements λεω δεν μπορει κατι εκανα λαθος τοτε το 2018 μιας και το Snake Pass το δινουν 7/10 δυσκολια.

Τελικα μετα το πρωτο βουτηγμα στα βαθια μιας και πηγα για 100% μετα τα πρωτα 2 level κατι ξυπνησε μεσα μου και καταφερα να μαθω να χειριζομαι το φιδι σχετικα ανετα ακομα και σε πολυ δυσκολια σημεια η εμπειρια του gameplay ανεβηκε κατακορυφα μιας και μπορει αρχικα να φαινεται πολυ tricky οταν ομως μαθεις τα physics και τους μηχανισμους το παιχνιδι γινεται μια απολαυση. Προφανως παλι παραμενει αρκετα δυσκολο για να μαζεψουμε ολα τα collectibles ομως οσο παιζουμε μαθαινουμε η εκμαθηση ειναι εκθετικη. Το ιδιο ομως και η δυσκολια που σε καθε επιπεδο ανεβαινει εκθετικα και ειδικα στα 3 τελευταια που μπαινει στην εξισωση ο αερας τα physics αποκτουν αλλη διασταση. 

Τις πρωτες 8 ωρες τελειωσα ολα τα levels 15 ειναι μαζι με το 100% των collectibles. Για τα υπολοιπα achievements χρειαστηκα ακομα 5 ωρες μιας και το πιο δυσκολο αυτο να περασουμε καθε level χωρις να χασουμε καθολου ειναι το πιο δυσκολο και θελει υπομονη γιατι μολις κανουμε ενα λαθος παμε παλι απο την αρχη ολη την πιστα. Σε σημεια μπορει να σπασουν τα νευρα σας δικαιολογημενα παντα οταν ομως το καταφερετε η ικανοποιηση ειναι μεγαλη μιας και το challenge του παιχνιδιου ειναι μεγαλο. 

Στα των γραφικων το παιχνιδι οπτικα ειναι πανεμορφο τρεχει αψογα και υποστηριζει ultrawide κανονικα. Το μικρο μπλε πουλι που βλεπουμε στο poster μας βοηθαει σε σημεια μας κραταει την ουρα κυριως το χρειαστηκα σε 1 achievement που πρεπει να περασεις ενα level χωρις να ακουμπησεις καθολου στο νερο και χωρις αυτο δεν γινεται οπως και στα 3 τελευταια levels που μας πιανει για να μας περασει απεναντι με τη βοηθεια του αερα. 

Συνολικα ενα πολυ αρτιο και polished παιχνιδι διαβασα αρκετες αποψεις οτι ειναι παρα πολυ δυσκολο και αδικο και για αυτο το παρατησαν αλλα προσωπικα το βρηκα απολυτα δικαιο εφοσον δεν κανουμε καποιο λαθος εμεις αν και δυσκολο ειναι σιγουρα οταν πηγαινουμε για 100% τα παντα. Οσοι ειστε fan των platformers αξιζει να το παιξετε ειναι απο τα καλυτερα simulator παιχνιδια που εχω παιξει αν και δυσκολο οποτε ισως οι πιο νεοι gamers να το παρατησουν αν δεν ειναι μαθημενοι σε τετοιο challenge. 8.5/10

118067475.review:
If you've ever wondered what it's like to be a snake, Snake Pass delivers.  With true-to-life slithering and swimming, and even life-like breathing, this novel and beautifully rendered game delivers an immersive snaking experience.  The rich tropical world and upbeat music create an engaging work of art through which to weave and coil.  A great deal of time and energy went into this product, and it shows.  The snaking mechanics are novel and brilliant.
Because the game is so close to perfection, I can't help but point out one issue that may create friction with the target audience.  When coiling, there is necessarily a point where up becomes down, or vice versa.  On stopping the coil, at times this immediately reverses the direction in which you were snaking.  It can cost you all progress instantly on a given structure.  There is a steep learning curve with this mechanic, and it is not intuitive to everyone, including the armchair or casual puzzle gamer to whom this design should innately appeal.  From my perspective, the natural solution is a strong grip mechanic to anchor when changing positions or directions.  In real life, arboreal snakes grip with the ends of their tails to avoid the fate of Noodle who, true to his name, often plummets from his perch due to his flaccid tail.  The grip function just seems to slow his roll a bit, and it will not offset loose coils that can cost him progress if he misdirects.  Instead, having the back quarter of his tail hold his position would help the player "get a grip" while using the innovative controls.  The combination of the novel rotational motion and a weak grip mechanic create a constant threat of falling in a game which should otherwise be a relaxed and pleasant challenge.  This degree of stress during the learning process will turn some puzzle gamers off.  However, I am pressing on and attempting to master the mechanics, because it is just such a darned good game.  Hats off to these developers!

113614195.review:
Snake Pass is a charming puzzle/platforming collectathon with a unique control scheme, which tasks the player to move a goofy snake through a vibrant 3D environment. I've never played a game quiet like it, and I absolutely love it. Can you find the all powerful Keystones and restore magic to the land?  

The Pixar-esk cartoon world of Snake Pass is well rendered, with saturated colors, and a focus on a South American rainforest aesthetic. Stone ruins, wooden structures, bodies of water, and interactive mechanisms beak up the large swatches of green which dominate the game. The ever expressive orange snake (smartly named Noodle) pops against the backdrop, and is animated with an impressive amount of detail and personality. Noodle is a delightful dude. The ability to change the their expression on the fly is hilarious, and I found myself doing it constantly. Later level include lava, and water worlds to keep things from getting stale.

The music comes from legendary composer, David Wise, who's best known for his work on the Donkey Kong County series. The atmosphere is upbeat, and some of the tracks are down right funky. It's a perfect match, as his talents are put to good use here. The King of Jungle Music Strikes Again. 

While the collectathon isn't a new concept, Snake Pass feels fresh due to the fact you're not jumping and climbing like a standard platformer. YOU'RE A SNAKE! This means you MOVE THROUGH THE WORLD LIKE A SNAKE. Stretching, slithering, wrapping, clinging, and swinging is the name of the game. The physics driven animations and interactivity is tied to the joysticks, along with several simple button presses. Tying yourself to branches and wrapping around objects becomes second nature, as you try to collect everything you can. The puzzles themselves offer a fair challenge, and the execution of the solutions becomes gradually harder as you travel with a humming bird ally, who can grab your tail, which is remarkably useful for anchoring, stretching and gliding.

Anyone who is considering this one should just get it. You'll love Noodle, as well as the gameplay of Snake Pass. It's a cute, fresh game that will stands out in your platforming library. I hope they do a sequel someday.

109021825.review:
Excellent core gameplay loop ruined by supporting systems.

The main gimmick of controlling the snake's body is very well implemented, with controls, while not without problems, being pretty fun to figure out and get a handle of. Shame it is surrounded by a myriad of frustration ticks.

Camera behavior and checkpoint saving are the worst offenders here by far. To start, while camera can be rotated freely, the input scheme (no remapping for "recommended" controller, of course) frequently requires to hold some of the face buttons, thus locking the right thumb out from handling the stick. But even if one manages to adapt, there's no camera clipping through scene objects, so any collision (whether it's a stone wall or a two-pixel pebble) will likely span and zoom in/out the view unpredictably. And with all levels placed over bottomless pit, sooner or later this will lead to snake's death, which is the perfect time for the player to discover that collectibles aren't being saved between checkpoints — a questionable decision by itself, a bad one with such high undeserved fail rate, and a boneheaded one for a collectathon with an emphasis on unconventional controls.

Basically all other aspects just add to irritation after that. UI elements constantly get in the view, as does the bird companion. Bird that also pesters the player with mandatory tutorial messages during the first levels. Tutorial messages that also can come as unskippable cutscenes. Actually, cutscenes are unskippable just period, all of them: from the area ending dialogue to bird's victory dance three times a level. And so on, and so on...

No amount of interesting mechanics or cutesy aesthetic gets away untainted. Most unfortunate, really wanted to get into this one.

107023191.review:
Firstly before I actually get into my review itself, I just want to say I am unsure who the target demographic for this game is supposed to be for. The game on first look seems like it is directed towards kids, what with the trivia that the snake is apparently vegetarian, but the gameplay itself can be a frustrating ordeal that I cannot see myself as a kid wanting to play, and seems to be meant for hardcore platformers. Maybe they are aiming for kids REALLY into platformer games?

I will first get into what this game did good. The environment is colorful and pleasant to look at. The music is also great, unsurprisingly due to the fact it was composed by David Wise. The characters themselves are adorable and this is one of the cutest snakes I have seen in any media (the snake is even named 'Noodle'). It is also one of the most innovative 3-D platformer I have seen, being that you are a snake having to traverse the levels like how a snake would and was refreshing to play, for at least the first few levels.

However, the flaws and what the game lacks becomes more apparent the further you get into the game. Yes, the gameplay is innovative, but so is the idea of utilizing 3 other GBA in tandem with a Gamecube for a 4 player coop for FFCC. Innovative gameplay doesn't necessarily translate to good gameplay. For one thing, this game is a physics-based game, and I often find that I have to utilize lots of precision to ensure that the snake won't simply slide off platforms, fail to grip on scaffold, or whiplash in a direction that I did not meant to go. I also wished that everything the snake could do is introduced in the first level instead of spaced out to later levels. One of the biggest problems, which is also another innovative idea this game has, is to have the snake slither left and right to pick up speed. While novel and fun to experiment with, it becomes a chore and in some cases, more frustrating than needed due to the fact that many puzzle elements requires a certain momentum that you simply cannot gather from lack of space to slither.

The music while nice to listen to, becomes repetitive over time because there are 15 levels spread over 4 different sections, and each section only has ONE type of music playing, which gives the game a grand total of 6 different OSTs: 1 in the title screen, 1 in stage select, and 4 for the actual levels.

While the game did introduce some form of a plot and antagonistic force, there seems to be a missed moment which has been mentioned by other players as well, as the producers could have introduced some boss level at the end of each area. Considering the snake character can activate switches, this could easily have translated into traversing the environment to activate switches and defeat the boss. But instead, its just 15 levels, with different elements for 4 areas.

And yet this game is already considered a vast improvement over the first teaser trailer on youtube. No really, if the game was released looking like this https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G4SEbhaGYLI I would have given this game a 2/10 for innovation alone.

Overall this game feels meh for me, as I feel like it is more deserving of a score of 7/10 at BEST.

106458226.review:
I love thissSSSssSs game!!

I don't normally leave a very long and serious review, but this time I feel like I'm obligated to. I first downloaded this game a few years ago, pirated. I was younger and didn't have a bank account yet, and my parents hated spending money on games. I completed the game and moved on. Every once in a while I'd miss the movement in this game, and so I'd occasionally just open it to do a level or two - until Windows started detecting the pirated version I downloaded as a virus, so I had to uninstall it.
This year, I started working, and have my own money and bank account. Of course I wanted to come back and buy this game for real - because I love playing it, and because I want to support the developers for creating such a unique and fun experience. I got all achievements too.

The story... Honestly it feels like they just forced a story into the game after finishing it, so it has no actual effect on the levels as you play them, which isn't right. [spoiler]I wish we could be more involved with the crow guy, maybe have some sort of boss fight at one point.[/spoiler] But no one cares about the story. Let's talk gameplay.
If you're gonna play it, try to collect all the orbs and coins you see. There's a lot of interesting challenges this game has to offer, but only if you go for all the collectibles. They're hard at first, because they're often a challenge of how good you are at controlling the snake, but that's how you get used to the movement. Once you do - it's smooth as butter. I literally played this game on controller years ago, and now I don't have a controller so I had to use kbm, didn't matter because I already got used to the snake movement, it's like riding a bike. Unlike other games like Rocket League, where the switch between kbm and controller is a lot more significant, in this game you just need to learn how to wrap and coil yourself around to move between obstacles. The movement is so fun and unique once you get used to it you might find yourself addicted to it like I was.
I know we're probably not gonna get an update or DLC at this point, several years after the game's release, but I do wish this game had more levels. I feel like 15 just isn't quite satisfying enough... And although all of these levels are very well crafted and decorated, and they all offer new challenges and mechanics... I just wish the game had some more content. More costumes too, like, what's the point of the 8bit costume if you're only gonna unlock it after beating the game??
I feel like the game is just a few interactions short of perfect. It could've had some more meat to it, if for example, you had parts where gravity shifts for an entire section, or parts where something is chasing after you, or if you had to complete a certain character's request to earn a keystone. Stuff like that. If this game ever gets a sequel, I hope these things make it in... There's so much more you could do with a movement based game like this.
Overall, I highly recommend Snake Pass. It's a fun, unique, and refreshing approach to a 3D platformer, that you just don't see anywhere else. It might be missing a bit of content, but it's worth the purchase, for the experience.

104948332.review:
I endured through the game just so that I could say I got all of the collectibles and achievements, then swore to never touch it again. My main complaint is that the player only seems to control the first third of Noodle the snake’s body, with the remaining two-thirds subject to the whims of the physics engine. Clinging to objects does not work with any degree of reliability (even worse on moving objects), so moving slowly and methodically as the game would lead you to do is a death sentence.

In a majority of situations, I found it’s simply better to run a “Hail Mary” and crawl straight across objects at full speed, hoping that enough of Noodle’s body catches on solid geometry for long enough to keep him from slipping off into the abyss. When hunting for collectibles, sometimes it’s better to try to get Noodle’s tail to hang down and brush the item to collect it, so that you can then quickly pull yourself back up by his upper body.

Finally, despite being released in early 2017, the game chugged even on the lowest graphical settings on my modest 2016 laptop. I can’t help but wonder if the dropped frames contributed to the sense of the game controls ignoring my inputs, but the damage has long since been done and it’s a mystery I have no interest in solving.

96844833.review:
A pretty fun puzzle platformer. Can't complain too much as it was given away for free.

I haven't played 3D platformers since Super Mario Sunshine, but this one's unique mechanics made me interested. The snake handles fine, after a few minutes it becomes second nature. There is no reason to ever use the "grip" button though, it doesn't seem to do anything.

The game is short and sweet. I 100%'d it in 10 hours. This is probably a positive, as the game doesn't outstay its welcome.

However I do have some complaints:
- Unskippable cutscenes. Even mid-level while replaying a level. Unacceptable.
- The camera sometimes spazzes out. There are also some forced perspective segments that mess with the controls.
- The controls are camera-dependent. In a game where you must rotate the camera around a lot this becomes infuriating as left is suddenly right. Also as your head can turn nearly 360 degrees it means you must point the stick one direction, then another, to do a full 180 turn. It just feels weird.
- The wind mechanics introduced in the last world simply aren't fun to play around.

Other than that it's a good game. Worth it even if you have to pay a few bucks. The story is non-existent, just turn down the volume and listen to a podcast or something.

After World 1 there is an immense difficulty spike, at least for me. By the end of the game I was just playing to finish it it and the last world was just straight up not enjoyable for me. Throughout the world there are now new gameplay mechanics. The whole time you just slither around increasingly difficult areas with little changed. I mean in World 2 they add Water that you can swim through and in World 4 there are giant gaps that ypu can push a button to fly over, but those aren't really big changes...

In the end, I loved it. I could really see the snake come alive on my screen quite often, moving exactly as I would expect a snake to move irl - trippy, especially since I am the one controlling it. Besides the camera being weird sometimes(like suddenly rotating full 180 degrees and killing me in the process) and random moments where the snake seemed to suddenly change the way it moves/grips(which again, usually got me killed), in the whole game I only have 3 gripes:
1. For some reason, devs decided to introduce certain controls in not the first level, and the first tutorial shows only A and D, instead of full WASD(which you could argue should be apparent, but at that point you have no clue how it's supposed to work), I found the controls extremely unintuitive and pretty much random for quite a chunk of the game until I had to learn the controls by myself by accidentally hitting W at some point to realize how the snake works, by which point I already cleared up multiple levels, getting into very hard places with only half the controls...
2. After 4 years of people online talking about no-deaths achievement being inconsistent, there is still no indication of which levels have registered and which haven't. Cleared every level for every achievement right away, still had to play through half the game again to get it, no clue if it was me or the game that missed it tbh.
3. Last level has some misplaced death triggers by the green keystone:
-If you get on top of the circular structure, you die because of the level above. Technically, there's nothing there, so it doesn't really matter, however what really matters is that...
-You randomly die while going onto the sticks near the keystone itself, where you can't not go. It's especially annoying when you are going for a no-deaths run and die for no reason in the middle of a hard level.
[b]Certainly, worth a buy![/b]

95295201.review:
Nice idea, with a poor execution

First the pros:

Great concept! The snake game is classic and bringing it to 3D surely would work.
And... Collectables!!! there's nothing better to explore the mechanics of a game than adding collectibles. It makes us explore the levels and use all the skills we learned while playing the game. It's all more interesting here that our movement it totally different from what we're used to.

However, it stops here. The rest of the game is a mess.

First of all, the controls. They are... bad. They are relative to the camera, not to the position of the snake, and there is no option to change that. Considering that you constantly need to adjust the camera in order to get some of the harder collectables, you often find yourself going on a different direction that you need to. And it may kill you sometimes.

Talking about deaths, while it's a common thing in platformers, here it's TOO PUNISHING. Falling in a pit and respawning feels slow enough, and we can't tell how saving works until we're screwed by the checkpoint system. Yes, there are some checkpoints (something in the ground that lights up when you pass on it) and it saves your progress. So, if you spend 10 minutes collecting a hard coin, continue the stage and die a lot further without passing a checkpoint... well, too bad, do it again. And they're also annoying to find, so you spend a lot of time also looking for the checkpoints.

Lastly, the cutscenes. If you want to complete the game, you'll probable play through the stages multiple times, and YOU WILL HAVE TO WATCH EVERY CUTSCENE EVERY TIME. Yes, they're unskippable and the devs said that it's kinda intended due to poor programming. So yeah... that says a lot.

Overall, if you just want to play it once and call it quits, I guess that it's an ok game.

If you want to play for the full experience... don't.

This game has good ideas and interesting puzzles/mechanics; it has a colorful and refreshing atmosphere, which makes the levels enjoyable to look at. Collectibles are hidden "just right", in the sense that they're not obvious to find but it's still possible to 100% every level on your first playthrough if you're attentive enough (after completing the game, you get some help in finding the leftovers if you have any).

However, this is all wrecked by the fact you spend the entirety of the game fighting with the controls, the camera, the physics, or all 3. And it's compounded by the fact that since some collectibles are hard to reach, you will restart a step over and over and over again because one or more of the aforementioned factors decided to fail you. This all makes the game much, much more frustrating than it is enjoyable.
I went to the end of it purely due to my weakness to the sunken cost fallacy, and it was a real self-inflicted pain.

About half an hour after starting I was ready to put Snake Pass down. I found the movement controls bizarre and the camera management infuriating. It wasn't that I had no idea what the game would be like before playing, but that it seemed like I was never going to gel with their implementation.

Of course then I switched to a controller and the whole game felt a lot better. So this is my warning, really; I think the keyboard and mouse controls are awful. That I'm sure some people can get it to work effortlessly for them I can entirely believe, but it felt far more natural to control movement with a stick than it did a couple of buttons. All this is really about what the point of the game is; you control a snake and snakes do not move like we do. Obvious, yes, but atypical for a game to convey and in taking a blatant observation Snake Pass really tries to nail what moving about as a snake would be like.

In this regard Snake Pass can feel a lot like a long-form proof of concept. There is no gating of abilities, apart from specific instances logically infused towards the end of the game, merely how you apply them to the 15 stages. Split between being a platformer and a puzzle game, you'll spend your time navigating enclosed levels with a variety of collectibles scattered around. Of these some are required to complete a stage, the majority to help guide you around and a few designed to test your skills and exploratory habits. Outside of the necessary items, hunting the rest down is entirely up to you. Though checkpoints around the level are frequent, some of these items are devilishly placed to the extent that it becomes very familiar to see Noodle, the titular snake, falling to his death.

The part of the game that is just about moving around in an intricately designed space is rather pleasant. The movement is unique, but in full flow feels about as good as any traditional platformer. Between the vibrant, vivid landscapes filled with critters that are lovingly animated and a simple, but fitting soundtrack, I find the game world presents a very inviting space. Even stages filled with hazards can be stunning in their own way. It's certainly not going to strain your graphics card, but for a small scale title I do find it easy on the eyes.

The presentation does betray just how challenging the game can get though. Levels can be completed in minutes, especially if replaying them in the time trial mode or even leisurely, but it is equally possible to find specific collectible items requiring a considerable amount of time; one of the final levels had an item that took around 40 minutes to get alone. At some point it's hard to tell if it's the game that's specifically hard in the moment or if the frustration is causing you to play worse. Normally this is fine. These challenges are optional and whilst they call to you, sparkling in the distance asking you how you're supposed to not just get them but safely return to a checkpoint, you can ignore them. That said, there are moments in certain stages, especially towards the end, where a required route seems abruptly difficult.

So whilst traversal can be fun, the pressure applied can pile on quickly. Even with the controls down, I was still finding myself struggling with the camera and infrequently with Noodle. The direction you move in is based on where Noodle's head is. That you have a clear point of interaction here makes sense, but it means you're reliant on this head to clearly indicate what will happen if you move. Between the camera sometimes being outright antagonistic and Noodle taking a more estimated interpretation of your commands, too many times I felt like I had done nothing wrong and the game failed me.

For a challenging game this is a pretty cardinal sin. Were it not for the fact that this rarely happens on required routes, it's quite likely I'd have put the game down far before clearing it. Between the game's charm and foolish bravado, it's very easy to keep plugging away until you get it right. That the game is relatively short and a visual treat goes a considerable way though to mitigating the frustrations I have.

All in all Snake Pass is a game very committed to its design and purpose, sometimes annoyingly so. Like most fair challenges though, overcoming its obstacles, discovering nooks and crannies and mastering the movement to pull off actions that game doesn't point you towards but hints at with the terrain does produce a very satisfying feeling. If it's worth the challenge and frustration I'm not entirely sure, but I do think that it's too unique, too well polished to simply go ignored. It is a good game, but almost equally frustrating.

*Game obtained during a free giveaway on Steam*

93252125.review:
[h1]Here's what you do:[/h1]
You play as a snake by holding tight trigger and steering your head with the left stick. You can move the camera with the right stick and lift your head with the A button. The goal in each level is to collect the three key stones to open the gate to move on to the next level. This is done by wrapping yourself around poles and other objects to climb and traverse through a stage.
There is an "easy" control option to move entirely with the left stick, but I wouldn't recommend it as it means you can no longer move your head independently for trickier spots.

[h1]What I like:[/h1]
+ 15 levels split up into four worlds. 
+ The third world, the volcano area, stands out as the most visually different from the rest.
+ Levels contain multiple checkpoints which can be activated over and over again by returning to them. Beneficial just before attempting a difficult climb. Dying sends you back to the checkpoint with your progress reset to how it was when you last hit the checkpoint.
+ Optional easy collectable blue orbs and difficult collectable coins for extra challenge. Unlock snake sight after beating the game to help find missed collectables. When replaying levels, once an item is collected, the level can be quit with the collectable retained.
+ Time trial mode and arcade mode to replay levels with different goals. 

[h1]What I don't like:[/h1]
- Three of the four worlds are simply grassy with blue skies. I would've liked to see more diverse environments.
- When holding down RT, your body and tail can move while your head doesn't. This isn't a bug, but a situation where your snake doesn't have the strength to pull forward, but the body moves anyway and can lead to losing your grip and falling (to your death).
- Cutscene dialog boxes are not voiced and advance automatically, meaning you can't stop to read them at your own pace if you don't read fast enough.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
This is a fun short game with a unique character controller setup. It is interesting to learn how to move in a different manner from most games. Some challenges may be a bit frustrating, but is overall enjoyable.

[h1]Here is a demonstration of the game:[/h1]
https://youtu.be/KVVkQW_Rl6Y

92687503.review:
Un collect-a-thon corto y simple pero muy fresco y orignial.

Snake Pass nos pone en la piel de una serpiente llamada Noodle que va acompañada de su amiga Doodle, un pájaro.



La historia es muy simple: Alguien ha cerrado los portales que forman el mundo y hay que volver a abrirlos recuperando 3 piezas de colores. Punto final.



El gameplay es confuso al principio pero mola:

Eres una serpiente y te arrastras. No hay saltos ni piruetas, solo tienes que aprender a moverte como si fueras una serpiente para llegar a lugares altos y traspasar obstáculos. Se hace un poco complicado al principio pero una vez le pillas el truco es bastante bueno.

He visto reseñas de que los controles son malos, pero yo jugando con teclado y ratón no he cambiado ninguna tecla. Todo me parece correcto. Creo que es más el manejo de la serpiente que es difícil de acostumbrarse pero luego resulta gratificante.

Yo recomendaría jugar por lo menos 1 hora para acostumbrarse. Sino no le des demasiadas vueltas y mejor dale al rembolso.



El objetivo es conseguir las tres piedras que abren el portal.

Luego hay 15 esferas azules y 5 monedas que son opcionales. No sirven para nada, solo te desbloquean una apariencia para la serpiente si las consigues todas, aunque acabarás yendo a por todas, más por el desafío que por la recompensa.

Completar el juego deben ser unas 8-9 horas, pero si vas al 100% (todas las esferas y monedas) puede durar hasta 12 horas como en mi caso. Si ya vas a por todos los logros, pues más, pero no se cuanto.






En resumen:

Juego corto y sencillo pero muy único. No se parece a ningún otro juego que yo haya jugado y eso que me gustan mucho los plataformas de conseguir coleccionables, así que me ha gustado jugar a algo diferente y divertido.

Obtenido gratuitamente en la Humble Store.


Gracias por su lectura.
