91812983.review:
[h1]Gripping, Coiling and quickly fixing a weak coil by [i]swiftly gripping a bamboo with the analog L2, and slithering right into place with the analog R2[/i][/h1]

So, funny story here: I bought the game on May 27th, 2020, but didn't play it cause I was in the middle of playing Saints Row 3, Just Cause 2, L.A. Noire, etc, so I didn't reach the 2 hour refund limit even within 2 weeks. SO on June 11th 2020, when Humble gave away Snake Pass as a 'freebie', I was still eligible for a refund for Snake Pass, so I filed a ticket to Steam Support, and I assume I automatically got the refund. The very next day, I activated the steam key I got from Humble, and the game was back in my account ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. Fast forward 11 months, and I finally get around to playing it again.

[u][b]Cons:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*][u]Un-skippable low effort cutscenes[/u] smeared all throughout the game to add a [i]'story element'[/i] to the game. It introduces us to characters in the last levels of each of it's realms [spoiler]only to completely throw it out of the gate and end with a goofy "happy ending", nullifying all of the foreshadowing with the [i]'dark bird with evil eyes'[/i] sub-plot as well.[/spoiler]
    [*]The grass in this game reeks of default_unrealengine_grass4.obj, and it's the same aliased, pixelated and blurry textures everywhere. Most levels feel like they have been made using a level-editor, and are then filled in with trees, artifacts, bamboos and other environment-filling models, and apart from the 4 different realms, each level in the same realm look like it has copy-pasted the same map 4-5 times [i]while changing the level design, of course[/i]
    [*][u]The snake's head sometimes glitches into the wood visually[/u], so it's hard to determine which side of the rod/log the head is facing, so you don't know for sure whether to coil clockwise or anti-clockwise in the split second decision, hence sometimes trying to correct yourself may lead to the body winding out of the coil and falling off of the log. This isn't part of the cons, but: especially in the wind levels, where your muscle memory is so used to coiling in a certain direction, you need to start coiling in the direction not-opposite to the direction of the wind, otherwise your head may not be able to make it back to get another grasp of the log due to the strong wind resistance.
[/list]

[u][b]Pros:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*][u]Noodle and Doodle are adorable.[/u] They're a scaly and a furry respectively, what's not to love about that?
    [*][u]The soundtrack[/u] is [i]'catchy music composed by Donkey Kong Country maestro, David Wise'[/i]
    [*]The game is definitely best played with the [u]non-easy[/u] controls with an Dual-stick analog controller like the Dual Shock or Xbox controller. If you had to use a keyboard to realistically simulate what a controller does as an input for this game, you would need to have 3D QWOP configuration or something... (Continued below...)
[/list]

When I finally started to enjoy the game's movements (for example, blue text title), it was over... which was disappointing, but understandable. There wasn't much this tech demo/prototype could've done to make itself more like a full-fledged game, but I feel like they've made a substantial experience and is definitely worth the play whether you bought it or got it as a freebie, cause the pros outweigh the cons even if it doesn't look that way in my 'review'.

This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

89190954.review:
Snake Pass is one of those games that have such a good idea that you might be thinking "This has to be a slam dunk". No need for story or character or any of that, just make the mechanics work with some decent levels and it should be enjoyable. Obviously it's more complicated than that, game development is never easy, but Snake Pass nonetheless fails in delivering on the promise of its concept.

The problem is simple: slippery, physics-based mechanics combined with difficult and punishing levels. When controlling the titular snake, Noodle, it feels as though you only control the upper half of him, with the rest of his body being dead weight. On top of this, he feels less like a snake and more like an eel, since he lacks any kind of grip. As a result, you constantly slip off whatever you're trying to climb, and it's [i]infuriating[/i]. Add to that the moments where you have to jump between different climbing structures, with distances that are extremely difficult to judge, especially later on in the game.

Another problem with the mechanics is that they make you hold buttons way too much. I played with a keyboard and mouse, and you have to hold left click to move, space to hold your head up (to climb upwards), rightclick to get more grip (if it actually did anything) and you have to work WASD quite hard during climbing sections. As a result, my hands hurt after playing for anything more than an hour. 

And why, [i]why[/i], can't you look up in this game? The camera just locks at ground level, even when you stand by the ledge and there shouldn't be anything in the way. Just... [i]why[/i]?

All of this is aggravated by the level design. There are death pits everywhere, The game is actually built around them. If the levels would have required less trial and error, if it would have been based in a forest or something so that there would have been a ground level to fall onto, then I think that I would have enjoyed the game way more. Instead, at several parts of the game you end up watching the falling animation over, and over, and over, and over again. The checkpoints are numerous, and somehow still ends up feeling too few for a collectathon where collecting things is a massive pain.

Now, I don't mind frustration. I have nothing against difficult games, and I've played several platformers in the past that made me quite mad. But a core feature of difficult games is the ability to make failing fun, or at least let you feel a sense of your own skill progression as you grind it out. Snake Pass instead makes you feel lucky. Not that you can't be good at the game, I ended up figuring out different strategies for problems like I usually do. But it just [i]feels[/i] luck-based. For example, I could fail at getting a collectible several times only to suddenly get a break where the physics of your tail happened to fall through it (which counts as collecting it). I would say that I felt cheated, but honestly I was relieved every time it happened, which is never a good sign.

I admit, I might just be bad at this game. Maybe it's better with a controller as well. The problem might just be mine. But on the other hand, as I write this, only 4,3% of players have actually finished Snake Pass, me among them. I started getting golden achievements for simple progress after only an hour or two. That has to be indicative of something, right? So, as a result, I simply can't recommend the game. Hopefully someone will take the snake-climbing idea and make a better game out of it.

88818269.review:
Spent last night with this and I found it extremely charming and fun. Genuinely made this old fart smile and it reminded me of playing old Rare games a hell of a lot. Sure, there is an initial hour of learning the controls and a distinct lack of helpful tutorials, but once you nail the controls, the whole method you see obstacles changes. You really do 'think like a snake'. I'm on the second world and have collected all the items in every stage along the way, which is where the game really shows its skillset. I recommend others to try the same. You miss some really cool 'platforming' if not.

The checkpointing system is a pain and I've lost collectables multiple times from falling before hitting a checkpoint once again, but I don't see any other way they could have done it. Simply saving progress once a collectable is picked up would mean there is no challenge as you could leap to collect them and die but still be successful. I would recommend it, especially to those willing to see past the checkpoint frustration.

88377617.review:
If you're a fan of collectathons and are prepared for a bit of a challenge, Snake Pass will scratch that itch. 
The unique controls are of course the main gimmick, but with some practice, they can actually get fairly intuitive. The first time I started playing this game, I did encounter some serious frustration, but once I came back for another attempt (and with a better level of patience), I was able to get the hang of it. By the time I was nearing completion, I was able to get around well enough that it was actually pretty satisfying just to move around, wrapping around bamboo scaffolding with ease.

For completionists, the biggest challenge is beating every level without dying (not all at once). But if you can get through the last level, [spoiler] level 15, [/spoiler] it's pretty much smooth sailing from there. Took me quite a few attempts, but when I did clear it, I only had maybe 2 or 3 other deaths finishing the other levels.

86565348.review:
[h1] Huge Brain Mechanics [/h1]
This game, has been more of a test of my problem solving skills than any other puzzle platformer/collect-a-thon thus far.  Usually, I get the crutch of playing some sort of humanoid or anthropomorphic creature and know how to do basic movements, because (and until proven guilty in the court of Area 51) I am most definitely a human and not a Cetacea from the planet Va-de 835, waiting for humans to commit nuclear fallout to evolve themselves, before I and my species help move them peacefully into the heightened system of space communism. That would be ridiculous and I'd accuse you of being a conspiracy theorist. HA. Anyway, learning how to devolve myself back into a creature without arms, legs, or namely thumbs, was quite the challenge. It's been a long time... I mean for us as humans to have evolved, millennia ago.

[h1] Where Was I? [/h1]
The climbing mechanics could use some work, I'll be honest, feels like you're more slippery than you should be, and the grip mechanic I feel should have been used to help climbing as a mechanic in total. Instead it acts as a barely passable system to hold yourself in place. Snakes are sleek, but they are not slippery, and although you can climb pretty well, it breaks the immersion when (in the first few stages) it seems like a great interpretation of how snakes are so fascinating on their movement; Just to later be dropped off a cliff, because your tail is functionally not there, and you can slide right off a pole to your death. How do they make up for it? Your "Kazooie," for all intents and purposes, can lift your tail up, which helps with speed, and can act as a counterbalance. Something in retrospect should be unnecessary, but the developers really wanted to nail in the Banjo Kazooie homage. 

[h1] Did you mention Homero Rómulo Cristalli Frasnelli? [/h1]
There are few places where this game can improve outside of a tighter climbing mechanic. The movement system relies on you having some idea of how snakes move, then continuing to remember that, and apply it to increasingly difficult tasks. while in a game that experiences genuinely good game design. The music is fun, and in fact there are neat hidden objects that use water or wind, to create the music you hear in the levels, quite a nice immersive touch. The game could have been longer, or based on the story itself, it would have made sense to have a hub world. which I can imagine would have been fun. And lastly if there was a level designer, that would have been fun as fuck. 

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
From one very human, to my fellow human comrades; I, as a human recommend this game as a means to train yourself for when legs will no longer be necessary. 
Or available. 
Or as they say in my native forked tongue W̴̨̡̰͙̫̼͖̉́̀͝t̴̖̹͙̘͙̩͙͂̊̂̌̈́͝f̸̢̝̠̣̲̂̓̈́̃̏͠͝ ̴̘͉̥͍̝͇̙̬͂̿͆ȋ̵̡̛̭̬̾̈̌͂̎̄̈̍̏̋̀͝͠s̴̥̲̬̗͇̼̲͙̒͑̀̅́̆͌͑͘͠ ̸͔̝͈͔̦̌͌͌͛͑w̷̡̛͕̲͒̔̒̅̉̋̿̽̑̏̇̏̒ͅr̸̰̊̎̾̇͋ö̵̢͕̗͎̣̜̯̺͒́͗̋̈́ͅn̴̡̡̖̜̗̰̠͈̽̉̓̂͗̊ͅg̵̢̛͓̘̱̖̖̖͎̱͍̘̔̉́̉̄̍̐̂͌̐̚͝͝ ̸̟͈̃̀̋͛͒̂̋͌ẁ̸̳̍̒̏̏̌̇͜͠į̵̩̳͓͚̩͚̹̲̮̿͜͝t̷̮̻͓̪͍̭̏̄͋̑͒͋͛͊̊͘h̴̨̺̳̹̥̭̱͕̝̥̃̃͊̍̃̽͛͊̃̈́̈́ ̷̨̢̡̥͕̰̰̗͖̀͋͗̒͆̕͜͠m̵͎̯̳̬̙̺̳̣͕̗̬̏̿̀̽̂͝e̸̛̛͍͙̻̖̽̐̔̕͘͝͝͝͝

86309427.review:
This "jump-less platformer" is a very innovative game. It takes a bit of time to learn the controls, but once mastered it is very satisfying to make Noodle wrap around pipes and stretch to collect the blue orbs floating above spikes and cliffs. The scenery is colorful and the soundtrack is enjoyable.

The game feels a bit... unpolished, though. Most notably is the absence of saving in the middle of the game; this means you must complete the level before leaving the game, otherwise that very difficult coin that you got will have to be collected again. The camera positioning is often times unhelpful, and repositioning is difficult when all your fingers are busy making sure Noodle does not fall from the sky. Cutscenes are unskippable. And the lore/backstory is so simplistic the game could do without it.

It is definitely worth playing this game, but given the issues, it is best to wait for a sale.

About 12 hours (not including the Quetzalcoatl achievement)
Snake Pass was super fun. I love the gameplay, the story is fine (no boss battle, even if it looks like there could be). The camera was annoying at times (especially in small, enclosed spaces, and there are a few of those!). I had collected most coins and wisps by the time I got Snake Vision, but it's a cool feature. I wish the collectables still appeared in the levels when you replay them (maybe fading them would have been cool). The achievements were cool, some are definitely challenging, like No Diving, but Quetzalcoatl (completing each level without dying) is on a level of its own. The music was charming, occasionally, the game frozes for a few seconds, but no crashes or anything like that. I wish we could skip the cinematics, but they are not that long.

85825822.review:
Let me ask you a question before you buy this game...

Do you want to spend 20-40 minutes in a single level because of obstacles that are way too difficult and precise for the very inaccurate and slippery movement controls you're given?

If you answered no, then don't even bother with this game

The novelty of playing as a snake wears off VERY quickly and by stage 6 (Out of the 15) I found myself not even bothering to get collectibles anymore because they felt like they had no purpose and were mostly placed in spots that can make you lose a decent amount of progress with a single slip up and it's extremely difficult to not slide off of the pipes since the controls are so imprecise along with being very slow on a fairly big map just made the game feel like a slog, even the slithering mechanic to go faster still felt slow as all hell sometimes due to the size and complexity of the stages.

I get they probably wanted to make a unique and difficult "Platformer" but sometimes going the safe route (Aka the Mario route) of making stages that aren't super hard and instead just simple fun with bits of depth would have been better for this game due to it's honestly very cool concept but instead it just ends up being a trudge through the mud of wonky controls, overly punishing level design and a very slow overall pace that feels pretty shallow as well...

I really wanted to like this game as it brought back memories of playing the platformers of my childhood at first but when the frustration sets in, that nostalgia goes away and makes the game feel all the more bitter...

In conclusion; if the controls were tightened or the levels difficulty was toned down, then this would have been a great game but sadly it's just not polished enough to recommend it...

3.5/10

85346506.review:
[h1]INTRO[/h1]
This isn't the Nokia Snake, so I'm a bit confused here.

[h1]THE GOOD AND THE BAD[/h1]
+ The snake physics are amazing
+ Cute graphics
+ Works just fine with mouse and keyboard, takes a while but is a non-issue once you learn it
+ No evil enemies to fight against, it's just about the snake and the obstacles
+ Level design keeps getting better as you progress
+ Nothing overly complicated with some few exceptions
+ Relaxing soundtrack
+ Works on Windows 7 despite it not being listed

- Game doesn't detect some keys on various keyboard layouts unless you switch to the universal US layout (not needed for core gameplay though)
- The "grip" function of the snake is absolutely useless, it's just an extra button that doesn't help you at all
- The bird automatically stops holding you when you collect a keystone (there's a cutscene involving the bird), so make sure the snake can survive without it
- Camera can be weird in tight locations

[h1]NOTES[/h1]
The "No Diving" achievement is designed to extend your gameplay by three hours, to make you rage like crazy and to make you replay just one level for 1254 times until you get it right. This is where the bird can be frustrating, so make sure the snake isn't left hanging when it has to leave to collect the final keystone. This is a water level where the game requires you to actually avoid any contact with water. And the snake is really long, so its tail is almost sure to hit the water at some point if you're not careful, you need to wrap around things as many times as possible.

[h1]OVERALL[/h1]
This game is absolutely brilliant. It was going to be one of those free Humble Bundle games I will never play for a long time, but I'm so glad that I decided to try it. I'm pretty close to finishing it and I will, including every achievement the game offers (at some point). Snake Pass deserves it. Not to mention, this is the first game I am willing to play at 720p because my graphics card is from 2012. I don't make such compromises usually.

[h1]RATING[/h1]
9/10

The game is neatly done, and it has a unique twist on the platformer genre. I think the art style and the graphic quality of the game is super. The levels are well put together. There is not much story in the game but it was nicely built up.

I recommend this game, despite the fact that I don't think I'll be playing this ever again nor a possibly upcoming sequel. 

How so?

I've never got very good with the most unique part of the game, the controls. I played with a controller and my hands started to ache after 30 minutes of play or so? I was grabbing it so wildly. :-D I learnt some nice tricks by the end of the game, but I also built up too much frustration. I died. A lot. Somewhat after the half of the game I gave up on collecting everything, and I just went for finishing the game. Mostly.

I liked the game. It was fun to hunt for the hidden collectibles and for some of the challenging ones. But then it started to get too lethal for me. So I'm happy I finished the game and I'd say give it a shot, you might be better in getting in control. ;)

84866232.review:
Snake Pass it is an amazing (unironically) puzzle platformer snake simulator.
Both in term of controller controls and feeling of snake movement is superb.
Climbing is fluid and fun while level design, puzzles and platforming is perfect.
Well, almost perfect. 

The challenge and puzzles are perfectly balanced indeed but checkpoints could be placed a bit more often so you don't have to spend your time going back to the previous checkpoint every time you collect a thing to make sure you don't have to do it again.

Also I really wish the game did introduce new mechanics and more elaborate puzzles in later levels. Sadly lack new mechanics really limits variety of gameplay.

The best levels in my honest opinion are last 3 because those are actually gets a bit tough.
Everything before that feels way too much like a cake walk.

My main complaint would be the huge amount of blur effect disallowing you from looking around the map (gladly that can be turned off by setting post-processing on low) 
and how camera act when near wall by zooming in way too much or pushing itself that may ofen f*ck up your movement. 
Sadly there is no option to turn off "camera auto wall recovery" tho.

I hope to some day a proper sequel to this game - especially after watching final cutscene.
This gameplay idea have a huge potential.

This had potential to be a good game.  Had. That's the key word here.

But there are game breaking faults that easily make this the single most disappointing piece of shit of all time. The controls suck so much ass they breath shit instead of air. The idea is sound, but the camera rotates at fucking random, completely changing your critical movements as you attempt to move. The snake cannot grip and move, which is completely insane, seeing as how real snakes do both simultaneously (this is how they scale surfaces so easily in reality). Games with shitty controls aren't "challenging" or "fun" they're just shitty games. And that is what ultimately breaks this game to the point where you find yourself with the nearly inescapable desire to pin the developers to the ground and violently punch them in the throat until your knuckles break shattering their spines. It's truly that frustrating. What could've been a relaxing, fun game is instead an exercise in frustration and stupidity masquerading as a 'physics' game. These fuckers clearly know nothing about either biology or physics and need to pick new careers. With 'developers' like this roaming about, video games are doomed.

Do yourself a favor: Get a frontal lobe lobotomy and burn your house to the ground. Both would be better for you than wasting your money on this garbage as I did.

83670267.review:
I really wanted to be able to recommend this game.  But the controls are just so bad.  The concept is extremely cool and animations are smooth.  But the game suffers from terrible controls that make most bamboo climbs in later levels feel like way more luck than skill.  I know there's plenty of players that have tuned the controls to a science and can speed run this game.  For people like me that just want to play the game it becomes frustrating to watch the snakes head flail around wildly on one obstacle and then exactly place the snake on the next.  This wouldn't be bad except that some levels are impassible without some of the challenging climbs.  The developers should have simply reserved the more taxing climbs for coins.  Perhaps I missed too many early training opportunities so later levels feel more luck based.  I'm just not invested enough to put in the practice time to figure out the controls.

After logging more hours I stand by my previous comments.  The controls are just bad.  The camera relative control scheme with moving objects, needing to press 3 buttons on the right side of the controller at the same time, having the head up causing the snake to fall down...etc, etc.  The game actually far more playable on a keyboard and mouse.

Some of the blue wisps can take up to nearly 30 deaths to collect, but when you finally get good enough to collect them all (and the coins as well) it is very pleasing And I’m glad they added a little unlock at the end of that. My only complaints are that I feel like there should be at least 2 more check points in the last world levels and I also wish there was a little more to the end game other than arcade and time trial that could add little more replay ability.

9/10

82531997.review:
Snake Pass is a platforming game where you are Noodle, a snake, that must collect a maximum of colorful rocks to open up each level's gate to move on to the next level.  There are four worlds, earth, air, water, and fire.  In each world you will play four levels, except for the last world (air) has three.  Each level becomes more and more difficult.  You must snake your way up and across pipes by wrapping yourself around them and not falling off.

The physics of the game are actually pretty decent.  When in the air, your snake seems to fly a bit more than normal, but when slithering on the floor or from platform to platform, gravity, and your snakes balance feel pretty good and are not necessarily surprising in how you react to the world around you.

Through each level you can collect wisps, blue glowing balls, and coins.  Neither are needed to beat the game, other than to get an 8 bit version of Noodle, you, or Doodle, your bird friend that follows you everywhere.  Your bird friend can be helpful at times as he can hold your tail, which can help in balancing in certain occasions and in the air levels, he can help you jump over chasms, so much the good physics statement earlier.

This game is not too difficult, but it can be especially if you are looking to get all achievements and all collectibles.  The not dying on any level achievement was tough, especially that last level which really works your skills.

The snake looks great and mimics the movements and look of a real snake very well.  I was impressed by the game, even if it truly has a very simple mechanic.  Only a certain amount of your head will go up, because, well, a snake doesn't stand, but if you coil up, it can lift its head a bit higher.  The graphics are fun and fit well with the genre and the attempt at a storyline, but again pretty impressed with the animations and movement of Noodle.

If you can get this for less than $10 then you should get it.  It's unique, it's a challenge, it's beautiful, and I found it to be fun.

"We recommend using a controller to play Snake Pass"
Except the devs put a bunch of effort in turning your controller into a hitachi for 30% of the playtime
Your controller will vibrate HARD whenever you:
-Fall to the ground/abyss (doesn't really matter how small the distance)
-Bump into something (even at ground level and minimal velocity)
-Collect a collectible (double digits plus they reset if you die without touching a checkpoint)

In addition to that, your controller will ramp up the vibes until it reaches a 'critical' point that's supposed to give you a sense of pride, accomplishment and coolness whenever you respawn. The devs also didn't think about putting a brunch of white-bright VFX in often-recurring elements of the game (like when you respawn).

Any fun this game will offer you by starting a new level will get sucked out of you by the controller vibration. Then you'll get frustrated halfway through a level because you've got to finish it to actually progress instead of starting over again next time. Very tedious.

78901261.review:
Snake Pass is not a game, it's a spiritual journey.

At first glance, one could easily be lulled into thinking this will be a lighthearted collectathon, perhaps a nice throwback to the exploration platformers of an earlier era. Then you begin the first level. As you attempt to grab that one coin under the bridge, you realise that this game could only have been conceived by the Allied Mastercomputer. But, as AM will do, the suffering eases, and the experience becomes more akin to your initial perception of what Snake Pass would be. But the continuous, repetitive Exotica throwback that constitutes the soundtrack is an ever-present reminder of the cyclical nature of suffering and pain. As you work through the particularly difficult segments, those little protrusions in the levels which offer only an unending time-loop, where a minor mistake or momentary camera change can cost you everything, you begin to learn the values of patience and precision. Again and again, our poor Noodle plummets to the abyss below, and the rhythmic dance of LT, RT, and A begins to befuddle the fingers, the futility of life and it's unending trails bears heavy. But, to push through, to overcome and work inch-by-inch, taking the time to perfect each individual button press, eventually leads to that satisfying sound effect as we collect another seemingly inconsequential item. But this satisfaction is short-lived, and we once again find ourselves in turbohell, flailing violently as we plummet to the depths yet again and wonder just what kind of sadist would build a place like this. Just -who- would construct such a thing, look at it with great consideration, and say to themselves "this looks like a reasonable place to live". The Allied Mastercomputer.

Snake Pass is a game of small victories, where the larger goal often takes second-place to the smaller-scale challenges presented within. It's getting that last coin, or that final weird, amoeba blob thing that gives the dopamine, I'll tell ya dat right naow, eh bud.

76089353.review:
[h1] Suited For Kids And Adults [/h1]

Snake Pass is a unique 3D platformer because it features movement mechanics not seen anywhere else. It's a 3D snake which physics are simulated very realistic. Unlike other platformers the snake doesn't have one point of mass where gravity is tied to, but it has its whole body simulated where gravity drags on every part. This means you cannot just concentrate on the head which your are controlling, but have to look for what the rest of the body is doing behind as well. Otherwise it could be, that the mass of the tail will drag you down a pit, or if you lean too much forward you'll slip down, or your middle part may slip off the bamboo bar dragging you down although the head seemed safe in that spot on top of the bamboo bar. Luckily Noodle the snake has his companion Doodle the hummingbird which will lift up your tail on a button press. You cannot adapt the usual platformer experience, you have to learn this new movement and I like that very much!

It features the usual 3D platformer collectathon. Collect 3 gems to finish each level, collect 20 optional blue orbs scattered across each level, collect 5 optional golden coins in hidden or in difficult to reach places, touch the gatekeeper idol in each level to earn their blessing. And a few more optional achievements.

[b][u]So how well is this suited for kids?[/u][/b]

My daughter liked it very much! She regularly asked if we could play "that snake game" :)

[b][u]Content[/u][/b]
+ Positive is the peaceful nature of the game. A mysterous creature stole all the colorful shiny gems, dropped them across each level and you have to get them back, It's very colorful and the two friends Noodle and Doodle are cute, speak about harmless things and do not make stupid jokes only adults may understand, but speak kids-friendly.
+ Colorful world
+ There is no blood. 
o I can't say "no violence" but have to say "mild" violence, because Noodle can fall into spikes or get burned in fire and glowing hot fire rocks. This will make Noodle's face transmit that it feels pain. You can not really "die" here, but you vanish in a fading white and respawn at the last checkpoint. But Noodle still closes its eyes when falling into spikes. You can also fall off the edge of the level making Doodle's face transmit "Oh nooooo, please heeeeelp".

[b][u]Controller difficulties[/u][/b]
The default controller setting is right shoulder button (R2) to move forward, left joystick (L) for left/right and A for lifting the head. This may be difficult if the kid's fingers are not grown up enough to simultaneously reach A button with the thumb while the index finger rests on the shoulder button R2. My 4 year old daughter managed to do it, but it was hard. However, there is an option available to switch to "easy" controller setting. This will get rid of the shoulder button R2 and instead make the left stick also go forward. Then it's only L and A to be pressed with left thumb and right thumb. This is much better suited for kids. It's not only easier to reach the buttons but also easier to get into your head. There is much to be looked out for if you want to control the snake. Going for easy controls is easier to get into the game, using the default setting is better for precise movement.

[b][u]Level design[/u][/b]
At the start I found it very frustrating that you do not keep what you collected unless you touch a checkpoint. It makes sense, though, because some coins require you to not only reach them but also make it back to the safe green again. That's why you don't keep what you collected after "dying". I would have found it better if your progress would save everytime you are on "safe" ground. I played this with my daughter and kids are not the most patient ones. Losing 5 orbs and a coin making us redo the last 10 minutes only because we didn't know how checkpoints work was very frustrating.

Checkpoints are not explained anywhere, not their existence nor how they work. Be sure to know this: checkpoints are those triangle plates which light up a blue snake when you crawl over them. They can be activated as often as you want. Just crawl away from it, collect something and crawl over it again. There are several checkpoints in each level and only one of them can be active. The specific checkpoint active is signalized by the blue light the shape of a snake. 

Also: You can't quit a level without losing your progress. You can't quit the level and continue it another time. You always have to play through a level collecting all 3 gems to save your progress. This is not optimal for kids as their speed and time commitment is not fit for this adult like design. Just now we said we had to stop to do something else and had to quit the game. Unfortunately our progress is not saved. The game told us that the progress will be lost, but we cannot let it run until we have time again, so this is a negative point about the game for kids.

[b][u]Also For Adults?[/u][/b]
I played this with my daughter only for the first 8 levels. The harder later levels I played on my own. And ss you can see I got every achievement of this game! I must have liked it! (I really liked it!) It was very interesting to master the snake physics and each mechanic of crawling up and along the many paths. I liked the graphics and adored the blur effect on distant objects. Everything looks so beautiful! The challenges and overall difficulty are suited for adults. The story content is for kids, but still enjoyable as an adult.

74985680.review:
I am a little conflicted on Snake Pass, On one hand, it is a charming little adventure with the snake Noodle and his friend, traveling through some worlds, doing some snake-...ing (?) and collecting keystones to open portals to travel to the next area. The game looks great, thanks to the Unreal Engine, though the worlds themselves are very standard fare (Grass, Water, Fire, Air).

Its all well and good, but the physics and controls sometimes dont make any sense. I get how the controls work - you control Noodle and since you cant jump, you have to wind yourself along like a real snake, meaning to climb wooden rods, you have to snake yourself around them. In the first few worlds, the physics based gameplay is actually really fun and, if you master it, it shows a lot of promise and is something new and interesting.

Especially in the last two worlds, though, the physics-based movement becomes a little too much for the engine to handle. Noodle itself is really floaty, so you can often make jumps or drops that probably werent intended. Every single rod in the game feels like it is doused in oil and just very slippery. One button in the game is for "tightening" around rods, which only sometimes works, and sometimes it doesnt. Often it feels like you fell for no reason and it can get a little frustrating in the later levels.

Even so, the game is definitely interesting and something different when it comes to gameplay, so I will give it a cautious thumbs up. On sale I would recommend checking it out, but if you dont like the way it plays in the first two hours, it will definitely not get better later on.

74626992.review:
[h1]Overall = 5 / 10[/h1]

The graphics are bright and cartoony, the music is catchy and upbeat and the characters are likeable and funny, which makes the game look like it’s going to be a lot of fun.  However, it is more frustrating than fun to play due to the inconsistent control system which is tough to get the hang of.  When it works like it should it’s relatively satisfying, but when it doesn’t, its rage inducing.  Credit to the developers for committing to their unique concept and its execution, but making the snake hold onto objects longer, more checkpoints and slower moving objects would have made it more enjoyable.

It’s actually quite a short game with only 15 levels, although replaying them for collectibles and other challenges adds to the play length.  The setting and premise is ok, but the twee plot could have been better – it either shouldn’t have had one, or should have had more to it.  As it is, it gets in the way for no real reason.  

Recommended because it's something different, but if you can't get the hang of it, there's no fun here for you.

74235640.review:
Se trata de un juego de plataformas en tres dimensiones bastante particular. El personaje que vamos a tener que controlar esta vez es una serpiente y esto afecta a todo. Manejar a Noodle (la serpiente protagonista) es todo un reto y te va a llevar tiempo y muchos intentos dominarla.
La gracia del juego, es que las situaciones que presenta (plataformas, escenarios, obstáculos) tienen que ser resueltas pensando como una serpiente. Este factor se nota mucho y es de lo que más me gustó del juego. Hay muchas zonas en las que es necesario enroscarse, hacerse un nudo para poder aferrarse, serpentear, etcétera y todo esta implementado perfectamente.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2196051418
Para mí, este juego presenta muchos aspectos positivos. Tiene una banda sonora que enamora, unos escenarios y gráficos muy coloridos, bien logrados y preciosos, el control de la serpiente es muy bueno (algo que me preocupaba bastante antes de empezar a jugarlo, que tan incomodo podría llegar a ser controlar a Noodle). Pero con diferencia, lo que más me gustó fue su curva de aprendizaje. El juego te explica los controles básicos y con ello, las herramientas para afrontar las distintas situaciones que están por venir, pero no como afrontarlas. Es uno mismo el que va a tener que aprender a desplazarse, aprender a colgarse de los elementos, afrontar todo como una serpiente.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2195047555
En cuanto a la dificultad, el juego consta de 4 mundos, cada uno con cuatro niveles exceptuando el último que tiene solo tres. Cada nivel tiene tres tipos de coleccionables. Tres piedras que son obligatorias (no muy complicadas de obtener en la mayoría de los casos), 20 wisps (orbes azules que son opcionales, algunos estarán a la vista, otros ligeramente escondidos y otros serán difíciles de alcanzar) y finalmente, la verdadera estrella, las monedas. Hay un total de 5 monedas por nivel (que también son opcionales), y la mayoría son muy difíciles de recolectar, ya sea por que están escondidas o por que hay que atravesar un tramo del mapa cuya dificultad es un poco más elevada respecto a la ruta normal del nivel.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2195047399
Finalmente, aspectos negativos le encuentro muy pocos. La cámara algunas veces me jugó malas pasadas, el control abajo del agua no es que me haya encantado y lo más importante, no es un título para cualquiera. Hay que aprender a manejar al personaje, y durante toda la fase de aprendizaje, es muy importante la paciencia. Pasarse el juego normal tiene su cierto grado de dificultad, pero intentar sacar todos los coleccionables hace que esta se multiplique muchísimas veces.
En conclusión, es uno de los juegos de plataformas que más me gustó y se lo recomiendo a todo el mundo, aunque sea que lo prueben.

73897423.review:
Snake Pass is a fun little exercise in its own unique movement mechanics, and not much else. Don't get me wrong, it's great fun slithering around and exploring and finding collectibles—it scratches that completionist collect-athon itch very generously and with mechanics so fundamentally different than the usual platformers and exploration games—but it lacks a lot of polish that ends up leaving me irritated and unappreciative. There's the minor inconveniences, like the overindulgent animations. Cutscenes are unskippable. despite the fact that you can encounter them multiple times, and feature excruatingly slow dialogue and animations. Even respawning from a checkpoint or finishing a level overstays its welcome. Another inconvenience is that, alongside the challenging achievements and the completionist achievements, there are hidden achievements that just ask you to perform some movement mechanics far more times than you would in a normal playthrough of the game. It has a childish vibe to it that I don't know that I can explain.

But then there's the big thing that disquiets me: the cheese. Snake Pass is eminently cheesable. For a game about exploring level geometry with an unorthodox climbing mechanic, one would think there might be more careful curation of what geometry is climbable and what puzzles are skippable, but very rarely do the skips or climbs feel intentional. They are often "off-brand" for the gameplay (you climb a lot slower, or jam through a gap or up an environmental decoration) and have no collectibles or even dev acknowledgements of these places' accessibility (at best, they give high ground for janky-looking jumps to other parts of the level). There are only 15 levels, one of which is a tutorial, so it's discomforting that I felt like I played them more thoroughly than the devs did.

I won't lie, I experienced a fair share of fun and challenge playing this game. But I also got from it a lot of irritation, and, when I pause and reflect on it, a lot of heartache, a yearning for the game this should've been but wasn't. I don't regret playing Snake Pass, but I didn't miss it, either, when I accidentally took a month-long break from playing it. I might grind out the last achievement sometime, but other than that it's a game I think I am ready to shed.

73724148.review: Snake Pass is pretty fun. The controls are extremely unusual, but that's because they're doing their best to replicate what it would actually feel like to be a snake--and honestly, I think they do a good job of capturing that (although your ability to climb walls is a little too powerful to be realistic, but... that's okay). The game's aesthetics (visuals and music) are on point, and the story is... passable, I guess. The level design is really good--it makes good use of the fact that you are a snake, and, the collectibles are just as fun to collect as the rest of the game is to play. That being said, the collectibles are fairly useless--all they do is unlock some mildly amusing skins. The game is also pretty short, so that, plus the pointlessness of the collectibles, plus the boringness of the story, makes the game feel pretty lackluster despite its aesthetic polish. Plus, it can be kinda rage inducing until you get a good handle on the controls. I still think it's a fun game, but it's really lacking in certain areas, so at this point I'm just hoping they release a sequel that keeps the elements that work, and expands upon the ones that don't. 'Cuz ultimately what would've really made this game better is just... more content.

73665256.review:
(Disclaimer: Received free from Humble Bundle) 

The 3D platformer/collectathon is my favourite type of game. I always wanted to play Snake Pass when it released in 2017, but never got around to it. Thanks to the gift from Humble Bundle, I was able to complete it today to 86%. I might return to attempt the 100% completion - my original intention - but I'm currently reluctant given how frustrating some sections were. Anyhow - I have a few thoughts on my experience which I'll detail below.

I was initially impressed with the vivid environments, cute platforming duo, and of course, the chilled out soundtrack from can't-put-a-musical-foot-wrong-David Wise. All those elements harmonise extremely well in Snake Pass, and Sumo Digital should be proud of such success. The story, while very minimal, is a sweet 'G' rated narrative that's ideal for kids. As many an online commenter has stated, it's more than acceptable for platformers, like Mario, for instance, to serve players a gameplay-first, story-last journey, and still be compelling. Snake Pass certainly ticks the box there. There are also no enemies, so if you're after a game that doesn't promote violence, look no further. It's rare to find a pacifist 3D platformer. Where it all unravels (pardon the pun) however, is in general gameplay. 

The whole game is centred around being able to master Noodle's (the snake protagonist) movement. The tutorials on it are fairly brief, but it's common knowledge that snakes slither and coil around things, so perhaps there needn't be too much explanation anyhow. Still, mastering it, at least in my opinion, is no easy feat. It's rather easy to make a blunder because Noodle doesn't move in the angle you wanted, and the camera angles can be wildly uncooperative, which then leads to multiple deaths and much frustration. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the earth and water worlds, which were great playgrounds for learning to weave through intricate wooden fencing, exploring subaquatic caverns, and more. The fire world raised the difficulty by adding lava that can burn Noodle to a crisp, but still kept me motivated to keep collecting wisps, and occasionally, the harder to reach coins. I lost patience far too often in the wind world, which featured some really fiendish challenges in the final level (even to retrieve the keystones, the only mandatory collectible) that felt more like painful trial and error, instead of that hard-but-fun sweet spot. I was also occasionally confused, not at the lack of checkpoints - there were definitely enough - but their placement eg installing a checkpoint after a moderately hard section instead of after an extra hard section. 

After Yooka-Laylee (100% completed on PS4), I'm sort of traumatised by any 'roll the ball' tasks, so I wasn't too excited to see them pop up multiple times in Snake Pass as well. To be fair, they *were* much, much better designed, and more fair to the player. In fact, I would just like to commend the level design overall. Navigation was consistently clear and not once did I feel lost on where to go next. Sumo Digital deserves SO much praise for making it look so easy. 

I don't think Snake Pass really has any puzzles in it, to be honest. If anything, there's one level in the lava world which requires you to rotate large stone structures in such a way as to form a path, which can then be used to reach a keystone. Everything else felt like a classic 3D platformer adventure. The 'action' label wouldn't suffice here either. You need a great deal of patience, strategy, and precise movement to overcome the various gauntlets on show, and the feeling I kept getting was not unlike that of playing a hardcore stealth game (not action-stealth fusions like Dishonored), something which MUST be played slowly and cautiously to extract maximum value. Therefore, I think the most accurate way to refer to Snake Pass is a precision-platformer. There's much debate on the exact definition of '3D platformer', and, usually, not including a traditional 'jump' button would have disqualified Snake Pass from the classification. But the fact remains that Sumo Digital does indeed describe Snake Pass as a 'platformer', that it most closely resembles the 3D platformer more than any other genre, and, that Noodle can pseudo-jump by lifting his upper body half. Considering a snake's natural abilities, this seems like a most authentic representation of anguine kinetics.

Snake Pass is an enormously creative game that uses a unique gameplay mechanic which ensures the player will be continuously challenged. While there is a lot of enjoyment to be squeezed out, there is an equal, if not larger slice of the game that winds up becoming tedious due to repetition and near-misses. I would have loved it if Noodle's slithering was permanently sticky. Perhaps in Snake Pass 2, one can only hope. Still, I am grateful to have played Snake Pass, and to have brushed shoulders with an fresh movement system and amazingly designed levels. Thank you.

A good 3D platformer / collect-a-thon with pretty graphics and unique physics based movement. Having arms and legs is actually pretty sweet, now that I think about it.

I always loved 3d platformers and this is such a refreshing spin on the genre. Who would have guessed that not being able to jump was the way for the genre to advance?! Even at it's full price the game is worth it for sure, on sale it's a proper steal.

If you want the same controls as all the other platformers out there, ie play a game that hasn't really changed since Super Mario 64, get A Hat in Time. But this here is a fun and interesting challenge with a good sense of progression and a control scheme that will have you wiggling along in your seat.

There are a  few minor annoyances, the cutscenes not being skippable makes replaying some levels a little annoying. And the camera needs some active management by the player - not a deal breaker, but with your thumb being occupied by the face buttons, it can be hard to adjust the camera while climbing around.

72061338.review:
Snake pass es una mezcla de puzzles de física, colectatón y plataformeo.
—Duración: modo normal con 100% alrededor de 10 a 11 hrs. No he tocado ni el modo arcade ni el contrareloj.
—Historia: Virtualmente inexistente, una excusa para la diversión del gameplay
—Graficos: Bellisimos, un estilo caricaturesco pero que no pierde detalle, y con una buena dirección de arte. 
—Música: No vas a quedarte tarareando nada, pero cumple su función de acompañamiento y no molesta.
—Gameplay: Una premisa sencilla y bien ejecutada, no reinventa la rueda pero si le da un uso poco común.
—Bugs: Ninguno.

En el mismo estilo que Octodad o I Am Bread, el principal desafío del juego consistirá en aprender a moverse como una serpiente. Eso sí, aunque el movimiento está bien logrado, es casi obligatorio el uso de un Joystick.

El juego consta de 15 niveles, en su mayoría pequeños y semiabiertos (con un punto que hace de centro, y 2 o 3 caminos a seguir), donde debes recolectar las gemas que sirven para abrir el portal hacia el siguiente nivel, y wisps y monedas que son simples coleccionables (un poco intrascendentes, ya que solo dan una skin una vez los tienes todos).
 A medida que avances nuevos tipos de obstáculos aparecerán para mantener la cosa variada, pero las curvas de aprendizaje y dificultad no son muy empinadas, por lo menos hasta el último nivel, que es una prueba de todo lo aprendido, además de algo de suerte y un ejercicio de paciencia.

Morir es algo común, pero no acarrea grandes consecuencias, y el respawn casi inmediato permite que no pierdas demasiado la inmersión.
Otras reviews se quejan de la ausencia de checkpoints, pero a mi no me resultó problemático salvo en el pesadillezco último nivel. Eso sí, no puedes guardar a la mitad de un nivel, si quieres dejar de jugar a la mitad de uno, perderás todo tu progreso en el mismo. Por fortuna, la mayor parte de los niveles no son muy largos, y una vez recolectado un coleccionable y terminado el nivel, no es necesario juntarlo de vuelta si quieres darle una segunda pasada para obtener todo.

Conclusión: Vale la pena comprarlo. Dura lo justo como para no cansar, y es un juego de calidad tanto a nivel audiovisual como de gameplay.

72051426.review:
I'd put a "meh" if it was an option.

Snake Pass is, unfortunately, a huge miseed opportunity, let me explain.

It is beautiful, have a nice calming music, the charac design is alright and the game is really original in its gameplay mechanics, as in you have to "slither around" like a real snake, you won't advance if you just go forward. This feels satisfying for the major part of the game, when you manage to climb across really complex puzzles by slithering around efficiently. 

BUT, and  such a huge but (hehe...), the last 5 levels are incredibly frustrating and will suck out all the fun you had until now. That was the first time for me I had to stop the game because of headaches.
-The snake only has strength in the first half of it's body, meaning that if you're holding on a pole by the other half, your snake will just slide and fall.
-The Strong Wind mechanic added in the last world is just frustrating, not exciting. Once your snake is caught up in the wind, it'll feel like you have the core strength of a wet noodle, even if you're coiled around a pole, the wind will simply uncoil you around and throw you in the void.
-THE F***ING CAMERA man, i can't count how many times i've died because the camera is fully passive and I don't have enough fingers to turn the camera around while i'm coiling around with 3 fingers. Also the fact that the sidekick likes to put his huge face right between the snake and the camera ain't helpin'!

Anyway, the game has its charm, it feels like a N64 platformer of the time, still, i'd love to try a sequel, with the main issues being adressed, and a better story and power-ups!

72036333.review:
At the time of a writing, I've just collected all the keystones in the levels (completed storyline). The game looks as if it made for kids, however, it's challenging enough so adults would have fun in it, if they ever liked playing Surgeon simulator or Dark Souls.

+CONROLS: While the game was made with gamepad controls in mind, it is possible to play the game with mouse and a keyboard without any disadvatages. While the game levels themselves are challenging, since you're playing a snake with a very unique type of movement, the controls are responsive, and the snake has really, really good, telegraphed physics. So is you're send yourself falling to death, would be entirely your mistake :D 
+ATMOSPHERE: amazing, calm but interesting soundtrack, bright and colorful visuals, lack of time limits (unless you choose them), and a simplistic story make the game far less pressuring, 
Of course, there is no game without flaws:
-Camera: Usually, it's fine and does exactly what you need. However, in some tight spaces it may go insane and make your snake life a bit harder. Luckily, it's not that severe that you're constantly reminded/had to be aware of that problem.
-The tutorial hints are somewhat heavy-handed, but luckily it's source (little bird Doodle that follows you around) usually is silent after the first couple of levels, and can actually be helpful.
=====================
Overall. the cobination of challenging but fair controls and a relaxing atmospehere made the game oddly enjoyable for me. It is relatively short, but you can revisit the game later to collect all shinies and do other achievement-related stuff.
Sequel please?

72004495.review:
Wonky physics, an inconsistent checkpoint system, and a severe lack of creativity bring this game down to the level of unenjoyable that I found it at. 

First, the shortcomings of the physics system in this game are always present. From randomly sliding off poles, to floating like a balloon across gaps, it often makes no sense why your character moves the way he does. This is only made worse by the awful checkpoint system as mentioned before -- if you die, the game resets you to an arbitrary point that you may or may not have touched while navigating the level, and it doesn't save your progress on collectables at all past the previous checkpoint.

The level design is uninspired, and of all 15 levels, the look of the world is virtually the same, despite allegedly having a differing theme for each level set. Only 2 new mechanics are ever introduced to the game, and the rest of it is just doing the same "slither up/down a pole" gameplay loop for the duration of the game. There is little to zero creativity in most of the levels. 

The main character is an annoying moron too.

3/10

71839088.review:
Snake Pass is a neat but frustrating physics-based puzzle platformer. You control Noodle, a snake aided by his buddy Doodle, a bird that can help lift Noodle tail a bit to help him. To complete the game, you need to think like a snake, coiling around poles to enhance the grip and allowing climbing structures more effectively. It is a great idea, however it could be better executed. Gameplay felt a bit random to me, because sometimes I wanted to do something, and the game did the opposite, screwing me. Over time, that stuff happened less, but overall gameplay could have had a bit more polish. Another problem is the camera. Countless times it got in my way, leaving me blinded in the middle of a crucial section. That is a bigger issue, because I can see the gameplay faults as me not having enough skill, but the camera is just bad sometimes.
Beating the story isn’t hard, to be honest, and with 15 stages it isn’t too long either. But if you want to collect everything, that’s where most of the frustration will come from. Sometimes my hands were hurt after hard sections, and that with a controller (I can’t imagine the pain it must be to play this with keyboard and mouse). And, I don’t remember cursing at fictional characters in a long time, but the freaking snake and bird deserved them (although just some of them!). There is some replayability with time attack and arcade modes, each with leaderboards for each level, but unless you are comfortable with the gameplay, I’d say those modes aren’t for you.
In the end, while frustrating, I kind of had some fun with it, and even 100% isn’t a terrible challenge, because it’s doable with enough patience. If you’re looking for a different type of platformer, Snake Pass may be for you, but it’s definitely not for everybody. For cheap, it is worth a try, and if you enjoy the first stages, then it is worth a playthrough. In the end, it is difficult on purpose, but the problem is that some of that difficulty just feels a bit cheap.

71838839.review:
Snake Pass has one of the most interesting and unique movesets for a platformer I have seen. Being restricted to sluggish feeling wiggling without any ability to jump initially feels weird, but is something you get a grasp on fast. After that the game is about becoming one with the snake, like learning its limitations but also its strengths. Playing the final levels was a breeze since at that point the movement felt natural. In that regard, the game is fantastic, and the skill ceiling for it is quite high.

The level design is centered around three main targets, but is filled with collectables, 25 of them to be exact. They can be located on the path to the targets, slightly further away, behind an obstacle course or sometimes even hidden. However they are quite well placed and evenly distributed across the level, and simply by exploring it they can be found without much extra searching, taking me a few extra minutes at worst to find the last one. The difficulty curve is interesting. The levels move gradually from easy to challenging, but the optional collectables provide extra challenge. Orbs being usually slightly harder than the normal path and coins being the hardest challenges in the game.

One slight complaint I do have is the checkpoint system. There are reusable checkpoints scattered around the levels. They work well for the more linearly progressing levels but sometimes feel a little out of place and clumsy for the more open ones, since sometimes the nearest checkpoint after collecting a bunch of collectables can be frustratingly far away. I know it provides a decision for taking the safe route or risking and saving time, but at times it does feel kind of odd.

The music is extremely catchy, even if it at times can get kind of repetitive. The artstyle and aesthetic feels uplifting and chill and looks reasonably good when thinking about pure graphical fidelity. Not much else to say about it, except that it fits the game perfectly.

Overall, the game was short and sweet. The game has a total of 15 levels + unlockable arcade and time trial modes. It took me about 8 hours to get 100% collectables and that time flew by fast. Personally I got the game for free, but I can still confidently say that for what it's worth, It's a brilliant platformer and a refreshing experience.

This is a much better game than I thought. Oddly, I would compare this to a racing game. Controlling Noodle is very much like playing a realistic racing game, manual transmission, on a wet track, using the controller. It's all about feathering the controls and never giving up control. He is constantly slipping. The movement and environment, the main parts, I have no problem with. They are well enough that you can master them. 

The MAIN problem is the camera. It especially becomes problematic in the wind world. In the wind world there are a lot of rotating elements and the camera becomes inconsistent. Since movement is tied to camera position, your inputs are no longer consistent as well. The camera needs to lock to the rotating elements or the elements need to change. Many people are going to run into these and wont understand why they are suddenly failing so much and give up. Aside from that, sometimes even Doodle gets right in front of the camera. Resetting the camera doesn't always do what you expect.

I really like playing as Noodle. I like the level design and the ability to take "advanced" routes, makes it feel like early 3D platformers. I hope to see more of this in the future.

71545411.review:
A kind of short, novel 3D platformer which as a whole was an relatively enjoyable experience. It took me about 7 and a half hours to beat the game with all the primary collectibles. The game is family-friendly and seems aimed toward kids, but the difficulty of the controls and some of the platforming is probably too high for many younger children. 
The manner in which you must control your character, a snake, is the bread and butter of the game and I believe it's well done, at least from the perspective of someone who played using a controller. The controls might seem somewhat difficult initially, but it doesn't take long to get a hold of wiggling and wrapping around things after a couple levels. The movement felt adequately snakey to me. I liked the fact that you had to slither back and forth to pick up speed. The nature of the controls however, constantly holding in your RT button and wiggling the analog stick, can leave the hands feeling tired after not too long and would make it a pretty bad choice for people with issues such as arthritis. The camera can be a little wonky on occasion and wind up getting you killed, but for the most part it's not terrible by any means.   
The primary fault of the game in my opinion is a heavy lack of variety. There's a couple areas throughout the game which introduce some minor new mechanics: water, switches, moving platforms, and wind. I think that's an exhaustive list, unfortunately. The areas themselves are visually quite samey as well; it's more of a lighting change between them than anything. It would have been a real breath of fresh air to be climbing vines, tree branches, other man-made structures, and more instead of nothing but bamboo fence-like structures for 15 levels straight even if it's just a glorified tile-swap. Rather than mildly forest overrun tribal temple exterior-esque brick for 15 levels straight, some plain heavy-forest area, some temple interior, some volcanic rock or any other areas or tile-sets that would still fit with the setting. It should then come as no surprise that the platforming itself starts to feel a bit stale towards the end too after you grow accustomed to the controls, considering the lack of obstacle-type variation. Maybe had they added a couple actual goals beyond the collectathon elements, which don't do a whole lot to foster a sense of accomplishment, they would have been able to keep things more fresh.
Although I think the game could certainly have been quite a bit better I did get a few hours fun out of it and would be happy to break it out again with my nephew or something. I wouldn't pay full-price but I'd gladly have bought it on sale.

71343862.review:
Snake Pass is one of those nice little games that has a completely original mechanic for you to master and doesn't overstay its welcome. It takes the running and jumping out of the 3D platformer and has you slithering around and winding your way around bamboo jungle gym playgrounds to seek out collectibles. The learning curve is solid and I went from uneasily making my way up small obstacles to quickly winding my way over poles that jut far over vast death pits with little worry. Mechanics are a little confusing at first, but once I got used to them I found them very lenient and in most cases you only need to just barely make it to a platform and get your head onto it to be able to wiggle the rest of your body up. 

If Snake Pass suffers from anything it's a lack of variety. Over the course of my playthrough I felt like variety of challenges hadn't vastly changed from the first level to the last, aside from the addition of some moving obstacles to climb they only increase the amount of time you have to spend over death pits. If you think of the best platformers there's the general difficulty curve of the platforming, but also unique challenges appear frequently across the levels so there's always something new to figure out. Each of the four worlds in Snake Pass has a theme, but only in the last does this come up as a new challenge in the level design.

Even if it's a a bit shy of being as good as it could have been it's nice to see a game that tries something unique.

It's a very difficult game if you aren't just going for the exit on each level, but worth the challenge in my opinion.  A controller is necessary.  The art is lively and endearing, and it has a nice soundtrack as well.  Truly a unique and well-executed concept that makes an unforgettable title.  Just be aware of potential frustration and remember where the checkpoints are.  I got the game for free from Humble Bundle, but would definitely pay for it.

71286693.review:
[h1]The closest I've ever gotten to breaking a controller.[/h1]

Snake Pass is almost a spiritual successor to Axy Snake but focused in object collecting, exploration, puzzles and precise movement control. The idea is very interesting and unique, but both the controls and stage designs can be very frustrating at times. 

The game is not very friendly or casual, despite its graphics. There is room for improvement in the controls, which are very unforgiving: It's hard to climb up maintaining grip, sometimes Noodle's head angle changes in an unexpected manner and you fall, the "lock" mechanic is not intuitive and Noodle's top speed isn't that great, even after you learn how to slither around. Controls could be more forgiving, Noodle could have more natural grip and still the core gameplay would be the same.

Whenever you die, you lose all objects collected before the last checkpoint, which invites you to constantly go back and forth saving progress, and this combined with Noodle's less-than-impressive top speed, can become tedious especially when the closest checkpoint is not that close or not an easy path to travel. Also, in order to save your collectibles you [u]must[/u] open the portal and finish the stage. That invites players to 100% each stage on their first attempt ("I don't wanna do this all over again because of a missed coin") which makes play sessions longer and more frustrating, when you push past the point of enjoyment just to be done with a stage.

[b]Final review:[/b] I recommend enjoying Snake Pass in small doses (like fully completing one stage per day), don't hesitate to use guides (you don't wanna have to redo every stage just to grab a couple of missed objects) and remember, good controllers are expensive, so resist the urge to squeeze and twist while you're shaking in a fit of rage (trust me, these [u]will[/u] come).

You’re the most agile snake ever and you can talk to birds while you slither around and collect shiny stuff. It’s a simple plot and it teases a bigger story but it’s a simple plot that doesn’t take itself seriously and just exists (but I wish I could skip the cutscenes). 71011610.review:
This game is a bit of a hidden gem. I picked it up for free on Humble Bundle, because I have a hard time turning down a free game. I expected it to sit in my library for a while, and then I would try it out and have fun for an hour at most. However, I found a bit of free time so I tried it. I love this game! Not only is it beautiful, but it is addicting and the features amazing snake physics. I know a lot of people do not like the controls, but I think the controls are incredible. It is hard to get the hang of being a snake, but after you do it is super satisfying to play. The key is to remember you are actually controlling the whole snake, not just the head. You need to balance your head and you tail, and that will trip you up constantly.

Now the game is not long, and I would not recommend spending more than $20 on it, simply for the shear lack of content, but this is a hidden Gem  that you can sink 5-8 hours into. Some of you will hate the snake physics, but some of you will love it. I think this is the Mario of snake games myself just because of how well you can move once you get the physics down. Now that I am good at the snake physics I find myself wriggling into all sorts of places, even places I probably was not designed to go. I love it!

71011177.review:
Received for free from humble bundle 
Honestly this game makes me think about Dark Souls in a number of ways. Primarily is that people say it's really hard when it isn't, similar to dark souls, this game is fair yet challenging, as it has its own rules that you need to learn before you can succeed. In that same vein, death is not a setback but an opportunity to learn from your mistakes and keep at it. Patience and perseverance is rewarded.
This is a very cute puzzle platformer that focuses on unique movement mechanics including slithering, climbing, and wrapping tightly around posts to traverse 15 moderately sized levels for collectibles. Spanning 4 worlds with different themes and gimmicks, I took 3ish hours to complete but if you care about getting more collectibles than necessary this could easily last much longer. 
My few negatives are that while this game looks great, there are surprisingly few graphics options given how simple all of the objects in levels are, and the swimming controls, while not frequently required, are fairly awkward.
Neutral point: Again like dark souls, using a controller is an absolute must.
Overall - 7/10 for what it is, and I would have been willing to spend 5 bucks on it for how long it is

70991989.review:
Getting the Game from the humble bundle its a great game and one i would not outset 20$ over to personally play but getting it for free was nice as I get to enjoy this game that I would not personally mind trying.

But in making a review I am going to say to those who say the controls are crap, to those I say. USE A CONTROLLER they literally recommend you use one. Because the controls with a keyboard are trash, if you have one use a Steam controller. But any USB controller with the help of Steam Big Screen's Controller config you can get a control scheme that will hold up well.

*sigh* Anyways

As for the game itself its a classic collectathon "Platformer?" where you play as Noodle the Snek and must work with Doodle the Hummingbird to pick up keystone's, Gate Keeper Coins, and Blue Wisps in an effort to make level progress and open up the level exit gate with said Keystone's (Which are the only collectables required). But playing as a Snek has its challenges one of which being you can't jump. (Yes a Platformer where jumping is not a thing) So as a Result you must slither up and around things to reach them. The Keystone's are what is required to progress, The blue wisps are special collectables scattered around the level that you have to pick up, most of them are in the way, some not so much. And gate keeper Coins are these special collectables that are put in hard to reach places with the first level giving you a taste of just how hard they are to grab.

Playing as Noodle is not particularly hard and you can get Doodle to pick up Noodles tail to make it easier to climb over things at the expense that Noodle cant extend as high when Doodle has his tail in which you have to tell doodle to put your tail down. And Because your a snek you need to slither in a left and right alternating motion to gain good momentum or speed. You can also grip to make it so Noodle stiffens up to make more subtle movements up objects to prevent falling. The camera can be hard but the camera buttons when you learn to use them right let you see around noodle for the most part.

As for difficulty its easy to learn hard to master, most required things are easy to get early on with those coins being the real test of skill in your knowledge on how to control Noodle. Also in classic collectathon fashion if you die, you respawn at your last checkpoint with anything you got before you touched a new checkpoint counted as being lost, forcing you to recollect it. Some can consider it bad game design, but because the levels are not on the very long end. Its more to stop you from jumping off in a kamikaze cheese it attempt to grab that one collectable without skill. And do believe me some of them do require a lot of skill to collect (Mainly the coins as I pointed out earlier)

Overall 8/10 Its a good game to enjoy in short bursts once you get the hang of it, and preferably played with a controller. Because cmon who would come on here and complain and write a bad review about keyboard controls despite the game telling them its recommended to use a controller, surely no one. :D
