70866545.review:
WHAT IS THIS GAME?
This game is all about mastering the wonky controls of a snake protoganist in order to collect items throughout obstacle courses.

WHAT THIS GAME *IS NOT*
This game doesn't involve solving any puzzles; the levels are designed like obstacle courses, not puzzles. Also, it's *not* particularly relaxing; you'll often find yourself tightening your grip on the mouse/controller and cringing as you try not to slip off ledges.

WHAT GENRE IS THIS GAME?
It's not quite an adventure in the spirit of Banjo-Kazooie. I would actually liken it more to Mirror's Edge. Like Mirror's Edge, the game is based entirely around your skills with a particular set of moves/controls.

HOW DIFFICULT IS THIS GAME?
There's a steep learning curve at the beginning, but about an hour or two into the game, you'll realize that the game is pretty easy to complete. However, the game is significantly more difficult if you try to collect all the collectibles and *especially* if you try to collect all the Steam achievements. This game is good for both casual gamers and "serious" gamers alike.

IS THIS GAME WORTHWHILE?
Yes, this game is definitely worthwhile. The most common complaint among the negative reviews seems to be that people don't like the controls. Well, mastering the controls is the whole point! Be prepared for a steep learning curve over the first hour of gameplay, but if you're OK with that, then I think most people would enjoy this game.

70865655.review:
What is Snake Pass ?

Something you dont usually see in those big, more expensive productions aka AAA games is new gameplay mechanics, innovation or just a fresh feel that youre playing something new that you didnt even see before, since the AAA market focus on existing formulas that they try to polish and change a little bit and then inject some marketing there and thats the AAA games you get, when you play them theres always this sense of familiarity, like "I played this before but It was another game", the reason why we need the Medium Markets and the Indie games scene is for games like Snake Pass.

Snake Pass originally was a game jam idea, the idea was to make a platform where you cant jump and they came with the idea of making a snake game where you have full control of its body movements, the non-AAA market has not only the balls but the boldness to experiment new things, which differentiate them from the AAA market and make them stand out, snake pass is not only a beautiful-looking game, its styllistic, comes with an amazing soundtrack and is overall a cute game, for gameplay, since its so different, theres nothing like it done before, you control this snake named noodle and you have an open but small environment, your objective is to collect 3 keys to open the gate to the next levels, theres 15 levels total and some can be quite long, one took me around 40mins, either way the controls are different and may put you off initially, its one of those "not so easy to get into but hard to master" because again its different and unconventional, I do recommend a controller instead of a keyboard since it feels better, you control noodle by swinging its body, gripping and cycling around obstacles, you also have a bird companion that explain a little more about the story of the game and he can help you by grabbing your tail which can save you sometimes from falling off the map for example.

Overall it took me around 7 hours to finish and I spent a bit more time doing time trials and the bonus adventure mode, the duration of the game is fair to me, considering it relies on a specific gameplay which it gave all of its focus to, it could have been repetitive if it went longer, so for me the duration was fine, it didnt overstay its welcome, theres some repetition in the overall look of the levels too, I had some problems with the camera aswell, especially in the final level but besides that the game is great, full of personality, it provided me tons of challenge and fun with many sequences that required skill to pull off and the huge satisfaction I had when I managed to finish a level after all the hard obstacles I had to pass, its a satisfying game, the best "snake simulator" you can get, if thats even a thing, hehe, fans of games that try new things or platformers should give it a go, its cheap and its worth getting.

70745787.review:
TL;DR: Get the game on sale. Fun and relaxing game (if you can handle the controls) padded out with a lackluster story, long levels, and collectibles that barely serve any purpose or motivation to collect them. 

Pros: 
-Fun to control and slide around (if the controls work for you) 
-Relaxing atmosphere where you can go at your own pace exploring stages. 
-No enemies to worry about helps the relaxing atmosphere. 
- Music is very pleasing. 
-Arcade mode is a fun change of pace if the game is too relaxing

Cons: 
-Controls are hard to get used to. 
-Not much variety in music
-Not much incentive to collect any of the extras. 
-Levels often feel larger than they need to be, with hardly any reason to explore
-Not much of a story. 

================

Introduction:
This is an interesting game that somehow manages to be relaxing and frustrating at the same time. 
Although you play as a snake, the game makes you feel more like a human in a snakes body. 
When you get the controls down, it's very pleasing to glide along the ground, wrapping around things, and explore. 

However, the tutorial level does a bad job and teaching you this. I learned a lot of the controls by playing later levels that had bigger structures to wrap around.  The first level has some things to climb, but most are right at ground level. And the ones that aren't are over bottomless pits. They also lead to a coin, and since the nature of this game just encourages you to explore, it can leave a bad first impression to keep trying for the coins and keep failing because the first level seems to forget that it should be getting you comfortable with the controls, not punishing you for stepping outside your comfort zone and skill level to get used to the game. 

Those who do stick with the game after this will likely come back to collect the coins and wisps they missed the first time. Which leads me to the second problem with this game. Unskippable cutscenes. Hardly anything goes on in them, and they are hardly worth watching the first time. But you have to watch them everytime you play a level. If you come back to the first level halfway through the game, you're still going to watch the cutscene that introduces you to the characters and story. 

================

Story: 
Speaking of characters and the story, there isn't much good to say. The story feels like it's just tacked on. I'm halfway through the game ( I think ), and it's still not explained what the gates are, and why I should care about fixing them, who the gate keepers are, what the "thing" is that sounds like a large bird. 

================

Characters: 
The characters are okay, but the don't compliment each other at all. The bird starts off the game in a panic, waking the snake up because the gates are broken and you need to fix them. The snake wakes up and maybe looks a little worried? But overall looks like he couldn't care less. His expressions and seemingly not-all-there attitude, along with the birds more serious nature reminds me a lot of Crash Bandicoot and his sister. But I don't think it works here. There's no backstory to these characters, nothing to tie them together. Making the contrast between the bird and the snake much more obvious. Like the bird was only made to be serious and in a panic in a shallow attempt to encourage the player to continue the story. 
Crash Bandicoot doesn't have the most in-depth story either. However, the little things it does goes a long way. Crash and Coco are sisters, so they have history, they have a mentor figure (aku aku), and you know who the villain is and have clear motivation from the start of the game. In this game, I often feel like I shouldn't even care. I mean, why should I? The snake certainly doesn't look like he cares. 

The character design is just fine. Although, I think they could've worked on making the expressions on the snakes face more distinct and less clueless. 

Okay, so the story isn't all that great. Let's get into the details about the gameplay. 

================

Gameplay: 
The controls seem flawless most of the time. Again, this is assuming you can get used to them. They are confusing at times and the game does a bad job at explaining the mechanics. For example, L2 makes the snake tighten in an attempt to stay in place. But when you are wrapped around something, it's not clear what part of you will stay tightened, and what part will seemingly at random start to uncoil. Sometimes it's the lower half, sometimes it's the upper half. If you get unlucky, it's usually not hard to correct yourself and avoid dying. But it seems nearly impossible to wrap fully around something like an actual snake can. A big part of this seems to come down to just how slippery the snake feels to control. This becomes painfully evident if you attempt to go for the no diving achievement. Ironically, despite feeling slippers, the snake feels slow and sticky on the ground, unless you can get the slithering motion down. 

For the most part, the game doesn't put you in situations where it's hard to correct yourself if you start to slip. My last on the controls are how sometimes the camera locks in place, which can make it extremely difficult as finding a comfortable camera angle is a big part of why this game's controls are at the very least manageable. Thankfully, the game only rarely takes control of the camera away from you.  

The levels are actually well designed, aside from the first one. They are a little big, and it can be a real drag to realize you forgot a coin or something and have to go all the way back (if you care about collectibles). If there was more of a reason to collect the wisps and coins, or more things to find, or reasons to explore, the levels being so big wouldn't be such a bad thing.  

Speaking of collectibles, there's two types to collect. In every level, there are 20 wisps and 5 coins. However, these collectibles feel tacked on just to pad out the game. There doesn't even seem to be a difference between the 2. Coins are usually harder to get, but some wisps are in locations just as hard to reach. Not to mention that the wisps blend into the level so well that the levels can look boring and empty. This could've easily been fixed by adding the fruit from arcade mode into the main game. There also doesn't seem to be any backstory to them, and no reason to collect them other than getting 100% completion. No upgrades. No extra levels. Nothing. Not even simple cosmetic options like being able to change the snakes color or something. Well, there is one thing: [spoiler] There's an 8-bit skin for the bird and the snake if you collect everything. [/spoiler]

The game also has two other game modes. An arcade mode and a time trial mode. Let's discuss them one at a time. 

The time trial game mode is probably exactly how you expect. Simply get through the level as fast as you can. At the end, you can see how your time compares to others. However, this is where time trial falls short. You can only see the fastest times for 2 players above and below you. And there are no numbers to rank the players. You could be the 3rd fastest player, or the 30,000th fastest player, and you'll have no idea. 

The arcade mode is  actually a lot of fun. You have a time limit, but I didn't find it to restrictive. You go around the stage collecting as many fruit as you can before time runs out. Different fruit give different amounts of points. And there being an immediate reward to collecting the fruit, combined with the different types of fruit, makes them very satisfying to collect. I think if they had put the fruit into the main game, it would have been so much more fun to explore the levels. 

================

Music: 
The music is very pleasing. It's relaxing to listen to and really adds to the experience. Although, as the songs are the same for each level in a world, you're likely to be bored of the song by the time you get to the next world. 

See top for final verdict.

70740326.review:
[h1][b]5.8 / 10[/b] (Critical) - Interesting unique experience. Cute, cozy and questionable.[/h1]
• It takes a [b]VERY[/b] long time to properly grasp the controls in Snake Pass, because there's many tricky situations the game doesn't properly teach you how to handle. It takes [b]at least[/b] 5 hours of play time before you'll feel like you're in full control of the snake, and that's only if you're trying to 100% the game as you go, since that forces you to learn tougher tasks, otherwise it takes longer. [b]Quick Tip:[/b] [i]Grip is super useful, and use a controller.[/i]
• With that said, Snake Pass is fairly difficult and it emulates a snake very well.
• The music is great, composed by [b]David Wise[/b], but there's only about 6(?) [b]primary[/b] tracks in the game repeating for 10+ hours; 4 during actual gameplay, because there's only 1 music track for each world, and there's 4 worlds/realms. I love the music in world 2 particularly.
• I think there's a little issue with gameplay consistency. Usually things work as they should, but they also regularly fall apart for no discernible reason even when you feel like you had everything under control.
• There's a mechanic where slithering left and right increases your move & climb speed, and avoiding this can slow you down to the point where you can't even move. This mechanic is far more annoying than interesting or enjoyable, from beginning to end. It's not clear [i]precisely how[/i] you should be slithering to efficiently gain speed, and most of the time it grants very little speed. The average move speed in this game is unbearably slow.
• There's no button to quickly respawn at checkpoints, which would've been preferable to a slowly falling/dying snake that also slowly respawns into a controllable state.
• The camera is obnoxious. Its FOV is too low to get a good sense of the stage layout, which is disorienting, and it constantly zooms too far in if there's nearby objects, and multiple collectibles force a nearly unusable camera. There should've been more than 2 zoom levels or a way to control the zoom level more precisely, which could've been implemented easily by holding RB/R1 while adjusting it with other buttons.
• A few of the special challenge achievements have very misleading descriptions and don't like to register.
• There's no indicator for which stages you've disturbed the gatekeeper idols in, yet there's an achievement to disturb one in each stage.
• There's no indicator for which stages you've beaten deathless, yet there's an achievement to beat all stages deathless.
• You can't change graphics settings in-game; it can only be done through the main menu.
• Depth of Field can only be disabled by changing the Post Processing setting to Low, which is unfortunately bundled with a bunch of other post processing effects you will want enabled. The game looks significantly better with DoF disabled.
• The game's mechanical annoyances pop up a ton in the second half of the game, making the last 2 worlds a bit more frustrating than fun, which probably could've been alleviated with a couple more checkpoints or shortcuts, or addressing the annoyances.
• There's no way to disable or adjust controller vibration, which makes it easier to get carpal tunnel.
• None of the cutscenes are skippable.
• [i]Arcade[/i] and [i]Time Trial[/i] modes are good for replayability, but they don't have any achievements, which you could have done for each of these modes on each stage, so 30 additional achievements for interacting with all of the stages in new and challenging ways.
• [b]Snake Pass is kind of cute & cozy though.[/b]

It's worth trying, but try to go in with a lot of patience.

70687831.review: Look, I've wanted to play this game for a long time and have come close to buying it many times. Finally got it free on both Amazon and Humble. I really want to love this game. Its super charming, the environments are adorable, but... the controls are so horribly explained and underdeveloped. I'm a huge fan of hard to control games. I've 100%ed I Am Bread and truly consider that game to be amazing. It has difficult controls that are easy to learn quickly and then its just a matter of figuring out strategies. In this game, they never take the time to properly explain the controls and then immediately dump you into scenarios that expect you to start building strategies around these controls that you don't understand and are incredibly obtuse. I tried my best to enjoy this game, but it just isnt very good and the fact that its been out for three years and is still at this level of quality isn't terribly promising. Maybe we'll get a sequel one day that'll tighten everything up a bit and be a true classic, but for now this is just a cute failed experiment.

69971416.review:
This game breathes new life into the genre of 3D Platformers.
The main critique Snake Pass seems to get is the controls, which I found aren't an issue so long as you take your time to learn them, however skills from past games don't translate well if you've never played a game with this method of movement. For example, aiming in a 2D Platformer is very different from aiming in an FPS though the basic concept is the same.

Aside from the movement mechanics it's just a well made game. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fresh take on the genre.

Best played with keyboard & mouse in my opinion, though on a 360 controller it was just as fun.

69930808.review:
This is probably one of the most unique platforming games I've come across. I've never seen one that had such a strange and unfamiliar non-humanoid style of movement. I'd say the most important thing to know about before getting this game is not to expect it to play like your average platforming game, because if you come in with that expectation, you're probably going to end up frustrated. This is not a fast paced game. You are encouraged to go through the various climbing challenges with a slow, methodical pace, much like a snake would. It's something that can be pretty confusing at first and requires a lot of patience, but once you make sense of the controls, you can tell that the devs put a TON of work into refining how Noodle moves and in perfecting their body's physics. Also, just as one last closing thought, the fact that the protagonist of this game is a snake, and a realistically proportioned one at that. I love snakes a lot and think that a lot of them are very lovely, cute, and affectionate creatures. They get far too much of a negative stigma, so it's nice to see a game that appreciates how great they are.

TLDR: The game is really well made, but don't come in expecting it to be like a normal platformer. It's pretty slow paced and has controls that can be confusing at first (but that's just because of how alien the movement is. It makes total sense once you figure it out.) Highly recommend, especially if you love snakes.

69239501.review:
It's rare you get to play a game where the core mechanic is this original, and from that perspective Snake Pass is a real breath of fresh air, offering the chance for people to learn and then master a brand new way of moving around inside a game world. The difficulty curve is pretty good, which is another way of me telling you not to under estimate this game based on its art style - it can be really difficult at times, and you'll curse both the game, yourself and Noodle himself frequently throughout. But it's also quite fair, and you'll quickly figure out what you're doing wrong and make good progress.

The only real flaws are that the camera can be a real pain in the ass at times, and it's a shame that you move from level to level through a simple menu rather than through a proper hub world. Still, if you're looking for a novel, challenging platforming game that doesn't overstay its welcome, Snake Pass is definitely worth checking out.

66958408.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=64s_GLs17p0

Snake Pass is a game that manages to be very reminiscent of the golden age of 3D platformers and yet wholly unique when compared and contrasted with the games of that era. The ways in which it evokes this bygone age of gaming is fairly evident just by looking at it: You play as a cute animal in a colorful world and you have to collect things in order to progress. It’s not far removed from games like Banjo-Kazooie or Spyro in that regard. 

But what makes it radically different form pretty much every other game it might superficially be compared to is one key fact: Since you control a snake, you simply can’t jump. And that removes basically everything a traditional 3D platformer usually builds its other systems around. The way the developers managed to create engaging gameplay by not featuring one of the cornerstones of the genre is pretty damn excellent.

Since you can’t jump around to your hearts content, the developers focused on the one thing that every game should strive for: Controlling your character should be fun even without any other challenge in the game. Think about the Mario games. Ever since Super Mario 64, Mario has gotten a large number of varied moves he can execute. Just running and jumping around in all the different ways you can is fun, even before you jump on the first Goomba’s head. And even as recently as Super Mario Odyssey, you can clearly see this principle still paying large dividends. So, true to that principle, Noodle, the snake you control in Snake Pass, is immensely fun to move around the levels by itself. 

It might take you some time to get used to the control scheme and fully internalize what happens when you push an analog stick in any given direction or press a button. Because, since you control a snake, you also have to move around like a snake. Pulling the trigger to move yourself in the direction Noodle is facing may push you forward but if you only move in a straight line, you’ll slow down to a crawl almost immediately. Because snakes don’t actually move around like that. In order to gain momentum, you’ll have to wiggle around just like a real snake would. Since this is a platformer, you’ll need to find ways in order to actually reach higher or lower places safely, so again, you’ll be using techniques borrowed from real life in order to climb around these levels competently. That means winding up tightly around objects in order to maximize friction in order to not slide off.

Since the focus of the game is mastering the movement of the animal you’re supposed to be playing, there’s no actual combat going in in the game. You have enough on your plate with the controls and figuring out how to traverse these levels without also having to bother killing enemies. But you still need a challenge. And it’s safe to say that the biggest adversary in the game is actually your character itself. This concept is nothing new. There are tons of games, often built around poorly implemented physics systems whose challenge stems entirely from getting through the game with a character that’s hard to control. But most of the time this is done for comedic effect and never really intended for graceful play. So, it’s very nice to see that Snake Pass takes the high road here and really wants you to commit to playing as a snake. Because Noodle’s body is obviously affected by gravity. And if the majority of the weight dangles off a ledge, you’ll risk sliding off. Though the game does offer a method of making things easier. Noodle has a hummingbird companion called Doodle and with a push of a button, you can use Doodle to lift Noodle’s tail and carry it around. That doesn’t mean that you can’t fall off a ledge, but it makes it easier when your tail manages to slide off and threatens to pull you along with it, which is nice.

However, the fact that Noodle is so finicky to control can still lead to some frustration, especially during later levels that severely ramp up the challenge, notably if you’re bent on really finding all the collectibles. I am by no means a completionist, but whenever I encounter a challenge I enjoy, I at least try to go for as much as I can. But I have to say that the last batch of levels tested my patience at certain points. Especially one of the very final jumps that required me to have Noodle be blown from one platform onto another one by a gust of wind that almost seemed like it deliberately went against every other type of challenge where you have to avoid the wind as best as possible.

But to the game’s credit, you’re never required to collect more than the requisite three keys that unlock the portal to the next level, so if you don’t care about collecting everything or you just can’t be bothered to overcome a certain challenge, you can just leave it at that.

Now, in the introduction, I mentioned how the game feels similar to 3D platformers of ye olde times. But one thing that is absent and what made that genre so endearing to me were the silly characters, the bonkers narratives and the often irreverent humor in their writing. And this is one aspect that Snake Pass, this time unfortunately, didn’t opt to let itself be inspired by. The justification for why you’re traversing these levels is thinner than one ply toilet paper. It’s honestly not even worth wasting any words in describing it, because it’s so perfunctory. Suffice to say that I would’ve loved to see some actual writing in a game that already features a cartoony world where you control a snake called Noodle. Because the rest of the presentation is pretty much spot on to what you’d expect from this type of game. You have a set of 15 levels divided into four thematic sets around earth, water, fire and air and it all looks gorgeous and the soundtrack is equally great and enjoyable.

If you’re after a fun and challenging gameplay experience, I can definitely recommend Snake Pass. It’s intelligently designed and offers an interesting and novel way of gameplay. But if you saw any of the trailers or screenshots and got nostalgic for the antics of the likes of Conkers, Banjo and the rest, I’m sad to say that Snake Pass unfortunately isn’t what you’re looking for.

It is a competently made game, and it was difficult to decide to ultimately give this game the thumb's down. It came down to if I think others will actually like this game and I think the answer is no.

The bottom line, without getting too wordy, is that the game becomes monotonous within minutes. All you do is tediously creep around maps hitting various touchpoints. Once I got control of the snake which only took me around 5 minutes, I quickly found that the entirety of the game's depth was revealed to me in that 5 minutes. The tedium set in immediately.

It should be fun, but I did not find it fun in the least. I'm not refunding, but I almost want to. There's no way this game is worth the almost $27 CAD that it is priced at right now. Even if you though this was the most thrilling snake game in the world, I feel it would be worth $4 at most. So please consider my review, but take it with a grain of snakey salt. Think like a snake!

Excellent! A new favorite.

Closest thing to a "snake simulator" ever. Just moving around the game is fun, and if you need a break, curl up and take a nap.

Novel, looks like a Rare game, music is relaxing, the main character is full to the brim with personality, the mechanics of controlling a snake are One-of-a-kind, fun, and you feel so good when you control your snek effectively. 64368113.review:
Superb. The control scheme is pure marmite. 

If you perceive a snake's movement as being as simple as pushing a button to hold instant set speed, to be able to turn on a dime, to be able to stick to objects like your belly has some sticky super glue on it and you're able to defy the laws of gravity then it probably won't be for you. 

On the other flip side if you perceive a snakes movement to be about acceleration through rhythmic wriggling, that the snake has an almost pendulum like weight distribution to it with the balance between heavy head and light body being a factor in both turning and balancing across props. If you appreciate the game play elements that the "grip" mechanics introduce, that coiling introduces, of being able to pretty much knot yourself round monkey bars and objects then you'll find enjoyment and probably long for it to be more challenging. I've seen people refer to the controls as tank like, I'd encourage anyone that sees this as tank like to watch some videos of semi decent players movement as its closer to flowing and free form.

Took around nine hours for an initial completion and another 2-3 for no deaths. Stand outs are the unique control mechanics, monkey barring and visuals which remind me of some of the best of RARE / NINTENDO and are probably the most colourful usage of UE I've ever seen. Minor critique...would have benefited so much from a workshop, needed two more zones IMO to be a satisfying length, they could have followed obvious tropes and had an industrial zone with conveyors and a zone styled on portals with teleporters as an example, also unskippable cut scenes.

Other than that thoroughly enjoyable and appropriately priced.

62642878.review:
A lot has been said of Snake Pass, with the focus of negative reviews being some mixture of the controls or difficulty. While I can understand frustrations at the start, Snake Pass is a deceptively easy game to play. Without much variety, practically all collectibles dangle precariously above the sky with no ground beneath them. Without much variety, the path towards them are bamboo sticks that loosely form a path towards the collectible. Your first collectible will be difficult to grab a hold of, but once you realize how to control Noodle the Snake, every challenge afterward is just repetition of the same basics.

The controls get some criticism, but they're actually ingenious. Noodle....moves like a Snake. He moves on the slower side, but to bypass potential issues the levels require the most minimal of traversing. There's never so much ground to cover that it showcases the slow move-speed and makes it an issue. I can understand wanting the ability to move Noodle to his left or right, rather than making left and right relative to where the camera is positioned at that time. I also understand that the camera can get a bit finicky and fights you at some points, but barring a few annoyances I never found it to be a detrimental issue to the overall experience.

My main issue with Snake Pass is the slow pace of everything. Every collectible is an agonizingly time-consuming experience. You're supposed to grab collectibles by wrapping around bamboo and making your way onward once you have a solid grip of where you are presently located. 

You're supposed to move slow. This game is meant to be a slow game. Moving fast means losing your grip.

You'll find that safely getting anything can take you upwards of 7 to 10 minutes depending on what the circumstances are. Ironically, fewer collectibles and levels would alleviate the issue, as Snake Pass is a game that remains interesting for a small window frame before becoming monotonous. It's not that the game is hard, it's that it's boring.

Snake Pass merits some respect for taking the idea and movement of a Snake, and placing it in a platformer sans the ability to actually jump. Other games have done it better (Bionic Commando), but Snake Pass takes the central tenets of its protagonist and makes it all work. For that I have to give it credit. Its a platformer who's challenge really lies in its physics, which is odd to say but makes sense in practice. But wrapping yourself around bamboo lying above what is a bottomless pit gets old once you solved the entire game within the first hour. And it's not the type of game you can just drop and come back to: you are committed to 30+ minute playtimes unless you want to lose all progress you'be made in a level. There is no saving.

I get the appeal to some, but I just felt like I was wasting time. I understand that the game does some things right, and I've given it its due. But ultimately the game is a slowly trodding affair without much meat or variety in a plate that is too large for the actual substance of the portion served. 3/10.

56290911.review:
This is almost my dream game. You're a goofy slithery snake with an adorable hummingbird friend, and you move like an actual snake. The controls are definitely challenging, which is what makes this game so much fun. It really gives me that PS2 platformer collectathon game vibe that I miss so much with its beautiful jungle and underwater environments. It kind of gives me that cozy Spyro: A Hero's Tail feeling from my childhood. All the music tracks are also extremely catchy.

Controls: 8/10 - The fascinating thing about this game is that there's a learning curve to the controls. It can be extremely difficult at first for new players, but fortunately there's an "easy mode" for the controls, and you can also play with a controller. Personally I found it much more comfortable to play with a controller, so to me this is the best way to play this game.

Gameplay or Concept Execution: 8/10 - You have to think like a snake to move in this game. Additionally this game is like a mini collectathon 3D platformer with terrific platforms and creative level design in the 15 levels across 4 different "worlds". Additionally your hummingbird friend Doodle can pick up your tail to help you in some sections. Besides the platforming, there's two more modes: an arcade mode in which you collect as many fruits as you can, and a time trial mode in which you try to beat the level as fast as possible. Personally, I think the game was a little too short, so it loses a point in this category. I completed the game 100% in just 15 hours. Also, the camera can be impossible to deal with sometimes, making the maneuvering harder than probably intended.

This game has Steam achievements, which I am currently trying to complete 100%. They're challenging to get, so this adds more length to the game.

Aesthetic: 10/10 - The 4 worlds in this game are gorgeous and are based on the four elements of earth, water, fire, and wind. The game is terrifically optimized. I was surprised how fast it ran on my laptop despite being so detailed. The water in this game looks absolutely delicious, and you will get enjoyment out of diving and dancing in it as a snake. 

The characters are ADORABLE, and there's no voice-acting, thankfully. The characters "speak" through little sounds and a text box, but the sounds aren't unpleasant. This game has a wonderful Spyro/PlayStation-like quality and personality to it.

Music: 10/10 - This game has some of the best music I have ever heard before. Mark my words: every single track will get stuck in your head. Each world has a different vibe that's reflected perfectly in the associated track and actually helps with concentration.

Sound Design: 10/10 - The sounds all fit the environments and nothing feels out of place. The hummingbird makes cute rrrr sounds, and the snake makes funny gasps and yelps in a goofy male voice. He actually sounds a little like Spyro, now that I think about it.

Final Score: 🎍 9/10

Suggestions: More levels, Workshop support, level-editor, co-op, skippable cutscenes, better camera

55125602.review:
Un ataque de nostalgia para los amantes de la época en la que todo videojuego debía ser un plataformas 3D y una experiencia a disfrutar por los más peques. Snake Passs es entretenido, fácil de entender y dominable, tres claves que forman los mejores casual 3D. No obstante, tiene muchos problemas por pulir, los más destacables siendo la cámara y el diseño de varios niveles.

Los objetivos al igual que mayoría de puzzles se reparten por el mapa aprovechándose de la horizontalidad, debes subir al punto A para recibir el objeto X, este X puede ser un coleccionable o una de las gemas necesarias para completar el nivel. El problema es que la cámara está limitada, no tienes completo control sobre ella imposibilitando así la visibilidad de lo que sucede por encima de ti. Es por esto que pueden darse momentos de frustración en los que no eres capaz de entender que será lo que te espera en lo alto de la montaña, muchos podrían sentir que su esfuerzo ha sido en vano al encontrarse un objeto innecesario tras un gran esfuerzo.

Como ya he dicho anteriormente, se necesitan unos gemas para terminar los niveles, están repartidas por el mapa como coleccionables y esto puede resultar en un jugador ignorándolas. Son obligatorias para terminar el nivel pero no para avanzar por él, un gran problema que exige mapas preparados para el backtracking y jugadores que se pierdan a dar todas las vueltas que necesiten. En caso de saltarte una gema u objeto coleccionable a la búsqueda del 100%, muchos zonas requerirán el reinicio de todo el nivel.

A pesar de no ser perfecto ni mucho menos, la jugabilidad interesante y su estilo artístico "cute" lo hacen una gran compra para todo jugador casual.

54965996.review: Un plataformas atípico y muy original, en el que en lugar de correr y saltar, solventaremos los obstáculos reptando y enrollándonos, al estilo de una serpiente. Es un juego encantador, muy bien hecho, con personajes carismáticos, y con un aire a la RARE de los 90 potenciado por la magnífica banda sonora junglesca del gran David Wise. Un gran inconveniente que puede echar para atrás a más de uno a la hora de empezar este juego es la curva de dificultad, que es peculiar. Al principio será muy alta por el hecho de que tendremos que acostumbrarnos a unas mecánicas y unos movimientos que no se han visto en otro juego y puede ser un tanto frustrante dominar. Eso sí, pronto le empezaremos a coger el truco y cuando lo hagamos, será una auténtica gozada solventar todos los obstáculos y puzles en forma de cañas por las que deberemos enrollarnos. Además tendremos la ayuda imprescindible de un colibrí que nos agarrará cuando pulsemos un botón. La curva de dificultad a partir de dominar los movimientos será muy adecuada, no suponiendo ninguno de los objetos a recoger una tarea imposible. En fin, un grandísimo juego para los que echamos de menos los antiguos plataformas y un soplo de aire fresco para un género en el que parecía que estaba todo inventado. Ojalá haya más entregas, el invento lo merece.

54698542.review:
Good wiggles, but with some niggles

Credit where it's due: Sumo Digital admirably mapped a snake to the physics and controls of a videogame. Snake Pass is very unique in terms of how it feels to control the player character, and I'm sure this was a welcome departure from their usual Sonic Racing titles.

Unfortunately, admirable doesn't mean flawless. Anyone familiar with snakes will find it confusing and irritating how the front 20% of your body weighs just as much as the rear 80%, and contains the vast majority of your gripping strength. Even using the "grip" button, I frequently found the rear half of the snakes body going completely limp in distinctly inconvenient situations. I think a "coil" button - where the rear half of the body firmly wraps itself around whatever is in reach - would have been far more useful, and probably more true to how real-life snakes behave.

Also, it's very strange how there's an achievement for completing every level without dying, but no indication of whether you've completed a given level without dying or not, or whether you've activated a totem for the relevant achievement. There's also no button for skipping cutscenes, even on subsequent playthroughs.

There's one more asterisk for my recommendation, which is that this is a snake-themed collectible game, not a collectible-themed snake game. If you don't like grabbing shinies, this game is not for you. 

All that said, did I still enjoy my time with Snake Pass? Sure. It was a good experience to develop an intuitive feel, if an imperfect one, of how snakes use leverage and friction to move. Likewise, it was interesting to look at obstacles and environments from the point of view of "what can I wrap around" instead of simply "what can I jump on." I collected all the collectibles (but not all of the achievements) in a little under 9 hours; I'll update this review if I 100% the game.

Recommended.

53998117.review:
Credit where it's due: Sumo Digital admirably mapped a snake to the physics and controls of a videogame. Snake Pass is very unique in terms of how it feels to control the player character, and I'm sure this was a welcome departure from their usual Sonic Racing titles.

Unfortunately, admirable doesn't mean flawless. Anyone familiar with snakes will find it confusing and irritating how the front 20% of your body weighs just as much as the rear 80%, and contains the vast majority of your gripping strength. Even using the "grip" button, I frequently found the rear half of the snakes body going completely limp in distinctly inconvenient situations. I think a "coil" button - where the rear half of the body firmly wraps itself around whatever is in reach - would have been far more useful, and probably more true to how real-life snakes behave.

Also, it's very strange how there's an achievement for completing every level without dying, but no indication of whether you've completed a given level without dying or not, or whether you've activated a totem for the relevant achievement. There's also no button for skipping cutscenes, even on subsequent playthroughs.

There's one more asterisk for my recommendation, which is that this is a snake-themed collectible game, not a collectible-themed snake game. If you don't like grabbing shinies, this game is not for you. 

All that said, did I still enjoy my time with Snake Pass? Sure. It was a good experience to develop an intuitive feel, if an imperfect one, of how snakes use leverage and friction to move. Likewise, it was interesting to look at obstacles and environments from the point of view of "what can I wrap around" instead of simply "what can I jump on." I collected all the collectibles (but not all of the achievements) in a little under 9 hours; I'll update this review if I 100% the game.

Recommended.

53747163.review:
Snake Pass is a fantastic twist on the platformer genre. It has great stylized visuals and a wonderfully unique design. You will likely struggle with the controls and camera at first but after the first few levels, you can easily begin to get a grasp on how to navigate the various obstacles Snake Pass will throw at you. The levels are well balanced when it comes to difficulty. I never felt bored with simple levels, yet I also never felt frustrated with down right unfair designs. The same can be said about the collectable location design. As long as you keep an eye out you can find all collectables by yourself. They are never placed awkwardly in downright obscure or out of bounds areas. Only once did I have to Google a location but that was my own fault as I had missed a lever in plain sight.

The game is relatively short and certainly could have done with maybe a handful more levels. However in saying that, too many levels and I get the feeling that it may have overstayed its welcome. For those that really enjoy the game there is also Arcade and Time Trial game modes. Lastly, while playing I couldn't help but feel that the game would have been even more fun if it had featured a level creator.

Overall Snake Pass is a wonderful title that I would recommend to anyone looking for something unique. It has great design, art and music. With its only small downfalls being a sometimes awkward camera, shortish playtime and sadly no level creator.

Rating: 8.5/10

This game is worth picking up for the movement mechanics alone. Gameplay largely revolves around navigating a snake through obstacles, often by climbing. Not sure about kb/m, but with a controller it's very intuitive and ... snakey. Getting the hang of climbing well is really interesting and fun. 

However, the game seems to falter later on. The locations are very similar, although there are some pallette swaps. The main problem is that almost every level mainly involves climbing on bamboo. The game throws in a few changes: switches moving portions, very minor puzzle solving. But after you've completed 8 or so levels you really aren't going to see anything new and exciting. 

The game does work well as an exploration game. You are mainly finding 3 different kinds of collectibles at increasing difficulty. Some are right on your path, but others can be hidden quite well. So, if you really like investigating every nook and cranny of a 3d area, this part doesn't disappoint.

50240259.review:
Amazing idea with too many mistakes in execution.

The locomotion in this game is fascinating and unique. On the surface it comes off as one of those obtuse games that are hard to control just for the sake of being hard to control. I do not like those type of games. The challenges feel artificial and while the controls can be mastered of course, they ultimately hinge themselves on sliding scale of random luck that you can only hope to narrow. Snake Pass ISN'T one of "those games" though. The locomotion is actually perfectly reasonable, logical, and fair. It's just new, and there's a learning curve. However. There are simply too many so-called quality of life oversights to ignore...

The most obvious being the checkpoint system. While I can actually excuse this for the sake of added difficulty. It simply does not lend itself to a game that has this many obstacles and slow deaths. Your mistakes build slowly. Your deaths come in animated falls that take a handful of seconds. And your movement to get back to where you failed is slow and tedious. That being said, the level design doesn't really leave many other options. So, it's downright awful. But I don't know what the solution would be. I'd have gladly taken something like a life system with a "last location on solid ground" instant-respawn, for even just two or three lives between respawn checkpoint continues. Or even just a button to instant-respawn when you know you've failed. Anything for a slight bit of relief. It's just too painful and slow. 

This pain is compounded by the game being a collectable game. If these were just "trials" without collectables? A lot of this quality of life stuff could be overlooked. But there is indeed collectables. One to beat the level. And two more just because. And going for these just makes the design mistakes stand out more than they deserve. Which brings me to the camera; For a game with hard to master controls and countless obstacles to overcome you will still somehow end up blaming the camera for well over 50% of your deaths. This is insane. It starts far too zoomed in by default. It is sometimes sensitive to landscape objects and other times not. And worst of all, your character control directions are locked to the orientation of the camera at any given moment. Nothing harder than trying to coil yourself around a pole as the camera moves and with it so changes your needed inputs. Again, I don't know what the solution is. I would've at least liked to have been able to have the option for direction inputs locked to snake direction rather than camera to see if it is a better option. Or an option to lock the camera in place during an obstacle. Maybe they would've been worse, but I have a hard time believing this was the best camera/inputdirection option. Another small thing was unskippable cutscenes. There's things to collect, I'm going to revisit the level, lemme skip the story part this go around. 

I found myself uninstalling the game once I realized I wasn't going to 100% the collectables without breaking a controller. I'm a decade or two past that phase and would like to keep it that way. "I'm too old for this shi..." I will perhaps revisit and just play it to beat each level without collecting everything as I really really really enjoyed the concept at the core of the game. The truly fascinating, new, inventive, locomotion was really fun. But this needed a lot more time in the oven. I don't even know if challenge/obstacle/puzzle is the right direction in the first place. I'd love to play with this snake in an open world with similarly difficult collectables parts, but some sort of other objective. Enemies, stealth, eating eggs/rodents? Or something. It just isn't quite there as a puzzle game. Which is another thing it is missing; Workshop/modding support. But oh well. Maybe in a bundle, or if you're of the more patient variety than it turns out I am.

48660059.review:
9/10

This game RULES, it's the most inventive "platformer" game I've played in years. It's fun to pretend I'm a snake. The controls are almost perfect, it becomes super intuitive, and the levels are usually designed extremely well. Extremely polished, both in graphics and gameplay. I've experienced no bugs thus far at all. The closest thing to a bug I've experienced was tying myself in a knot and getting myself stuck to the pole (which really just shows how great the physics are honestly)

Little pro tips for new players:
- Gravity is super lenient, and you can fly over most obstacles with it, and just slither over poles and stuff without bothering to coil and grip. Basically, once you have the hang of it, you can get way more reckless than you think you can, and it's super fun
- If you corkscrew upwards you have more structure and you can raise your head higher
--- In combination with the above, you can slither up walls a little much like you slither on the ground, allowing you to climb walls MUCH higher than you think (at its best you can use this to skip parts of the level, at its worst it's fun and can give you a vantage point to look for things you missed)

Some gripes I have:
- Can't change keybinds. Mostly this is fine because the controls are good (I'm on controller) but you can't move the camera and use a face button at the same time
- The above is a problem because the camera moves on its own if the snake moves, and this can get you killed by obscuring your vision while you're moving over a dangerous spot
- Your snake head is gigantic, and some poles are too close together to fit your head through vertically. This isn't objectively an issue, but it has gotten me killed 3 or 4 times, which was kind of annoying
- Some orbs are a huge pain in the keister to find. Too well hidden orbs means backtracking, which is super slow in a game where you literally have to slither around with no limbs
- Cutscenes are completely unskippable in the main playthrough. In time trials and arcade they're disabled, but in the main game you're better off getting everything in the level in one go, so you don't have to go back and watch the cutscene again

Keep in mind none of the above really make the game much less fun overall. It might mean the difference between a 9.5 and a 9 out of 10, and really none of it should influence your decision to buy the game

In the platforming world, just about everything that can be done has been done. "Snake Pass" is a rare exception.

While initially cumbersome to work with, the controls (roughly 90% of the challenge of the game) slowly become easier to work with over time. Most levels consist of coiling, snaking, and climbing around things while holding on for dear life.

One of only two games I've played where the camera actively tries to kill you, either by spuriously swinging around, occluding the snake from view, or bouncing like a manic terrier, especially when working in confined spaces. If you can survive slithering in and out of a hazardous narrow passage on the first attempt, the camera hasn't done its job.

Having said all of this, the game is bright, polished, and--without a doubt--unique. A thumbs up from me, if just barely.

You play as a cute snek with a birb buddy, that's all you need.

But for real, got interested right away on the game with the whole concept of a 'platformer' without being able to move, run and jump like most characters of this genre do (which I love).
When I played it at first learning the controls was a bit slow and clunky, but oh man, once you get the hang of it and set your mind on the fact you are snake and move as one it's super rewarding seeing yourself moving around levels quickly and going through crazy obstacles to get all the collectables!

The whole design of the game with it's cartoony graphics, characters, soundtrack and levels also help a lot to enjoy the gameplay, it's such a joy to play and explore around when everything looks SO GOOD AND FUN, that's super important in a platformer.

I think the only downsides I can think of is the unskippable cutscenes (I get it when you play it the first time, but when you wanna replay it several times it can get very annoying, at least it's only in very few levels) and the game can start feeling a bit repetitive, though the different level designs and obstacles does help, wish we could interact with some NPCs or even have some sort of enemies we would have to deal using our movement and enviroment to add some even more challenge.

Overall I really had fun with this game and hope to see something more with it in the future, however this game might not be for everyone especially if you don't like the idea of being forced to have limited/restricted movement and having to adapt from it, though for others like me it's an interesting and challenging twist on platforming.
(Still really helps that you play as a really cute goofy snake that has a very cute bird friend)

45826348.review:
Snake Pass is an interesting case of a game.  Some love it while others hate it for one particular reason: The controls.  I love the controls, personally.  But why are they so controversial?  

You know those board games where you need to learn the ins and outs of things before you can fully enjoy them?  Well, Snake Pass is like that in video game form.  The controls are simple in concept, but very, very hard to master.  Some might even call the controls unwieldy.  But this is not fair.  Snake Pass demands much of the player, but rewards the player brilliantly as they tackle tasks they didn't know whether or not they could complete.  

Snake Pass can be a bit of a long game, according to skill level.  Mine is probably somewhere in the middle.  I haven't completed the first world yet, and there's so much more to go. 

If you have this game from Humble Bundle a while back, please, give it a try!  Its uniqueness makes it a game worth experiencing.

45799509.review:
While the game looks great, has a fantastic soundtrack by none other than Donkey Kong series composer David Wise and has its memorable moments, most of that is kinda ruined though by a clunky camera and equally clunky and hard to get used to controls.
It took me all the way through the earth levels to get used to the controls and even then I still had trouble navigating the worlds. Movement seems to be all over the place. One time you slither at light speed, and other times it seems Noodle can't get off the spot no matter how hard you ravish that right stick. Combine that with the fact that every object (no matter how small) has a tangible hitbox, which makes it very easy to get stuck on all the decorative objects like twigs and stones and you have a formula for disaster.
But the worst thing about this game, and the worst thing in the history of all 3D games in my opinion, is the camera. Remember the old days of early 3D games in the N64 era, how much you wanted to hurt someone because the camera was so bad? In this game you'll have those feelings again, but three times as much. The camera gets stuck behind objects, you loose sight because something gets in the way (most often decorative foliage), objects between you and the camera make the camera instantly zoom in even though there clearly is enough space and sight, not being able to zoom in or out at times and the camera not auto-adjusting to help you in certain situations (like going with you around corners while climbing a wall) but will do so at other times where it seems to be totally unnecessary and then won't budge no matter how much you want it to move.
Wanna look around for that one object you missed? Too bad, 20 seconds later your bird friend constantly gets in your way if you haven't moved in a while. It's a cute mechanic for when you are not there, Noodle asleep and the camera frozen, but please for the love of god don't block my sight WHILE I'M MOVING THE CAMERA trying to figure out where that one coin is I've missed.
Speaking of the bird, his tail grab seems to work only when he feels like it. At least five times during my playthrough I clearly heard Noodle whistle but the Bird wouldn't help me, resulting in death.
There could have also been more control options. I've found that pressing the left stick instead of Y to call the bird for help avoids situations where you are already pressing the A button to avoid falling (had to press Y with my chin then), and having the camera zoom in and out by pressing the right stick (the stick that moves the camera in the first place) works much better. I've rebound those keys with DS4Windows for my PS4 controller, but it would've been nice to have those controls available from the start or even being able to individually rebind each function in the game to your liking for people that don't have these tools.

But that's it for my complains, and there's enough that I nonetheless still love about the game.
For one the amazing soundtrack by David Wise, with every track fitting the style of each world perfectly. I think the music alone was the reason I continued to torture myself with the controls and camera, as well as the outstanding look of the game, making great use of the Unreal Engine 4 to make it look like a Pixar movie. And the way Noodle is animated, with the option to give him different facial expressions for different situations made the game rather charming. I stuck to one facial expression through the whole game though, and that was the one you get when you slightly press D-Pad down, giving Noodle that look like he's about to cry, a look of constant fear, sadness, depression and suffering, because I thought all he wanted was to sleep and relax in the sun but bird buddy has him make do all these deadly tasks for his enjoyment and to (rather cliché) "save the world". And because of the camera.

Now the question: Would I recommend this game? If you've played 3D platformers in the past and are used to horrible cameras and are generally a fan of the genre then yes, definitely. If not then it's up to you if you feel up to the challenge of constantly fighting with the camera and trying to get a hang of the controls all while enjoying the great music and sceneries.

[h1]Played with a controller[/h1]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Amazing graphics design
- Great soundtrack by David Wise

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Worst camera of any 3D game I have ever played
- Controls are clunky and hard to learn
- Cutscenes can't be skipped even when playing a level for a second time

[h1]Room for improvement:[/h1]
- More control schemes or the ability to individually map each button
- Make it visible on the level select screen that the left stick can change between domains (I noticed that very late while I was already in the wind domain and expected LB/RB to do it)
- Improved camera (objects fading out of view; small objects not affecting the camera; automatic camera adjustments around corners and other tricky spots but with the ability to still move the camera to your liking)

[h1]Overall:[/h1]
☐ 5/5 (Great)
☐ 4/5 (Good)
☑ [u]3/5 (Okay)[/u]
☐ 2/5 (Bad)
☐ 1/5 (Terrible)

45713524.review:
I had a lot of fun with this game. Although at first, I did make the mistake of assuming that this game was fast-paced. It isn't. Most platforming games require quick thinking and fast reflexes. Snake Pass is more of a thoughtful, slow platformer. It still requires dexterity, but it wants you to think about how you're going to move Noodle.

There's a bit of a learning curve for it, but once you get the hang of it, it's very rewarding. Controlling Noodle really makes you feel like a snake. When you achieve a tricky maneuver, you feel accomplished.

I did have a few gripes, mostly nothing to do with the movement system. First of all, collectibles don't do anything except unlock a skin once the game is finished. And by then, there's no reason to play anymore - the collectibles don't respawn when you restart a level. Noodle also doesn't get any new abilities or access to new mechanics as the game progresses.

The 'grip' button does f*** all as well. I never used it once.

And the plot? Pick up a book written for 4 year olds. That's the plot.

You're playing this game for the challenge, and the challenge alone. Then the game is finished and you beat the challenge. And it's not an overly long game either.

I still recommend it. It's simple but fun.

I also recommend using a controller. I have no idea what it's like to play it on keyboard, but considering some of the maneuvers I was doing, it must be uncomfortable.

44623246.review:
Snake Pass introduces intuitive, unique and yet easy to learn controls that you master throughout the game's 15 levels. This game has a very simple story and can be played both by adults and children alike. There are no puzzling things to solve, this game is solely about platforming and dancing with the controls.

People who want more laidback challenge can only collect three required portal gem stones to complete a level. Those who want more challenge can try to collect all the water bubbles, or those who want the most challenge can try to collect the bubbles and all the gold coins. I have to warn you though, if you only collect the gemstones, the experience will most likely feel very short. You can always return to previous levels to collect everything possible if you wish so.

Kids can play this game and try to collect as many things as they can or just pass levels. There will surely be enough challenge for elementary school kids or a year or two lower aged children. For a long time gamer like me, collecting everything possible was an actual challenge. There is still a time trial mode to be had and an arcade mode, where you try to collect as many fruits as possible under a time limit and can compare your score to other players online.

This game utilizes Unreal Engine 4, which makes the graphics look very pleasant, though a fair warning: this game has an FPS lock of 62. Audiowork is fine and musics are quite melodic and catchy, very fitting to the theme. All in all this game is well executed.

I can confidently recommend this game to anyone who seeks for an enjoyable platforming game. Paying 20 € didn't feel much to me for a quality title like this.

44297746.review:
[h1]Snake Pass.

Frustrating yet rewarding, Snake Pass challenges players to overcome 3D platforming obstacles, collect the necessary unlock mechanisms, and pass from island to island by guiding Noodle the snake, always affectionately assisted by Doodle the hummingbird.[/h1]

I adore this game!

The controls are intuitive but take a little time to grow accustomed to, and I seriously recommend using a controller, (the joystick is a blessing when wrapping your mind around gravity vs Noodle's muscle control and using strength to your advantage.) Consistent, persistent practice really helps with surpassing many of the obstacles, eventually, you'll be climbing your way to victory, and hypnotically swaying through streams with the elegance and grace of a synchronised swimmer.

There's a nice variety in a challenge with collectables providing a couple of extra hours playtime, and semi-regular respawn points scattered throughout each level. These are very handy, especially around rickety ladders, steep declining edges, or moving pedestals and really tones down the frustration if you fail to grip correctly and fall.  

Beautiful graphics and fresh, vibrant colours help to deliver an interesting environment to explore; lush terrain, waterlogged temples and acrid, fiery biomes. The camera, while not brilliant, didn't pose too many problems for me. It's just something else you grow used to as you progress, and I suffered no motion sickness problems.

I really hope Sumo Digital decides on a sequel. It would be an immediate purchase for me and I'm quite interested to see their future creations. Highly recommend to -patient- players who seek an unusual platforming challenge, yet unsuitable for very young children or players who seek quick completion as it requires high amounts of concentration, patience and natural ability to complete levels, especially if you want maximum scores. Totally worth the store price, and a must for nostalgic original Playstation games fans.

44172698.review: Muy buen juego de plataformas/puzzle. Los controles son un poco complicados al principio y la cámara a veces juega malas pasadas, pero Snake Pass es divertido, colorido, entrañable y con un montón de elementos para descubrir en cada nivel. Lo recomiendo.

44076202.review:
(If you want a quick sum up, there's a lil' pros/cons at the end of the review).

Snake Pass was one of the best surprises I had recently. Initially, what made me wishlist it instantly was that it reminded me a lot of JUJU, that I really enjoyed. I wasn't disappointed. 

The story: in a world made of floating realms, Noodle the snake and his pal Doodle the bird set out to repair a series of portals which serve as access between the various islands. The portals have all been mysteriously looted and made unusable...
The game is what it is advertised to be: a kind of family friendly platformer. But beyond this central concept, the whole thing is rather original and absolutely lovely on all levels.

[u] The visuals [/u] 

     I thought from the previews that the graphism and overall aesthetics were really nice, and indeed they are, even more so than I thought. It is incredibly colorful, but what's truly amazing is how lively the world/realms feel: every bit of the platforms is detailed, part of the flora moves softly, and there are several little critters that come and go and react to your presence. From beginning to end, you evolve in charming and varied maps, full of life. 
     Also, the two main characters, Noodle the snake and Doodle the bird, are equally lively and colorful, especially Noodle: with a contagious smile by default, he reacts to finding items, to holding tight, to loosing balance or grip and to being lifted by Doodle. He also falls asleep if you don't make him move for a little while. On a side note, he has a pannel of four available expressions, but, personaly, I couldn't part with his basic smile. These two are easily some of the cutest characters I've seen in a game.

[u] The gameplay [/u]

     As you would expect considering the genre Snake Pass belongs to, you gather items in a series of levels in order to access the next one. Most of the items are what I would call collectibles, but to me exploring every corner to find them all is really a big part of the fun, otherwise the game looses in length and interest. 
The true originality is that the whole gameplay evolves around playing and feeling like a snake, which Snake Pass does wonderfully. You must alternate left and right to make Noodle move forward efficiently (the better the faster), its slithery body is fast on even ground and in water, can turn in all manners to grab a structure or pull himself up (he can actually climb higher on his own than you'd think at first...)... 
     That's where the difficulty also comes from. Noodle won't hold onto something automatically, so you have to be constantly aware of what you're doing as soon as you're not just slithering on plain ground. This results in an almost constant play between physics and dexterity (the Unreal Engine does its job very well in this case, although probably not in the most realistic way, but I don't mind). In that regard, you also have to work with Doodle, who's always there to grab Noodle by the tail to help him compensate his weight depending on the situation. You will also need to make good use of the 360° camera, not an easy feat as well. Be warned, these mechanics can be [b] incredibly difficult and frustrating [/b] to master/apply, and it drove me mad several times. You will have to go through quite a lot of trials and errors before you succeed. I was fine with it because I like challenges in games and I have a lot of patience, but I'd tend to say it's not for everyone. That said, difficulty is well balanced overall, with a good number of rather well placed checkpoints on each map, which also save whatever items you found prior to activating them.
     To finish with, there are four realms to explore, each corresponding to one element. You start with earth (meaning jungle), then continue with water, fire and finally air. First level for each is an easy map, which allows for a rather peaceful discovery of the element, and for Doodle to brief you on new obstacles and mechanisms. Difficulty increases with each level but also with each realm, the fire and air ones being very hard. The latter adds its own mechanics to the gameplay. Each realm is quite unique, and never did I feel like I was doing twice the same level.  

[u] Sound [/u]

     Though there isn't much to say about the overall audio in Snake Pass, it's worth mentionning that just as for the visuals, a lot of care went to the sounds. Noodle's slithering and hissing, Doodle's wings flapping, the critters movements/reactions, the grass, the plants, the wind, the fire... All these also make for a lively environement that you take pleasure to evolve in.
     The music is also lovely. Mostly soothing, there's one for each realm, evocking each element adequately. 


[h1] In short [/h1] 

[u] Pros [/u]
- carefully crafted and light hearted indie platformer
- lovely details and atmosphere
- varied realms and overall game design
- cute as hell characters
- original gameplay; think and act like a snake
- progressive difficulty
- fun item hunting

[u] Cons [/u]
- frustrating at times, requires lots of patience through trial and error; I really liked it but definitely not for everyone.
- interest and length rest on gathering all collectible items
- minor audio bugs with moving platforms
- don't even think about keyboard, you absolutely [i] need [/i] an Xbox controller to play (I actually bought my first one because of this game).

43896761.review:
If Snake Pass was just ten percent easier to control, it would have gone down in 3d platformer history as an instant classic. It’s unfortunate that in my time with Snake Pass I never quite got over some of the movement controls due to a combination of a tricky camera system and a steep difficulty curve. I never really figured out how to efficiently move through the levels. I had the most difficulty when climbing ladders, especially when trying to use the grip button.

Ignoring my frustrations with the platforming, the game really does a lot to impress me with its lovingly crafted worlds filled with detail and personality. I pray that some day there is a Snake Pass 2 that can rectify some of the base issues with the game’s vertical movements. Sumo Digital took a helluva risk by putting such a strange control scheme front and center in their game, and should be commended for the bold move. Snake Pass is an absolutely fun game! I originally found it browsing tumblr and was super interested since.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
The core mechanic of Snake Pass is the way you control snakey boi and it works very very well! I highly recommend playing with a controller as that is what the developers recommend and the controller controls just feel more tight. One thing to keep in mind with the controls however is that they are hard. This game is not sunshine and lollipops, Snake Pass will make you hurt and hold your soul in it's scaly hands. You have to put effort in learning how to move and taking the time you need to figure out how to get through a puzzle. Once you master the movement this game feels so rewarding. There are difficult levels but once you get through them you feel like a god among sneks.
The added point challenges are also fun.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
I was disappointed to find little story to this game. I was hoping for more but I love story. It's not a big issue at all, the game's enjoyment more then makes up for it. The last area of the game also didn't feel as hard as the previous world. Almost like the two should of been switched to really make the end more rewarding.

[h1]Overall/tldr[/h1]
I love Snake Pass and recommend it to anyone looking for a challenge in the 3D platformer genre. Just remember, it's hard to get the movement down but once you do it's so worth it.

43112218.review:
Snake Pass is an extremely unique, physics-based platformer with a vibrant, saturated color scheme, excellent visuals, a finely crafted soundtrack composed by none other than David Wise (responsible for the "Stickerbrush Symphony" track in Nintendo's Donkey Kong Country 2 video game), and features cleverly contrived controls for the snake's movements.

Firstly, I would like to express that I think Sumo Digital has done an amazing job in creating something that is outside of the ordinary for the average level-based 3D platformer genre. What we have here is a very unique game that demonstrates very creative/very skilled utilization of Unreal Engine 4. It may be to some people's surprise that Snake Pass is actually a very hardware-demanding game--this is primarily because of the fact that Noodle--the protagonist snake you control--has a body comprised of highly reactive, fine-tuned geometry that entirely obeys the laws of physics inside the game's engine; from head to tail, the snake is wholely reactive to every surface and object it contacts in a realistic manner. In addition to this, varying friction upon different surfaces, reactive water, caustic lighting effects, and reactive foliage (grass) all will give your computer's hardware a run for its money. Considering these demanding hurdles, the port for PC is very well done.

The art style featured in Snake Pass offers a vivacious palette of colors, and appears in a cartoon-esque fashion. The visual effects of much of the environment look very good, like the reactivity on the surface of bodies of water that pertains to the movement and forces of Noodle. Also, the way the bamboo has a reflective sheen to it, and how bodies of water produce a caustic effect and showcase light refraction are great examples of this game's pleasing eye candy that truly shows how much effort went into the display of the game's image.

The control scheme for Snake Pass was constructed in a clever way for the player (I STRONGLY recommend using a gamepad controller). Although it might not seem like it at the beginning and the first few hours may be a bit frustrating, so long as you are patient and make a genuine effort, you will likely become significantly more efficient and skillful in controlling Noodle. Wrapping the snake's body around objects, coiling, and gripping are crucial maneuvers for Snake Pass, which the game will gradually teach you.

The soundtrack of Snake Pass is phenomenal. David Wise--who composed the widely renowned and critically acclaimed Stickerbrush Symphony track for Nintendo--is responsible for Snake Pass's music as well. The music of the game accomplishes an exceptional combination of tones during your slithering exploration. The tracks create a sense of relaxation, but at the same time, they also deliver the feeling of a mission that needs completing. The game's music makes use of a very unique blend of string, air, soft percussion instruments, and even a xylophone. In my opinion, the music is not only fantastic-sounding in a right of its own, but it suits the style, feel, and setting of the game impeccably. The music in Snake Pass breathes effervescent life into its atmosphere.

Snake Pass will offer you a remarkable visual experience, a bubbly, enthusiastic soundtrack, an extraordinarily unique take on 3D platforming, and controls that are more than aptly suited for the gameplay (and will require some learning).

TL;DR
- A wonderful and imaginative 3D platforming game
- Impressively polished 3D visual assets and visual effects
- Marvelous soundtrack composed by David Wise (composer of Stickerbrush Symphony)
- A commendable, well-optimized port for PC
- Excellent work, Sumo Digital

UPDATE (11/21/18): I nominated this game for the "Best Envrionment" Award for the 2018 Steam Awards because the atmosphere that the developers created for this game is unique, serene, and deserves recognition.

Beautiful graphics, innovative mechanics, great level design, and pretty enjoyable gameplay. I highly, highly recommend Snake Pass for people who enjoy a new take on platformer.

It's very refreshing to have a slow and precise platformer like this (so, the Dark Souls of platformer?). Instead of relying on your reflex and timing, you're asked to understand how the movement works and how to best navigate the terrain. The movement is very physics-based, where moving platform actually has effect on you instead of just moving you around. And albeit the game only has 15 levels, on average each level takes around 30-40 minutes to complete if you're gunning for all collectibles, so it doesn't feel short at all.

My only gripe with the game is that some time it's quite frustrating to die at the same spot over and over again, mainly because of the lenghty die and revive animation. But that's pretty minor I'd say.

Snake Pass is delightful. It's somewhat a puzzle platformer, but without jumping and all the puzzles have to do with being a snake. The main game is fairly short, but it took a bit longer to collect all the hidden collectibles. Controlling the snake feels generally good, but it takes some getting used to. I ended up playing on keyboard because controlling the camera with the mouse is just the only way to not go crazy. 

The good:

+ Unique concept - I've never played a game quite like this before and I love the concept.

+ Great soundtrack - David Wise, 'nuff said.

+ Challenging - How am I supposed to get that? What? You're crazy.

+ Cute - Noodle is adorable and has controllable facial expressions


The bad:

- Camera - Oh gosh, the camera. Sometimes it has a mind of its own and you will lose track 
  of where you are, uncoil and fall. 

- Unskippable cutscenes - This was fine on my first time through, but in revisiting levels to get 
  collectibles I missed, this was minorly annoying.

- Physics on moving platforms - Riding anything that moves in the game will eventually cause  you to unwind and fall just because of the weird jostling physics tricking the snake into 
  thinking he's falling. This was only really frustrating in a few spots, but it definitely was frustrating.

Overall, I adored this game and had a really fun time playing it. I would love to have a few more levels to snake through.
