42074365.review:
Imagine Mario 64 or Banjo-Kazooie, but with a snake, and you'll have a pretty good idea of what Snake Pass is like. The gameplay is all about learning the mechanics of the snake, like slithering, coiling around things, making wild low-gravity leaps between platforms, standing straight upwards on your tail, and exploiting the hell out of level geometry.

The controls are, expectedly, a bit unintuitive at first, but once you get the feel for them it becomes a lot of fun to just move around in the game. There are 15 levels across 4 worlds themed in the classic Earth, Water, Fire, and Wind, and you're tasked with collecting 3 GemGuffins in each to open the next with the option of collecting a bunch of doodads and 5 bitcoins for some extra challenge. I didn't think most of the game was very challenging, even with collecting all the things, but I also didn't feel that made it any less enjoyable except on a few levels where finding the last whatsit was an exercise in tedium.

The villain of the game is the camera. It has a physical presence in the world, so it collides with and is pushed around by level geometry. Worse, the controls are oriented based on the camera's positioning, so when working in tight spaces or on moving objects the camera will often hit a wall and change position suddenly, so now not only might you not be able to see what you're doing, you'll also be pushing in an unintended direction.

Another big issue with the game is that it seems like they realized it wasn't super challenging, so decided to pile 80% of the frustration into the last 2 levels. I'm not sure I'd even recommend playing those, honestly.

Overall though, an enjoyable experience.

41670681.review:
Incredibly fun, and frustrating unique platformer.

This game comes closer to emulating the challenge of real life climbing than any other. Which is weird since you play a snake in it. But unlike other games that have you press a contextual button when it flashes up on screen, or at best give you a challenge that can be easily beat once you have the timing down, Snake Pass recreated that sweaty-palm feeling of “Can I reach that next ledge?” and the subsequent breathless moment when you let go and hope you can reach it and hold on. 

It takes some getting used to, but the controls are very well done and fluid. The game recommends a controller and I’ll second that recommendation. You control the snake’s head with left stick and A button, then move the body forward with the left Trigger. To move, you need to slither back and forth like a snake and to climb, you have to wrap yourself around poles and other objects, then stretch out to the next pole or ledge. It’s extremely hard at times, but also a lot of fun and steamy satisfying to finally reach the gold coin that you spent 10 minutes trying to get.

At 9 hours, I’m about 2/3rds through the game, but probably won’t make it much farther. Like I said, the game is frustrating at times, and the save system doesn’t help. You can’t save and quit in a level without losing all your progress, which means you have to dedicate yourself to seeing a level all the way through before sitting down. The levels themselves aren’t that hard; the biggest and most punishing challenges are the 5 gold coins in each level, which are purely optional. Still, it’s hard to commit to finishing a level and dying repeatedly in the attempt when all I want to do is unwind for a few minutes. 

Mid-level save points are occasionally frustrating too. I get why the game doesn’t count the coins and water bubbles you pick up after you die, otherwise you could just suicide jump for difficult coins and skip half the challenge of getting back safely. But the save spots are few and far between. Sometimes I’ll see a coin in an impossible place, but haven’t saved recently. Rather than risking my progress so far, I head forward to the next save spot, then backtrack to the coin. It breaks up the flow, and could have been fixed by just making any flat and “safe” terrain a save spot. 

Even though I didn’t finish the game, it wasn’t boredom or frustration that made me put it down. I still recommend this game to anyone curious about the premise and open to a challenge.

41441217.review:
Snake Pass is a game I saw on Snoman Games as a sign of good design along with Nier Automata, Hollow Knight, and Tumbleseed.  This list is a mixed bag of one game I like, one game I dislike and one I haven’t been able to play.  However Snake Pass is definitely a shining example of game design, and in fact great gameplay all over. 

Snake Pass clearly has its roots in the classic 3D platformers.  Its art style reminds me of Banjo Kazooie and Yooka Laylee instantly, but where I feel like Yooka Laylee didn’t bring enough new to the table, Snake Pass may have brought too much new gameplay, and I’m not actually angry about that. 

The core of this game is a story about a Snake named Noodle and a Bird named Doodle, called Snake and Bird for the rest of this review, as the names are a bit silly and didn’t make a strong impression on me.  They explore levels to find out why bad things are happening in the forest, and the truth of this is, I played the game two weeks ago and don’t remember the story that much, though I do remember the story being weak.  In my notes, the only mention of the story is the fact the entire story is really told in the last cutscene and ends what could be a cliffhanger (an unnecessary one). 

On the other hand, Snake and Bird are freaking adorable. While Bird is a good looking character, Snake is adorable, as you can see here: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1322964944

The player is given the four d-pad directions to change his face similar to how Little Big Planet does it.  While Snake faces away from the camera for most of the game, I can’t help but enjoy how great the facial animations are.  The characters are great looking and the levels are gorgeous.

However there is no voice acting and while most of the game doesn’t require it, the small cutscenes there are use a noise generation similar to Banjo Kazooie, and it works, but it’s just a touch annoying, though used far less than Yooka Laylee.

Now we get to the gameplay and this is where Snake Pass shines.  Snake Pass has the player play the Snake and slither around.  Instead of moving in a specific direction, the player is able to move faster by shifting back and forth, it’s a bit of the defining feature of the game.  Some people hate the repetition and some people love the feeling, and while in the first level or two I found it a bit annoying, I got used to the motion and I adore the unique feeling of traversing the levels.  I felt like a snake, and I realized that’s not a character type that I typically have played in a game.  This game feels fresh to me. 

Since you’re a Snake you’re forced to think like one.  You don’t have a normal jump, but you are able to slither up poles and objects, going from one limb to another and curling your long body around them to rise up and climb.  From there you can extend yourself out and reach other objects, slither along beams, or grab onto rotating platforms.  Each is required to beat the game and each one works quite well once you get a handle on it. 

I find it hard to really compare this to another game.  This isn’t Yooka Laylee which is like Banjo Kazooie.  It is a really unique system where the goal is to support your body as you reach out to your next objective, whether it be a platform or a collectible (more on those in a bit).  You’re able to grip whatever you are curled upon and then arch your body over to the next target.

The maneuverability of the snake is absolutely fantastic.  I love that reach, and the feeling that sometimes I just needed an extra inch, which would require me to arch out an extra inch and lose the valuable grip, that required me to make a last-ditch effort to make the move I wanted, it mostly worked.  A few times I felt like I was cheesing the system by getting just my head up the wall and then somehow gimmicking my body back on solid ground. 

Then again other times I felt the system “broke” in just the right way.  The player isn’t able to jump, he’s only able to raise his head, however, there were places which required the snake to reach out and make the right move or curl up on a specific object I didn’t care to try.  So I tried to fling myself off one end of a log and was able to almost throw myself to the next object.  This is a bit of a rare occurrence but the fact is the snake almost jumped in the air and I was able to make these great awkward leaps work.  I’m sure speed runners will use them to great effect but just playing it myself I loved the feeling of the motion. 

Of course, there was a reason I had to jump, there are a number of manners of “death” in the game, and they’re all about the same, whether it be a never ending pit that surrounds islands, spikes, lava or being crushed, the adventure is never without peril.  While the danger rises sharply for the second half of the adventure, the snake never seems to be completely outmatched and almost every death feels like a failure of the player rather than a cheap unavoidable death.  There are checkpoints and the checkpoints are able to be hit multiple times in a row, so collecting an object and then returning to safety allows the player to grab a checkpoint again to save the progress made as a nice touch. 

I mentioned collectibles before, they are quite a task for players to tackle.  Each level requires three objects the player has to grab to exit a level.  There are also twenty bubbles and five gold coins per level.  The bubbles and coins are the main collectibles with the bubbles mostly being on the main path most of the time and the coins usually requiring some extra work.

Players can spend a lot of time to find them and I collected them all for the first five levels, but then gave up as I heard there is an item after you beat the game that makes it far easier to find all the collectibles, and it does.  Sadly it also requires you to replay all the levels which are fun, but I feel lacks some of the novelty of the first playthrough.

The grip in the game is a special annoyance for me, half the time it feels like it doesn’t work at all, that I slip a little too much, and half the time, I feel like I’m stuck fast to the object I’m curled around.  Part of it is that it seems to only increase your coefficient of friction, so the more you’re coiled the better it is, but if you need an extra inch or two, it’s hard to get that without losing all your grip.  This is the real challenge of the game, and you have to learn how to deal with grip versus slip.  I just wish it was a little more consistent or at least had a gauge so I knew how much grip I could have.

There are fifteen levels in the game, and the first 8 levels are pretty easy, but the last half and especially the last four levels are real beasts where all of these features come in to challenge the player.  But it’s a challenge I enjoyed because it took all the skills I had gained in the game and had to combine them to conquer the last few levels.  For those levels, I felt that I actually accomplished something grand when I beat a level.

Ultimately, I like Snake Pass.  I think the game design is something special.  It hasn’t perfected the movement but it’s unique enough for me to take notice.  The music, which is not something I normally talk about, was bright and cheery in all the right ways.  Thank you, David Wise, the famous composer of almost everything Donkey Kong and a ton more.

So yes I recommend Snake Pass, it’s a great game and really charming.  You will have to get used to being a snake, but once you have mastered the feel, the entire game feels really novel and special.  Moving from object to object is fluid and there is just something about this game that makes me smile just from the style alone.

If you enjoyed this review or want to see what other games I enjoyed you can find my curator page at this link. http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/ Give me a follow.

41411443.review:
SNAKE PASS

Game Difficulty: 3/10
Story Completion: 7-10 hours
Story Rating: 2/10*
Gameplay Rating: 9/10
Soundtrack: 8/10
Achievement Difficulty: 4/10
Estimated 100% Time: 10-15 hours
Reccomended Play Experience: Play through each level twice (or once if possible) before moving onto the next: One time without dying and another for getting all the collectibles.
Overall Rating: 8/10
Overall Impression: A unique and charming take on the stagnant platforming genre. Simple and well designed levels with a focus on fun gameplay above all else. If you like any kind of platformers but have gotten bored with playing the same ones absolutely give this a go.

STORY
-------
You play as Noodle (the Snake) and Doodle (his Hummigbird companion). One day, Doodle sets upon a disaster. The keystones that allow animals to travel throughout the world using portals have all been scattered around by something! As Noodle you have to traverse his home, finding and placing the keystones back into the portals and find out why the keystones have all been left lying around!

*Note that I didn't factor the story into the review score. The story is nothing more than a reason to go forward. Most of the game the story is forgotten and it's nothing more than a filler.

GAMEPLAY
----------
Playing as a snake obviously means you can't jump, so then how exactly do you play a game as a snake? Using a controller i'll give a rundown of the controls:

Left Stick: Look
Right Stick: Camera
Right Trigger: Go Forward
A: Raise Head (Go up in water, X is to dive down)
LT: Grip
Y: Use Doodle To Lift Tail

Holding RT moves you in the direction your head is facing (controlled with LS). However moving in a straight line is VERY slow. In order to move faster you have to move the LS left and right while moving to "slither", gradually building speed. Raising your head is used to climb up platforms or as a a way to try and get your head over a pole to coil around. Raising your head and moving forward are generally how you get past every obstacle in the game. 

Each level has 3 kinds of collectibles: 3 Keystones, 20 Wisps and 5 Coins. You need to collect the 3 keystones to go to the next level. The 20 Wisps are a standard collectible, scattered throughout the level in either obvious or not super obvious places. The coins are the hard to find collectible in each level and generally are more difficult to get too. These 2 types have no impact on anything other than completion rating.

Snake Pass is very slow paced compared to every other platformer. There are a total of 15 levels, each of them relatively small in comparison to other platformers to make up for general slow movement speed. Each world (4 worlds) will introduce a new gameplay mechanic or obstacle to you. The game does a good job of letting you adapt to it's obstacles before moving you on.

This game also has an Arcade Mode and Time Trial. Time Trial has you complete each level within a set time limit while Arcade Mode has you eating different kinds of fruit in a level to build up a big score.

DESIGN
------
Snake Pass design is outstanding. Noodle is silent but he has more character in him and his expressions than 90% of other main characters in any kind of game do. Doodle is a bit more talkative and is the one to point out things in the levels, always anxious and worrysome. The levels are gorgeous and most of them are really well designed, usually being an open area where you have the freedom to get whatever keystone you want. The soundtrack is great, with each world having its own "theme", such as the lava world having deep bongo themes or the cloud world sounding relatively angelic and peaceful.

PROBLEMS
----------
- The camera can be a total disaster for alot of obstacles. While you control it with the RS, getting into slightly tight areas or against walls will move the camera into obnoxious positions making obstacles far harder than they should be.
- Every cutscene is unskippable making replaying the levels that have cutscenes kind of tedious especially if you have to play them quite a bit.
- Standing on a high ledge or platform overlooking the rest of the level, most of the surrounding areas will be very blurry (by design). This makes looking for missed collectibles VERY difficult by doing what should be the obvious way of looking for them.
- Continuing the game will always start the level select on the first level instead of your current progress.

ACHIEVEMENTS
---------------
Snake Pass achievements are great, especially varied and interesting. You'll get about 1/3 of them just by playing through the game, another 1/3 by 100%ing the game and the last 1/3 by doing a bunch of miscellanious stuff. The hardest achievement is probably to complete the game without dying but you if you just go through the levels getting the keystones most levels are easy and fast to complete without dying. I reccomend the following:

1st Level Play: Focus on getting all the collectibles (3 keystones, 20 Wisps, 5 coins, Touching the Guardian Statue)
2nd Level Play: Complete level without dying.

PERSONAL THOUGHTS
----------------------
- I rarely ever used Grip. It didn't really do anything and I found it better to go through the obstacles fast then gripping and going slowly. As you get used to the game mechanics, certain obstacles will become super easy even if they look difficult.
- In the same vain, I rarely ever used the Tail Lift apart from when I was barely hanging off a ledge and I need my tail weight lifted to try and climb up. Other than that I didn't see what purpose it had.
- I liked how most levels were very open and easily memorizeable. Within 10 mins of playing a level I could memorize every area.
- I think this game is designed to be played in short bursts, possibly doing 1-2 levels a day. It will absolutely wear you down if you try to complete it in one sitting.
- The discrepancy of the collectibles is strange. I found that some of the wisps were far more difficult to find or collect than some of the coins were in the same level. Most coins sit behind ledges or off a ledge whereas Wisps can be anywhere.
- I wish there were more unlockable skins for Noodle.
- I found the final level frustrating and the opposite of what every other level before it was.
- I'm thankful Arcade Mode and Time Trial have no achievements attached to them, they'd be very unecesarry.
- Most of the tougher obstacles can be entirely circumvented by climbing the environment around the obstacle rather than doing the obstacle itself which may have lent to the fact as to why the game isn't super difficult.

41382476.review:
Ok, I know I'm like a year late and noone cares about that game anymore, but I need to get this out of my chest.

First of all, I [b]enjoyed[/b] that game, and I [b]recommend[/b] it to anyone that is intrested(thus the thumb up). Now, I'm gonna list only bad things in this game, and maybe even use explicit language out of frustration, so I guess look away if, I don't know, it offend your religion, or something. Keep in mind that despite all those things that needs to be said, it's a good game.

[h1]Characters[/h1]

There's a snake and a hummingbird. Usually they are refered as such, but I think their names are like Noodle and Doodle, or some other poodle, I don't know. The problem is, they have no character. It could be something like Banjo and Kazooie, or Yooka and Leylee, if you're into disappointing Kickstarter games. But no, you get empty set of polygons that shoots a bunch of texts on screen.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Though I couldn't care less about the story, because all I wanted is to collect some things and slide on platforms, I wish the story made [i]some[/i] sense. The whole story is that 2 animals are chilling on a bamboo stick, and then oh no, gates are destroyed. What are those gates? Why there are only 2 animals in this world(that contains of a bunch of flying islands)?

[h1]Hummingbird[/h1]

God is he useless. Normally, both companions are codependent. One can do something, second can do something else, but they mostly corelate together. In this game, there's a snake, that does 99% of the job. The hummingbird can lift your ass of the ground. It may feel like it is useful when you are on the edge trying to climb up, but I think most of the help comes from placebo making you think that you got on the ground using hummingbird's help. Oh yeah, it can also lift you up with those streams of air, but everything about that animations is scripted and they break all laws of physich possible(normally, hummingbird can barely lift your end, but with a help of some wind, it can toss you around across the map[hyperbole, but still]).

[h1]Ending[/h1]

Even though the ending is... is, I'm gonna put it inside the spoiler, because some people may find it a mood-damaging spoiler, so I respect that.

[spoiler]The raven(I don't know the exact specie of that dark bird, and don't care enough to check) seemed like a mean villan, but it was just a rather friendly bird. I liked that "plot twist". But how he destroyed the portals, trying to go back to, whatever is he lives in? Why did he do that? If you need to go to ravenland using those 4 stoney things,
 why do some spirits owe them? What are they anyway Why do they give them to hummingbird, if snake collects all blue balls? CAN SOMEONE TELL ME WHAT THE HELL IS HAPPENING???[/spoiler]

[h1]Vibrations[/h1]

I suppose if you use keyboard there's no problem(unless someone is rich and stupid enough to obtain vibrational keyboard), but if you're using gamepad, you can actually shove is up your ass(or your vagina), since it's vibrating non-stop. I understand that short vibrations are nice when you, perhaps lose some health or something. But this game doesn't understand that maybe if I want to have sex, but I am lonely, I'd rather use a dildo that Wireless Xbox 360 Controller©.
You start level? Get some long-ass vibrations(and at the end get a bit of those slower vibrations, because fuck you)! You've fallen from high ground? Get some vibrations, [b]EVEN THOUGH THERE'S NO FALL DAMAGE[/b]? You've collected [u]anything[/u]? Fuck you, get some vibrations? That's not "immersion", that's being "obnoxious" and "annoying".  It feels like devs found a function for vibrations for Unreal Engine in StackOverflow, and apparently it was so hard they wanted to showcase everyone "look guys, we can google and read!".

[h1]Cutscenes[/h1]

It has been said, please let us skip them or showcase them only once. Such a minor thing to do, but so annoying.

[h1]Camera[/h1]

It's useless. You have to control it yourself, and it still gives you seizure when there's [u]any[/u] object between snake and the camera, because it will zoom so close you will lose the sense of position. Fortunately, you can control camera yourself. If you use gamepad, at least with default key bindings, you have to hold A button with your index finger, which can be unfomfortable, but doable.
Also, [b]is it really that fucking hard to write if(object_nearby_camera) object_nearby_camera.opacity = 0.1???? NO I DON'T WANT TO SEE A FUCKING LEAVES ZOOMED SO MUCH YOU COULD COUNT THE PIXELS WHEM I'M TRYING TO GET THAT COIN?[/b]

[h1]Depth perception[/h1]

Actually, depth perception is not a problem, because THERE IS NONE. You have to guess, whether you're in line with an object.

[h1]Progression[/h1]

As above, there's no progression. There are scripted snake tosses and later on you learn, you can grip to bamboo poles(although you could use it from the beginning). I wish there were some power-ups that let you go to parts of maps that you couldn't go previously or something.

[h1]Level choosing UX[/h1]

Why can't it go to the last level available, instead of going to the first one? Browsing through levels is slow and it is annoing to browse up to your last leve every time you start the game. Also, there are 4 levels in chapter, but you can see only max 3. Why not four? And perhaps all the time? It would be way nicer and clear. And wouldn't be nice if there were like "no deaths" tokens that you get when you beat the level without dying, so it's nice when you're an achievment hunter? Why people can't thing of these things?

[h1]15 levels[/h1]

Really? Really? Every chapter has 4 levels, so why the air one has only 3? It would also nicely feel the void of lack of last level. Because you see, the "last" level is just like every other. It's not bad, but it feels like there's no ending. 16th level could be like a [b]metaphorical[/b] boss fight, or some other arena shit, so you still beat the lever how you've done so fat, but it feels different and refreshing.

[h1]Saving when touching the stones[/h1] It saves progress when you die, but why it cant when you leave the game? Levels can be long, especially is you want to collect everything, and sometimes, you know. Life happenes. Ever heard of that?

It's all I can think of right now, as I said it is still a [b]GOOD[/b] game and I had fun playing that.

41363355.review:
Let's get the great things of this game out of the way: amazing graphics and really creative and innovative game concept idea. Furthermore, at times the controls can be airtight.

And now to my gripes. I love the classic platformers, puzzle games, open world games and the likes (Banjo-Kazooie etc.) and also don't mind the completionist route for games. "Finishing" the worlds became frustrating and a chore, however. The game lacks any real purpose. Collecting the crystals has a purpose, but the orbs and coins? I can take it or leave it. No punishment, no purpose for (not) collecting them.

The story (or lack thereof) was frustrating/not encouraging. Right at the beginning a bird tells you that you need to open the gate or otherwise you will stuck in that place forever. Noodle (the snake/protagonist) seemed perfectly happy sleeping on his bamboo poles. The ending actually gave the game a meaning. If that message had come earlier I might have been more motivated to keep going.

Last but not least, the camera. I can usually play around bad cameras. Heck, I didn't have any problems with Yooka-Laylee and people really complained there. I have never died as often because of the bad camera than in this game.

I wouldn't mind a sequel, but please give me a purpose to play this game and collect the things that seem frustratingly far out of reach. A better checkpoint system (or at least more forgiving one) would also help. In two levels especially, one being the very last, one checkpoint each was nonsensically far away from the next thing to do and replaying became tedious.

41293354.review:
Oh man, Snake Pass is both freaking amazing and freaking frustrating! On the one hand, I absolutely love the game due to it's innovation, beautiful aesthetic and really enjoyable platforming. On the other, I can't stand the absolutely terrible camera and how the snake's head doesn't go where you tell it to 50% of the time. I think this is because the direction the head moves in is tied to the camera so sometimes when you're switching your camera around to get a better look at a particular route, the head ends up going in a different direction than you intended which causes you to unwravel and fall to your death - or less dramatically just to the bottom of the the thing you're trying to climb - way too often.

Overall I really do love this game and I'm glad I bought it but wow would it ever be nice if the devs tweaked the controls a bit more, and while they're at it, maybe they could write another track or two for the music. Yes, the song is catchy but I wanted to tear my ears off after listening to the same song for 4 levels.  Oh, and I'm playing with a gamepad, I can't imagine how terrible this would be to control with mouse and keyboard. If you get easily frustrated by difficult controls this is definitely not the game for you but if you like platformers and want something incredibly unique with a heck of a lot of charm, then give Snake Pass a try, it's pretty cool.

41229584.review:
[h1] [i] Unique Platformer using Snaking Techniques  [/i][/h1]

[b] Overview [/b]
Snake Pass is a simple yet unique platformer where you play as a snake named Noodle as he slithers and coils his way around obstacles collecting all sorts of shiny things and solving a few simple puzzles here and there to unlock the next level. The game is unique amongst platformers in that you do not jump over gaps or obstacles. Instead, as a snake, you must slither and coil around bamboo, lots of them! and get around these obtsacles.


[b] The Good [/b]
Graphically, this game looks absolutely gorgeous. It uses only a simple cartoony style, but it is done with many of the beautiful effects of Unreal 4. The lighting, the shadows, the particle effects, the reflections, the water are all beautiful. Not only that but the animations too are just nice to look at. Noodle's facial expression visibly changes depending if he is happy or scared and there's even a button to manually change his expression!

In terms of gameplay, it is a fairly simple collect-a-thon platformer, with the twist being you cannot jump or do anything typical platformers do. Instead, each level is designed with your sepentine form in mind. You must coil around obstacles to climb, hang on to, and get across gaps. Because of this unique movement, the game's controls are also unique. Instead of a typical moving forwards, back, left or right and jump, you have an accelerate button, a button to raise Noodle's head, and controls to change the direction his head is facing. It is here were I warn any non-controller players: I do not recommend playing this game without a controller. Having free 360 movement with an analogue stick and the ability to control your how quickly you accelerate with analogue triggers helps a lot in later levels. The controls are very weird at first, and you might struggle a bit in the beginning, but after beating the first world, which is basically a tutorial world, you should have a good enough understanding of how movement works. Everything sort of clicks in once you understand the physics of them. There's great joy to be had in slithering around, wrapping around different objects to get to the top of that complicated bamboo structure.

As a collect-a-thon, you have to run... I mean slither, around the entire map, looking around every corner and find every collectable, which is usually placed at some obstacle or simple puzzle. You technically don't have to look for everything as you only need to collect three keys to progress to the next level, but then, you'd be missing out on a large portion of the game. Some of these, collectables, like the coins are much more difficult to obtain and placed on far more difficult obstacles. However, with skill and some patience, you can get through.

I have seen some people call this game "darksouls of platformers". I can say, is, except for the last two levels. Most of the game is not that hard once you grasp the controls. I'd rank the game about as difficult as a typical 3D Mario game, with the last two being on par with Mario secret levels, like the star world from Super Mario World which if you were a kid in the 90s, you know that world was bs.  That said, if you play with a mouse and keyboard then maybe.... Seriously, don't torture yourself. Use a controller.


[b] The Bad [/b]

The camera is bad. Very bad. It works okay in an open space. The problem is it gets shoved forwards and zooms in at even uneven ground or really short fences. It's especially terrible in small confined spaces and areas where theres a "window" and pillars supporting the roof. That means if you are looking at Noodle directly, the camera is fine. But when you rotate it and Noodle starts getting obscured by the "pillar", the camera gets shoved into Noodle's body. This is especially annoying when platforming in small confined areas, and also the camera can get "pushed" by walls and even obscured by decoration. Developers should have taken the 3D Mario approach to camera in confined spaces; that is to make the camera stay the same distance when the camera gets obscured by "pillars" and show Noodle's sillhouette. Having the camera gets shoved forward and back due to some pillar or wall is disorienting and annoying and has caused a few deaths too. 

Besides that, the only other thing that's bad about this game is that it is short. There are only 15 levels. It's short and you could probably beat it in a weekend if you just run right through and ignore some of the more difficult collectables. Thus, the game is about 10 hours long to 100% on your first try, you could shave a couple hours off if you go for a lower percent.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

It's a great game. Worth buying if you like a unique platforming experience. It is on the short side and just be prepared to learn the control scheme. I do not recommend if you do not have a controller.

Graphics - A
Sound - B+
Gameplay - A-
Difficulty - [strike] BabyMode | Easy |[/strike] [b] Normal [/b] [strike] | Hard | Frustrating[/strike]
Length - 8-10 hours

Overall - A- 
(Not an average)

41215719.review:
Fantastic game. I love the concept. The controls are great and very fun to learn. They become surprisingly intuitive very quickly. After that, the game is entirely about figuring out the best path to get your body where you want it to go. It's a very slow platformer that asks you to think rather than throw yourself in and improvise as you go. Granted, you absolutely can throw yourself at the various bamboo pipes and wriggle around until you save yourself or fall off, if you'd rather try to go fast.

Dying isn't much of a setback, anyway. I found the checkpoints to be more than enough to keep me from getting frustrated. I don't recall a single point where I had to redo more than, say, 5 minutes of lost progress. Every time I saw my snake slowly, helplessly slip off a pipe, the drawn out "nooooo"s I uttered and then laughed at myself for saying completely made up for any frustration I had.

Getting most of the bubbles and coins is proving to be very satisfying, since the fun of the game comes entirely from the challenging platforming. I'm only 13 levels in at the time of writing this review, though, and I've only gone back to 100% the first 5 levels or so. I have to say, wandering around empty levels for the last bubble or coin can be long and boring, so I'd actually advise against compulsively completing everything. Take on the climbing challenges that seem interesting, and forget about the bubbles you never even saw. But, either way, do play this game. It's lovely.

41168932.review:
Snake Pass is a delightfully playful and friendly platforming game with a distinct control scheme. With a play-time of around five hours--with an additional number based on extra game modes and one's penchant for collectible hunting--Snake Pass slithers gracefully through four elemental-type environments, each itself composed of four levels. 

The core mechanic underpinning Snake Pass is the dedicated movement controls of Noodle, which sees you sinuously navigate environments and hazardous playgrounds. It's a control scheme that initially intimidates but is easily grasped and a pleasure to become competent at. Back this with a jaunty and pleasing soundtrack, a cheery disposition, and a quick-fire level progression, Snake Pass is slight but entertaining dalliance. But dalliance it remains, as Snake Pass suffers from a dearth of gameplay diversity; the manner in which you play the first level is the manner in which you play all levels. Coupled with this simplicity and absence of content, Snake Pass also suffers from a frantic, frenetic camera, which frequently switches position frequently enough, and in the most precarious moments, that you'll constantly be swearing at the most friendly and jovial platformer you've probably ever played. The troublesome camera is a serious grievance, as it greatly sours the experience of the later game, which requires greater finesse and control.     

As annoying as the camera can frequently be, and acknowledging the lack of diversity within the game, I find myself still adamantly recommending Snake Pass. It's a brief experience, but a pleasant one. Utterly non-offending and welcoming to all, you should probably play Snake Pass.

41063572.review:
I love this game. It’s one of the most truly original games I have played in a long time.
In Snake Pass you control a snake named Noodle. Being a snake, Noodle controls quite unlike any character in any other game.  You can’t simply hold down a direction to move, you have move from side to side to slither like a snake would. Noodle also can’t jump, so to get to higher platforms you need to find something to coil around to climb up. 
Despite being tagged as a puzzle-platformer, this isn’t really a “puzzle” game in the traditional sense. There is really only one puzzle, namely figuring out how to control Noodle. The controls take a little while to get used to but mastering them is very rewarding. With a bit of practice, you will be breezing through sections that seemed impossible at first.
There is also an easy control mode if you want. I advise against using it since mastering the controls is a large part of what makes the game fun, but the option is there if you need it.
I played with a controller. According to the creator, this is how the game was designed to be played. I did try the mouse and keyboard controls before writing this review just to test them out. I found them to be functional, but the controller feels much more natural and I recommend a controller if you have one. 
Contrary to what some other reviews stated, I though the checkpoints were generously placed. And although some of the optional collectibles seem difficult to reach, but there was only one that took me more than a few attempts to collect.
That said, there are several valid complaints.
It is a little short. If you just collect the required items, you can rush through the whole thing in only a few hours, depending on how quickly you master the controls. There are optional collectables – 20 “wisps” and 5 coins in every level, but even 100%ing the game can be done in less than 10 hours, again depending on how quickly you master the controls.
The camera sometimes freaks out in certain areas, especially in confined spaces. This can cause Noodle to move in unexpected ways and occasionally this results in a cheap death. I only died due to this about twice in my whole playthrough, but it was infuriating when it did happen.
There are unskipable cutscenes in most levels which can be quite annoying. Fortunately, there is a time trial mode that unlocks after beating each set of levels which removes all of the cutscenes. 
Noodle is assisted by a hummingbird named Doodle. The fact that they didn’t call the game Noodle-Doodle is really missed opportunity.
Despite these flaws, I still highly recommend this game to anyone who thinks it looks interesting.

41027389.review:
Snake Pass is a 3D puzzle platformer with problems that get made up for very quickly by other aspects of the game.

This game is mainly about finding hidden objects even though your character has no legs. It sounds weird and it's as fun to learn as it is to do the objectives.

The best part about this game is that even though it's frustrating by design (being a puzzle platformer and all) the amazing music from the guy who did Donkey Kong Country keeps your head cool throughout the game. The next best thing is that you'll find even though you're moving through the game at a snail's pace it's fun as hell. The controls are difficult for sure but when you finally master them it's kind of creepy to see how snake-like you move even when you're just traversing flat surfaces. Most of the time the game gives you adequate time to plan your approaches and work your way up with strategy.

Another thing I love about this game is the graphics. They're as beautiful as Yooka-Laylee's with bright, colorful environments that pop out of the screen and make it very easy to see where you can and can't go. Every level has its own flavor and unique style. This is how I want all my platformers to look as it reminds me of the old adventure games.

But it's not perfect.

A lot of the puzzles rely on camera movement to find secrets or see where to go next. Camera movement is very smooth, and this game would unplayable if it wasn't. But it still felt like the camera was the final boss for me. Underwater it's complete garbage and you'll find that 60% of the time there are plants in your face, 30% of the time it will be forcing itself above the water that you're exploring and the last 10% it will look somewhere useful. Fortunately there aren't many water sections and none of them are challenging, purely for exploration. Above water the camera still suffers a little, Rather than making objects between you and the camera transparent, it will rapidly zoom in and become useless. Since you HAVE to move the camera to find secrets that are hidden off the edges of platforms or behind objects this will happen repeatedly in every level, though it doesn't disturb gameplay until you get to the point where there are lots of moving objects.

Speaking of moving objects, the last part of the game is not just frustrating, it feels downright lazy. You'll quickly realize that "wind" and moving objects are not actually that, they're really just zones where your snake has no friction. Enjoy your garbage ice level posing as a wind level - any time something moves or blows near you you'll suddenly have Looney Toon Wiley Coyote physics where you're stationary in the air for a moment before falling to your death. In a game where you don't have enough fingers to move the camera and move your character simultaneously, these final couple of zones are cheap and boring. Early game you can take your time and plan your movement. But I actually found that flinging my snake at objectives and hoping he landed in a place where I could recover from was far better than climbing across pseudo-ice poles with strategy. An unfortunate end to what was otherwise a very enjoyable game.

Overall it was really fun but super short. If you don't play it then get the SOUNDTRACK because it's a classic that I'll keep going back to when I want to hear game music.

Also no skippable corporate intro/cutscenes/credits? What is this a D-tier PS1 game? Get out of here with that bullsh*t.

Oh one more thing - the little bird is a dirty traitor. For every 1 time he saved me he's dunked me into a pit 3 times. Don't use him unless you're certain you'll fall!

★★★✯☆
Aaaaaah such a good child-friendly game, the atmosphere, the graphics, the characters, the story, they are all as if they are made for a child to play through. The only thing that puts me off from giving this to a child to play is … the difficulty, holy hell does the game get extremely difficult at some points, especially the last few levels. They had me screaming and swearing as Doodle would keep on slipping or just not getting to the point he needs to.

The collecting aspect of the game was a selling point for me when I originally saw the game, that alongside the cartoony graphics and playing as a Snake. But the collecting aspect is one I just flat out avoided later on through the game, as the golden coins would get to difficult to collect without spending a huge amount of time getting it and to a save point to not lose your progress, so I eventually just gave up before even finishing the first stage (5 levels) and decided I would just enjoy the game and not focus on collecting every little thing.

And it greatly increased the fun aspect of the game for me so I would recommend others to do this as well as getting 100% in this game would require you to gather all the collectibles, finish the game without dying once!!! And doing a few other objectives. One really good point is that the game has time trials but not any time trial achievements, which is a big bonus as those achievements always make a lot of people waste far to much time getting that gold trophy.

I would recommend this game to someone wanting to take a break from Dark Souls and enjoy a more child-friendly happy go lucky version of a difficult game XD (okay no it isn’t that difficult). I would recommend this game to general gamers, casual gamers and people who like collectathons. 3.5/5!!!

40836822.review:
I'm sure that the full game is incredibly fun for those who appreciate the different kind of platformer that this presents but it just doesn't work for me.  
  
Visually, it's very good and it's an interesting concept to say the least. The snake here is just that, a snake (although with amazing gripping power on almost thin air), and that makes the game feel like something new right out of the bat.  
  
HOWEVER,  
  
[*] The controls really aren't very good: I've seen some comments stating that <2hours' players shouldn't really complain about the controls but that makes no sense. If you have to battle the game for 2 full hours to get the grip of it, I'm staying away from it. I'm a fan of increasing a game's difficulty by enemies, terrain and so on but making the mechanisms of it faulty really isn't a good reason;  
  
[*] All the cutscenes are unskipable: sure, that doesn't sound like much but the story really isn't something worth seeing and, alas, you're forced to see it anyway;  
  
[*] The checkpoints: You pass a checkpoint, start doing the important bit of the level, fall, and here you are again by the checkpoint having to do the whole puzzle again. You can go back to your checkpoint mid puzzle to save it, but why should you? If you're grabbing an orb, it should just save that at that point. Resetting your whole progress in a game that makes you fall simply because the controls aren't the best, really isn't a proper way of setting it.  
   
Overall, a not very enjoyable game, even for the little time I played it. I'll keep it installed since I lack platformers in my library and might want to give it a try once again, but it's just frustrating.

40792551.review:
Jugando a Snake Pass

Empiezo diciendo que yo he jugado con mando de 360, para movernos en ‘Snake Pass’ lo único que debemos hacer es pulsar RT para avanzar. Si lo hacemos en línea recta el paso será muy lento, deberemos ir serpenteando para acelerar.
Si llegamos a un obstáculo y queremos superarlo deberemos elevar la cabeza pulsando el botón A, mientras que si queremos cerrar nuestros giros para agarrarnos a palos y escaleras deberemos sujetar el botón LT, momento en el que la serpiente seguirá moviéndose pero con una fricción mucho más acusada y velocidad casi nula.

Hasta aquí todo bien, de hecho los primeros niveles son una auténtica gozada en la que poco a poco le vas cogiendo el truco a eso de enrollarte, recuperar coleccionables y salvarte por los pelos pidiéndole al pájaro que te acompaña que sujete tu cola con el botón Y para que el peso de tu cuerpo no te arrastre hasta una muerte segura.

Un control infernal

Tras ello llegas a una zona con un tobogán, un divertido descenso que acaba en una laguna (también puedes bucear). Pero lo que no sabes es que a donde acabas de descender no es a un oasis que forma parte de la colorida selva del juego, acabas de realizar tu viaje hacia el infierno.

Los puzles se complican, los checkpoint dejan de tener el más mínimo sentido lógico en sus posiciones, caer supone la muerte o tener que volver a rehacer un recorrido enorme con varias posibilidades de morir o volver a caer, los palos empiezan a moverse y a empujarte antes de que puedas agarrarte a ellos.

No es una cuestión de reto, sabes lo que tienes que hacer en todo momento. Tampoco una cuestión de habilidad, has subido por zonas similares en más de una ocasión. Y por supuesto tampoco es un problema de dificultad porque, de funcionar bien el movimiento de la serpiente, de servir a un esquema lógico o más profundo que no se limite a cuatro botones, una cámara que no ayuda y un pájaro que siempre escoge el peor sitio posible para colocarse en pantalla, ‘Snake Pass’ sería un juego tan original como divertido y asequible.

Una triste decepción

Sin todo eso, o al menos sin la posibilidad de que cuando quieras estar quieto estando bien agarrado a una rama, el bicho se esté quieto y te deje pensar tu próximo movimiento, o que cuando quieres bajar la cabeza y volver a subirla por debajo de una rama para enrollarte la serpiente no empiece a hacerse la picha un lío volviendo a sacar la cabeza por donde no tocaba, me lo habría pasado en grande con el juego.

El movimiento de la serpiente es como un niño con la vejiga floja que llega a casa después de estar un buen rato aguantándose el pis. Por mucho que le digas que aguante, antes de levantar la tapa ya estará meando por todos lados.

Es cierto que puedes acabar cogiéndole el truco a ‘Snake Pass’, que es lo suficientemente corto para que la frustración no dure mucho y que si tienes ganas de exprimirlo aún más, sus coleccionables te van a tener un buen rato entretenido, pero que el 75% de toda la meada haya caído dentro de la taza nunca ha sido razón suficiente para decirle a alguien: "buen trabajo".

40514781.review:
I'm using an XBox 360 controller. Controls are unusual, but work very good for this "snake simulator".

But this game is not as casual as it looks like: The snake (Noodle) dies when it falls down. There are checkpoints, but the "saved" progress is lost when you quit the game, so you have to finish each level in one (possibly long) session.

This makes it unnecessarily hard to get full completion of bonus objectives of a level before advancing. The frustration caused by this is the only reason why I can't recommend this otherwise great game.

Edit:

This mini-review is not meant to discuss all aspects of the game, just the [b]unnecessarily hard[/b] part of the game making a game-play difference between pausing the game and exiting the game.

If I were to write a review of a car where you will have to drive home instead of to your intended destination just because you turned off the motor at a parking place, this one aspect would be enough to not recommend it, too, even if otherwise it is a very good car.

And a game with such a car would not test my driving skills, just my willingness to keep the motor running. I can't recommend a game which tests my willingness to keep the motor running.

Edit2:

40244492.review:
Unskippable cutscenes, an annoying checkpoint system that deters players from taking risks, a finicky camera, and a unique, yet frustrating control scheme make Snake Pass an incredible chore to play. At least its graphics are sssstupendous.

All its flaws work together to antagonize the player as much as a possible. You have a checkpoint system where falling to your doom means losing progress. In other kinds of platformers, you'd have the solution down and be able to repeat your steps and get right back to business. Here, you're always wrestling with the controls which makes any reattempts not go as quick as you might think despite knowing what to do. Noodle’s head will sometimes suddenly start unraveling your coil around a bamboo in the opposite direction if his head doesn’t wrap around in the way the game wants (nose hitting the bamboo at just the right angle to split off into the unintended direction).

In addition to having all your fingers busy to control Noodle, sometimes the camera will decide to work against you. The only way to fight back is to set it straight with your thumb using the right stick. This action can interrupt your platforming or slow down traversal until you adjust the camera so that you’re not looking at the floor of an upper level or a wall or having a bird’s eye view. It’s a frequently occurring issue.

I don't even want to explore the levels. To save myself time from lost progress, I'd have to slither back to a checkpoint to gather those golden coins which are usually place in precarious locations around the level. Sometimes the little balls of water will be dangerous to reach too. Anyway, going back to activate a checkpoint to save in-between coin attempts is tedious and ironically also wastes time. I’m wasting my time, especially when after falling off a high platform, it takes another good minute to return to that spot by normal means. Or maybe they wanted to encourage jumping off to respawn quicker which I’ve done when no collectibles were at stake. I also skipped most of the collectibles that weren’t mandatory the more I played. 

Still, it’s a beautiful game and tried something different. I can at least give a nod to what they were trying to do. You can occasionally feel well-accomplished too after navigating a difficult environment successfully, but those moments are too few and far between.

You cannot depend on Snake Pass to provide an enjoyable experience. I can imagine some people digging its control scheme in the same way others can enjoy Surgeon Simulator, I Am Bread, or Getting Over It. If you didn’t enjoy those games, there’s a high probability of disappointment with Snake Pass too. I had high hopes. Unfortunately, I have to point people in the direction of A Hat in Time instead for their 3D platformer fix.

A great concept completely destroyed by horrible checkpoint placement, lack of saving options, and awful camera.

Snake pass really grabbed me at first. The way you move and climb with Noodle is such a unique style of locomotion, and the characters are so charming, it will grab you too. Unfortunately, after grabbing you, it will choke you and shake you violently. After the first world, you will enter into a video game hell. You will swear as you try desperately cling to a climbing obstacle, wishing you had *three hands* so you could re-position the camera, as Noodle's movement depends on where the camera is positioned. Then, Noodle will slip, you will fall way back down into some water, and you will wonder, "Why wasn't there a checkpoint *right* before that challenge!?" You will waste time climbing over a ton of easy stuff again, then fall in the water, repeat for 60 minutes, be shaking with rage, then you will think, "Maybe I'm frustrated... I should take a break and calm down."

The game will inform you, "If you quit, you will lose all your progress!" It really means this. It will not save any collectibles from the level, if will not save any checkpoints. You will have to start from scratch if you want to take a break from this teeth-clenching frustration simulator.

I really wanted to love this game. It's too bad that so much talent can be WASTED by horrible design decisions like these. I could even forgive the camera, as that is a unique technical challenge, but the checkpoint and save systems are NOT.

I started this game up because I needed something to cheer me up. An hour later now tonight, I was screaming at my television, grinding my teeth, and swearing at this adorable snake, and I gave up. 40056281.review:
Snake Pass, un plataformas en el que no puedes saltar, con unos gráficos preciosos, unas plataformas simples pero bien implementadas y una banda sonora deliciosa.

El encarnar a una serpiente es la gran apuesta de este titulo, lo que lo hace especial pero también lo que lo hace tedioso, me explico, Noodle solo puede reptar y levantar su cabeza, y con esas 2 mecanicas nos pasaremos el juego entero, tendremos tambien el apoyo del colibrí para evitar que el peso de nuestra cola nos juege malas pasadas, con todo esto se consigue una gran sensación sobretodo a la mitad - final del juego, cuando vas pasando cada plataforma midiendo el agarre de Noodle en cada bambú con caidas controladas y llegando a sitios imposibles unicamente con un palo de por medio. 

El problema viene como decia en que somos una serpiente, por lo tanto tenemos que ir serpenteando TODO el tiempo para poder movernos, es decir ir de izquierda a derecha sucesivamente, con un botón de acelerar para poder medir la "velocidad", de igual forma tienes que agarrarte bien tanto al terreno como las plataformas, haciendo que un exceso/disminuyo de la velocidad o un mal angulo de la cabeza pueda hacernos caer fácilmente, además acostumbrarse a llevar a Noodle es demasiado complicado en las primeras horas de juego, ya que nadie está acostumbrado a estas mécanicas en un plataformas, y despues de varios intentos fallidos el jugador puede frustrarse.

Eso no quiere decir que el juego tenga una dificultad elevada, ni mucho menos, recoger lo necesario (3 gemas) para abandonar el nivel es sencillo incluso en los últimos niveles, pero el juego incluye ciertas bolas azules, 1 idolo y  5 monedas escondidas en cada nivel, estas últimas son el mayor reto del juego, estando mas escondidas o en sitios dificiles de llegar, exigiendo al jugador saber controlar a Noodle en su perfección. ( Añadir que aunque cojas cierto coleccionable no sera "tuyo" hasta que no llegues a un punto de guardado, que estan repartidos por los niveles, por lo tanto no vale con tocar la bola/moneda y morir.)

La facilidad para conseguir las gemas y la dificultad para conseguir las monedas hacen que el juego pueda ser disfrutado tanto por adultos como para los mas peques, o simplemente para gente que sea mas casual o realmente busque un reto en este plataformas. (Además creo que es necesario recoger todos los secretos para desvelar un pequeño final)

Hablamos de 15 niveles, repartidos en 4 mundos, ( jungla, agua, fuego y aire) con plataformas que iran variando, fijas, moviles, con mecanismos, trampas...) 

Una historia muy simplona, happy y con posibilidad de secuela, pocos personajes y pocos dialogos, pero las animaciones tanto de Noodle como del colibrí estan muy bien logradas y hacen que sean personajes "cukis" muy agradables a la vista y que seguro que llamarán la atención de los mas pekes ( y no tan pekes )

Al finalizarlo se recompensa al jugador con otro modo de juego, alguna skin graciosa y un modo de visión para terminar de recoger los coleccionables restantes.

Como punto negativo aparte del dificil control en su comienzo, esta la camara, que es fija y que no ayuda en muchas plataformas y puede ser causante de bastantes muertes, además diria que a veces la suerte también juega un papel importante tanto para bien como para mal, sobretodo en algunas plataformas moviles, o algunas fisicas gracias al agarre (a veces superfuerte, a veces superflojo) que tiene Noodle, además de algunos pequeños bugs que hacen que te agarres una vez estas casi fuera del mapa y mágicamente puedas ir trepando hasta volver a un punto seguro, o que el colibrí a veces la lie al cogerte de la cola, o al enviarte volando en los últimos niveles... 

En difinitiva un buen plataformas con una duración de unas 8 horillas si quieres completarlo todo y hacer ciertos trofeos, diferente, fresco, precioso en sus grafícos, animaciones, colores, paisajes, diseño de niveles y banda sonora.

No es perfecto pero si lo ves barato y te llama la atención, te aseguro que vale la pena.

40050035.review: Clunky, uncomfortable, confusing. I got this for free and I would still like to refund it.

40038850.review:
Snake Pass is a highly unique 3D platforming game. You play as Noodle the Snake, and the twist of this game is that you need to move like a snake – slithering around, wrapping yourself around stuff to climb, and, most importantly, completely lacking the ability to jump. Assisting you is Doodle the Hummingbird, whose contribution is primarily lifting your tail on command.

This is a very unique game – the lack of ability to jump and the ability to slither around obstacles is very interesting, but it is also something which comes with a bit of a learning curve. Rather than the left joystick controlling your direction of movement, instead it controls the direction your head is turning, with a shoulder button used to push yourself forward. This is unintuitive at first, but is necessary for overcoming the various challenges in the game. You have the ability to lift your head (gravity will lower it on its own, though there is a dedicated dive button for the obligatory water sections), grip more tightly to what you’re clinging to (slowing your movement speed and helping you slither more tightly around the many thin poles strewing the levels), and the ability to have your hummingbird companion lift your tail when it is dangling off inconveniently into space. Being a snake, rather than moving in a straight line on the ground (or in the water), you instead move at the highest rate of speed by slithering your head back and forth.

Despite the novel control scheme, the game itself is pretty straightforward – it starts out simple in terms of obstacles, but then adds increasingly more complex and dangerous obstacles along the way, ranging from switches and moving platforms to blowing wind and ever more difficult to slither around platforming sections. There are no living enemies in any of the levels; it is only the environment, and the many bottomless pits, pits of coal, and spikes that can “kill” you. However, death is only a minor setback, putting you back at the last checkpoint, which you can manually run over to re-activate – a handy thing, considering that collectibles grabbed since the last checkpoint go away, to prevent kamikaze runs on collectibles – you have to collect that coin hanging way out in empty air and *survive* to keep it.

The primary objective in each level is to collect three colored crystals, which unlock the gate, each of which is located in some prominent but hard-to-reach location, with a convenient colored skybeam indicating what direction you’re supposed to go in. There are also secondary collectibles in each level, in the form of 20 blue orbs (mostly in pretty obvious locations) and 5 much more hidden coins (which are sometimes hard to see, and other times simply very hard to get to safely). Navigating the levels is the lowest level of challenge, with collecting all the collectibles the thing that will really tax your skills.



It isn’t a terribly long game – 15 levels in all, with the whole game taking perhaps six hours to beat, or twice that to 100% the game. The core gameplay isn’t hugely difficult at first, but it ramps up over time, with the final level being much, much harder than the first. However, because you are learning the control scheme early on, the early parts will seem harder than they actually are, while the later levels, despite their added difficulty, won’t feel too bad. The biggest hump in the game is mastering the control scheme – once you understand how to control Noodle, the game becomes much less frustrating, and is much more of a set up for some fairly unique 3D platforming.

Aesthetically, this game reminds me very heavily of the N64 era – while the graphics are much higher fidelity, the characters are cute animals and the levels have music reminiscent of that era. While the background music was passable, it wasn’t anything particularly memorable, and I’d say that about the aesthetics in general – it feels like many other games Rare made, even though it wasn’t made by Rare. The game’s levels are split up by a level select screen rather than a hubworld, which gives the game a slightly barebones feel – something reinforced by the very bare bones story, which is essentially nonexistent and anticlimactic. But let’s face it – your real goal in this game is to collect the shinies, not to care about the plot.

This is not a game for everyone. But it is a game for people who are interested in 3D platformers, but who would like to see something very different out of one of them. This is a very unique game, and the control scheme is likely unlike anything you’ve ever played before. As such, I’d say this is worth playing if you’re into 3D platformer games, but it isn’t really something that people who aren’t already into that genre are likely to appreciate.

40021614.review:
Snake Pass is a wonderful game, though obviously not for everybody. It's slow, can get quite tedious, and the controls can be hard to learn, but once you do and if you can get past those things (I wouldn't even call them problems, it's a puZZZZSSsssssssssle platformer), Snake Pass becomes a delightfully charming game with tons to explore. Sure, the collectibles don't do much but they're challenging and fun to collect. There's obvious set ways of completing each puzzle but there's also these fun alternate ways of completing these challenges you can find just by exploring the levels (Here's one: https://gfycat.com/SadCarefulAmericanwarmblood )

39972875.review:
Snake Pass is a really fun and unique platformer.

Although, maybe platformer is the wrong word as what defines the game are the unique controls that let you move around your snake protagonist Noodle. Instead of jumping, you slither, wrap around and cling. It's a wonderfully refreshing way to navigate the game's 15 increasingly complex levels. I felt that the controls were pretty easy to get a hang of, and didn't take too long to master either, which is good, as the environmental hazards escalate on a steady, well designed difficulty curve.

The music is upbeat and catchy (and I found myself wishing the soundtrack would be available outside of the game) and the visuals are really pretty too. Having Nvidia Ansel integration is also a really neat plus, though I found myself using it less for taking screenshots and more for zooming around the level trying to find the remaining collectibles, haha (hey, I basically just switched to playing as Noodle's hummingbird friend Doodle).

A few minor nitpicks were that the achievements were bugged for me (although I'm not entirely sure it was the game's fault rather than my computer's?), as well as the fact that when playing on a controller you'll find yourself pressing down the right trigger pretty much constantly to move forward, which can create a bit of a strain on your hand if you play for longer sessions.

Overall, I would highly recommend Snake Pass if you're looking for a gentle challenge and are into upbeat, non-violent games with unique and new gameplay ideas.

I feel like this game should be more fun that it is. They had a nice concept, and just didn't make the most of it. Wrapping yourself around objects to climb your way up for a bit is fun but... Only for so long. Entire levels of more of the same isn't fun. It's not even that challenging.

The real issue is this game touches on trying to be so many things, it misses all of them.

Innovative mechanics indie game? Barely. You are a snake, but there are swo many missed possiblities, like gripping and moving objects with your noodly body, or perhaps ingesting things to change your snake's shape or ability.

Collection quest? Barely. There's a few items to collect on each level and the hardest ones aren't that hard to find, nor that interesting to find either.

39927963.review:
A delightful colectophon with a unique twist on traditional „platforming.” Game consists of 15 levels. It is not much, but they are well designed and quite lengthy. While it would be always nice to have more of Snake Pass, I think the game as is, fully explores the depth of the movement system.

The biggest joy of the game are controls. You control snake, which game simulates really well. Gameplay revolves around gaining momentum by slithering, wrapping around environment to gain traction, which will counteract the weight of your body. Game doesn’t have much in terms of additional gimmicks, but basic movement has enough depth to carry the game. Unlike most of “physics” games, Snake Pass has reliable and tight controls. As it can be the case in 3D “platformers” camera can be bothersome in tight spaces, but there were really few instances when it was the case.

I played the game twice as the time of writing - once with keyboard and once with a controller. If you have a choice, I strongly recommend a pad - it just feels and controls far better,

One complaint I have  with the game are the unskippable cutscenes. There aren’t many of them, but when you replay first and last level, be prepared to sit through unskippable cutscenes/credit sequence every time. 

Overall, and innovative and really entertaining title. With a learning curve - it is not hard once you grasp basics, but due to unique controls it take a while to master.

39927839.review:
Snake Pass is a well designed puzzle platformer that takes a single mechanic (you're a snake that can wrap around poles) and creates a memorable experience.  

The visuals are absolutely stunning, colourful and fun, they really succeed at taking a challenging game and making it feel approachable. 

The difficulty curve is pretty well balanced thoughtout the game but it is a very challenging game.  Going for the collectables can present a significant challenge early on if you're not fully familiar with the controls but after a few hours you'll easily be slithering around with the best of them.  My advice would be to complete the game without them and then go back for a second run.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game and would highly recommend giving it a go.  

Note: I got the game in a Humble Bundle, so didn't pay much for it.  As such i wasn't really expecting much but was pleasantly surprised.  I probably wouldn'y pay the full £15.99 for it but getting it on sale would definitely be worthwhile.

39895454.review:
Snake Pass is a puzzle snake simulator. The objective is for you to play as a snake and collect bubbles, coins and 3 coloured gems in every stage. The most important thing are the 3 coloured gems as that opens the exit. Snake Pass is not the snake puzzle that you used to find on your Nokia phones. This is a totally different ball game where you try to use overly complex controls to move a snake up and down points. 

Gameplay-wise, Left Click to move forward, SD to turn your head left and right, Space to mvoe the head up and Ctrl to Grip and Dive. 

Conclusion, it's not a good game. The controls are overly complex requiring the player to press multiple keys, stop and rotate. The point of view does not help when trying to control the snake's head. 

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Sounds Like Snake the mobile game
I thought it was too. 

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Overly Complex Controls
Way too complex to play. Your view is not optimized to control the snake. You have press space just to lift the snake's head.

2. Where's the Excitement?
Ok, I collect the gems, coins and bubbles and then what happens? Oh, I open the next stage which is another level of collecting gems, coins and bubbles. Where's the fun and excitement?

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Mouse and WASD keys
Use the mouse pointer like a string pulling on the head. That way you can do complex actions like wrapping around things.

39889643.review:
After twelve hours I've now finished the game and gathered 90% of its collectibles. I've already dabbled in time trial mode a fair bit, it is surprisingly enjoyable and since the game is not immensely well known I've already managed some top 50 ranks. I anticipate that I'll put another ten hours into gathering the remaining collectibles and getting reasonable times on all stages in time trial.

 [h1] The Good [/h1] 
Gameplay is first in snake pass and it is where the game shines most. I feel it is enjoyable in a similar way that super meat boy or mirror's edge (or maybe ori and the blind forest) might be enjoyable. All the control options are available from the start and the game only teaches you how to use them as you go along. The game starts you off with a body that gets in your way all the time and even moving on flat floor is not trivial, not to speak of climbing. At the end of the game you are a snake deity that is more flying than wiggling through the stages, and all the difference is just learning the controls. Initially you learn how to curl around objects and slowly move from branch to branch, and for a long time there is usually a slow and safe way to go through obstacles. But there is always a fast and unsafe option as well and eventually you will need to learn how to do that too. This is what made the game so much fun for me, because after some initial struggle this is actually easier than expected and it's just so much fun. There is a steep learning curve at the start which might be frustrating, but after that you realize that the game isn't actually that hard. Gathering all the collectibles adds a lot to the challenge, so players can choose their difficulty level.

As you can guess from the above, this is a game of skill, it is not a game of strategy or puzzle and there is also no story, though it does have a lot of atmosphere. The characters are super cute and the levels are bright and bubbly and atmospheric. It feels polished and the whole design is just so sweet and happy. 

This is where the positive part ends and I'll adress a couple negative points that I feel need to be pointed out. All in all I really enjoyed the game and most of the following classifies as minor and did not make me enjoy the game less.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
Most importantly the price is just plain too high and there should be a free demo. I didn't buy it on sale because when I saw the right videos of it I felt I really needed to play it right then. And it worked and I enjoyed it as much as I anticipated and for me the price is justified. But still I feel that it doesn't offer enough content to justify the price, because not everyone will get as much out of time trial as I do nor gather even half the available collectibles. More importantly though, I'm hesitant to recommend this to people who are not experienced with platformers or speedrunning in some way because it might be either very enjoyable or very frustrating depending on how quickly people pick up the game. And I wouldn't want to make anyone spend 20€ on a game which they end up hating after three hours. A free demo of the first chapter would really help.

The second issue is the camera, which caused a fair share of my deaths because the game is brutal if you see it at a bad angle. The camera is almost completely manually controlled so I strongly recommend finding a setup where you can adjust the camera constantly while you are moving through even intense sections. I found playing it with a controller with two sticks and all relevant buttons bound to the shoulder buttons made the game a lot more enjoyable. An issue here is that the game does not allow rebinding keys which it really should, so I had to use an external software to rebind keys instead. The keyboard and mouse controls are better for controlling the camera and when I tried them for half an hour there weren't any terrible issues compared to the controller, except that I was not used to them. They might make it harder to pick up the controls initially, I can't comment on that.

Checkpoints in my opinion were generally available a tiny bit after when I felt I wanted one, which is how it should be because it keeps things interesting. However in a few key sections checkpoints were really scarce, this happens especially in a some areas that also have a bump in difficulty. I never struggled with a section for more than a few minutes but I did pick up the controls fairly quickly and this might make the game really frustrating if you don't. It did affect my gameplay sometimes in that I would rush forward to a checkpoint and then come back for a collectible; I feel this is how it should be in a way, because it makes the experience matter just a bit more. A thing to note here is that in many sections the game will allow players to pick the difficulty through the choice of which collectibles they will get. Skipping a few collectibles made the game more managable and when you come back later you get to breeze through these levels that you were struggling with, which I found very rewarding.

Lastly, the game contains unskippable cutscenes, which is just unnecessary. Plus after you collect everything there is in the stage the game will still offer you the classic mode first instead of having time trial as a default. These are just nuisances but they shouldn't be there.

To sum up, if you're into platformers or you have some patience with games then this will be very enjoyable. The bright atmosphere is a nice bonus. I think it's important that game developers produce genre-breaking games occasionally and this one really nails it for me.

39882772.review:
This game has a lot going for it.  I think the core gameplay of this game is fun.  It's gorgeous.  It's cute.  I don't even mind the controls playing with the keyboard and mouse.  But I do mind a lot of quality of life stuff that's just missing.  It's gone.  It's just not there.  After thinking about it, it honestly feelsjust so weird that it seems like they put a lot of time into inventing puzzles and making it gorgeous, and then didn't care about everything else.

Navigating menus is a chore.  You have to use the keyboard to navigate anything.  To choose a level it starts you at the first level every time and you have to manually move through the worlds one level at a time until you get to the level you're on.  Cutscenes are unskippable and play every time you play a level, which wouldn't be a problem if half the game wasn't gathering up collectibles.  They don't play in time attack, but that has to be unlocked so if you want to get all the collectibles as you go you have to get it on your first shot or deal with the cutscenes.

You can use the bird to hold your tail up to help keep you in certain positions but on gathering the collectibles needed to advance or putting them on their pedestals the bird will just drop you which can lose you progress just so the game can play an animation of the bird.  You can then have him pick you back up, so it isn't even a design choice.  It's literally just to play the animation.

Certain achievements you get by doing specific things on specific levels are bugged and require going back to the main menu to restart, even though there's a restart button.  Trying to replay a level after you've completed it to get more collectibles resets all the collectibles you got on that playthrough, meaning you not only need to collect the ones you missed but also the ones you obtained.  The restart button does restart the game, but it forgets your progress unless its detrimental to you.  Which means going through the menus, which again, is a chore.  This game shines when it lets you play but so much of this game seems to just want you to not play.

This is a fun game.  It really is.  But after three and a half hours, I just can't get over these problems.  They keep shoving themself in my face over and over.  There's not a level that's gone by where SOMETHING hasn't come up and just sucked me out of whatever fun I was having  If the menus were just bad that would be fine, but they keep making me go back to it.  I can't recommend this game unless you have the patience to deal with not just a finnicky physics game but also with frustrating design choices (or lack of choices) that are generally unrelated to gameplay.
